name: Gone Home
description: June 7th, 1995. 1:15 AM. You arrive home after a year abroad. You expect your family to greet you, but the house is empty. Something's not right. Where is everyone? And what's happened here? Unravel the mystery for yourself in Gone Home, a story exploration game from The Fullbright Company.
minimum_requirements: •  Windows 7 SP1 or higher •  1.80GHz Processor •  2GB Memory •  DX10 Video card with 512MB of VRAM • (NOTE: Intel HD Graphic 4000 NOT CURRENTLY SUPPORTED on Windows 8) •  2GB HDD space

reviews.review_text: First of all, for those who are arguing this is supposed to be a horror game, it's not. The basic storyline is 'you come home and nobody is there, find out why' and not 'zombies have taken over the house and lurk in the basement'.  Yes, 'Gone Home' is short, once you know where to find the information and the keys, you can play it in a little over 10 minutes ... but that means only going through the house and triggering the ending sequence, that kind of playing will not give you the complete story. The story, however, is not just about Sam (the sister). You can also find out about your father's troubles with writing, about his weird uncle, who owned the house before the family moved in, and other stuff. Basically, the game lets you catch up with the family history during the time you were in Europe.  It's an everyday story, not something great or heroic or scary. It's just the unease everyone would feel alone in a house they've never been in before, at after 1 a.m. on a night with a thunderstorm, not atmospheric horror like in 'Amnesia.'  $20 might indeed be a little much for the game... and 'game' a little too much of a word for 'Gone Home' but it does not deserve all the bad reviews it has gotten. If you want an action game, this is not for you... but that should be obvious from the description. If you like uncovering a story for yourself, you might want to give it a chance.

Gone Home is an emotional immersive story. It's very thought provoking and will stay with you for a while after finishing the game. It's a great experience for those that love story based games. I am not going to go in to detail about the game because i don't want to spoil it for others.  Would i recommend the game yes. I would even give this game a 9/10.
referenced nirvana and sonic youth  also made me bawl my eyes out  10/10
a game about white people who cant exorcise a ghost. read the book instead.   took me 69 minutes to complete (the sex number)
This game is superb and delivers such a unique experience woven with a touching and personal story. You owe it to yourself to check it out.

Without ruining too much, this is one of the most atmospheric stories I've played in years. Note that I used the word story instead of 'game'. If you're expecting a traditional adventure or horror game, you'll not find it here. Instead the game manages to capture the essence of the nineties while keeping you in a constant state of psychological tension as you explore a mysteriously abandoned home (with more than a few uncomfortable secrets to discover). As someone who grew up in the 90s, listened to riot grrrl, played bass in a riot grrrl band and experienced a very similar coming of age as the invisible protagonist, Sam... I can perhaps relate to the themes conveyed more than the average gamer demographic. Perhaps because of that, I consider this to be one of my favourite games of the year. It's an experience which rewards slow-paced exploration and the ability to soak in the atmosphere of the era. It's also very short, I finished it in about four hours despite taking my time in piecing together the subtle threads of the story and exploring the manor obsessively. I don't consider this to be a bad thing, as it suits the game's purpose of telling the story of a slightly dysfunctional family and their history. There is no need to pad it out with unnecessary content. By the end, I was deeply moved and pleasantly surprised... in my opinion, there need to be more games like this in the world. Period.

BUY THIS GAME ON SALE. DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE. Unless you look at EVERY object in the game or take a break in the middle of game play, the game should take about two hours MAX to complete. This game is almost haunting, at times heartbreaking, and at other times heartwarming.  Overall, though it is a quick and simple game, it is worth playing if you like story-rich games featuring a female protaganist.

This isn't the easiest game to describe, let alone review. Some nitpicky people will even try to tell you it's not a game at all, since there's no way to die/fail/lose. There's only one level, only one thing you work towards, and then it's over. A mere 3 hours in (for me personally).  That can't be good, can it? It is. It so is.  The player controls Kaitlin Greenbriar who, after a year of travelling abroad, has Gone Home. Her homecoming isn't quite as she'd planned it though, since nobody appears to be there to greet her. What follows is an exploration of a large house, its history, what your family has been up to in the year that you weren't there, and why nobody is there.  This exploration is done very literally, you roam through the house in a first person perspective and look at things that you find. Almost everything can be picked up and analysed, most of it won't progress the game along (should you choose you can spend half an hour looking at a pack of toilet paper from all angles). What this accomplishes is that the house you wander around in feels very real. It's not laid out like a videogame level (mostly anyway), it actually feels like a home.  Some objects spark memories, either Kaitlin's or those of her younger sister, Samantha. The protagonist's are displayed along the bottom of the screen, but Samantha's are fully voiced, generally taking the form of diary entries. The voice acting is believable, emotional, endearing.  The game tells you a story, primarily Samantha's, of how Kaitlin being away has impacted her life, what she's been up to, how she handled moving to a new house, how she's making new friends. Endearing is a word I've used already in this review, several times maybe even, but that's what the game makes you do. You care about Samantha, and every diary excerpt you uncover makes you care a little bit more.  By the time you've finally made your way to the last room to explore (game progress is generally non-linear except for two or three segments where you have to know a trick that is only explained in Samantha's diary entries to gain entry to a new part of the house) you'll be hooked and want to know the conclusion.  And I  loved  the conclusion. The entire game builds up to it so well, both foreshadowing and alluding, and it's amazing feat of storytelling. Treat yourself and play this game, but expect to be told a story and explore a house, not to have your reflexes challenged. Definitely, passionately and endearingly recommended.

You are not the protagonist, and Gone Home is not your story.   In most games, the players write their own stories: their actions and struggles define the game plot. Not so in Gone Home: this game asks you to explore the stories of other people (your family, mostly, including the psycho great-uncle Oscar). Your impact on these people is zero, because during the game, they're not home. Also, their stories are hidden: you need to find it in odds and ends strewn around the house, and even if you find them all, there'll be a lot left to the imagination (provided you have any).  If you're a narcisstic person with no emotional intelligence, this game will leave you cold because it won't be about you, but about other poeple's feelings. If you aren't, you'll enjoy a good teenie 'chick-flick' story told from a very different angle. If you're a child of the nineties, it's worth it for amount of love and detail that went into the whole house alone. Rarely have I wandered through a game and felt so immersed.

To experience a story just by discovery and reading with no violence or other characters actually around can be amazing if done right. Gone Home is one of those experiences. I wasn’t sure what to expect when starting up Gone Home. I didn’t read much on it before getting it just thought it looked cool and said why not.  You are Katie Greenbriar who has just arrived home after been abroad for a year. Unfortunately no one is home to greet you but it’s not really a bad thing either. The story is told through exploration and discovery. Letters scattered throughout the house written and narrated by your sister are spoken with such emotion and feeling that just sucks you in. It was wonderful hearing her talk about how she falls in love with a girl who is her best friend and the issues that came along with that and just growing up.  You can also discover the stories of you mom, dad, and an uncle who is deceased by things you pick up through the house. Dad getting some success as a writer and losing it. Mom seeming to be lonely and maybe having an affair. Uncle supposedly haunting the house you live in. It really makes you feel like you’re really there doing it in real life.  Almost everything in the game is interactive to deepen the immersion. Turn lights on and off, open and close drawers, and listen to music from cassette tapes you find. Find secret passages through the house to expand on the stories. Sound in the game is fantastic with the sound of rain and thunder outside while you wander around the house. I could have sworn I even heard other sounds at times which may have been a ghost.   There’s no violence or interaction with other characters, just some wonderful stories to discover all while having a nice relaxing time. Only problem I have is there’s not lots more to discover and keep me sucked into this world. So try it out when you have a few hours to spare and see if you have an experience to remember.  Bear Rating: 9.5/10

Gone Home tells the story of a young woman coming home in the nineties. Her sister is supposed to be there as their parents are away but with a home in the dark, with the sister missing.... What happened? Which are the mysteries? Are you ready for the scare of your life?  Well, it's just a point and click game, visiting rooms, finding the story of your sister, the music she likes, her rebellion against the society in the nineties, her friends, her hobby....  The graphics are correct but the ambiance... I was really on my toes and watching my back, expecting a paranormal entity to get me.... until the end.  *cough* Well, I managed to scare myself for nothing anyway *cough*  The soundtrack is pretty good too. And discovering the struggling of the young woman is interesting. Because her story is still lived by millions. And that's interesting.  I think I wouldn't have enjoyed Gone Home so much if I hadn't set in my mind that something will appear out of the blue and scares me. But in your house, with nobody, with locked rooms, in the dark, what do you expect? Horrible things.  True, the game is overpriced: 20$ is perhaps a little much. So wait until there is a good deal, like today (-88%).

I lie not, there's multiple factors that influenced me to like this game. I bought it when it is on sale, so around 4$ for a 2-hour adventure; I naturally am drawn to story-heavy games, so this game's genre just fits my preference; I often relate this game to Life is Strange, which is a fantastic game influenced by Gone Home itself. So I admit that I am quite biased in my opinion.  But here's the biggest bang for the buck, in my opinion: the context. If one can relate what's happening in the story(  immigration, adolescent problems, homosexuality  ) to the society in the 1990s, one can easily see the struggles of the characters.  So in the end, I think to enjoy this game, you need to have a peculiar taste to storytelling, and a little empathy. But of course, by the time you read this, this game is gonna be back to 20$; at this point, I would recommend to just watch some let's play on youtube.

Less of a game than an experience. If you know what to expect (ie. that it is atmospheric but NOT horror, and that it's a slow, emotional story with queer/feminist themes) and that interests you, then you will enjoy this game. Otherwise... well, I don't even know why you bothered buying the game..? Next time, do your research.

Gone Home felt pretty much like reading a touching little short story but the way it was told could only be done in a game. It's not a suspense or a horror game and doesn't fall into the usual genre fare gaming usually stays in. I could definitely relate to the 1990s nostalgia which helped sell the setting, and I'll recommend it heartily to older gamers such as myself. Don't go looking for twists or mysteries but expect quality writing and great voice acting.
This Game Strives to Answer the Question: Who Killed John Fitzgerald Kennedy?  It does not, however, answer that question.  Tis a Shame.

This is not super video game-y and that may be a plus or not to you! It's more like an interactive story with some puzzles, but I liked it and I think it's good there are games like this out there. well cya
I really liked this title, it's very interesting with a deep storyline. I must give you a heads up though it is a very short game!

I don't think I've ever cried at the end of a game before... <3 Everything from the slightly offputting atmosphere to the soundtrack to a jump scare that I actually thought made sense for once, and of course the story itself.   Oh, that and the fact that it makes obnoxious basement dwellers upset because 'how dare teh wimminz have a game they like go back to the kitching lololol'. This game right here? This is the games industry moving forward and leaving your pathetic antisocial ♥♥♥ behind. Full recommendation.

This game was excellent. Although a bit short for the price(I recommend waiting for a sale to pick it up like I did). But that's not why you're reading this.   The storyline is incredible. You're Katie. You come home from Europe to find an empty house and a letter pinned to the door from your sister saying 'Don't come find me'. This starts an immersive investigative journey through the house. It takes place in the 90s, so the VHS tapes and cassettes are there!. A lot of throwbacks to those days as well, so I would recommend being old enough to 'get' that time. The main story focuses on your sister Sam and her whereabouts. Although side-stories and plotlines involving your mother and father run concurrent to the main story as well. There are no objectives or waypoints. Progression in the game relies on human curiousity. I personally just went exploring in the house and the game subtlely guides you to the next location, you never quite feel guided but you are. Being thorough and anal in searching each rooms turns up interesting tid-bits on the occupants of the house, both past and present so search everything.   Atmospherically the game does well, it's taking place in the middle of a massive thunderstorm, so rain, thunder and lightning blanket the house, there are creaks and eerie sounds throughout, and some interesting moments with lights. Playing this at night, the atmosphere of uncertainty and the fear of basements comes into play(lights!).   All in all it was an exciting journey. I enjoyed it. It's not for people with low attention spans, and if you aren't enthralled by gameplay lacking action and gunplay, this isn't for you. But the story, and the very subtle ways you develop bonds with the characters you are trying to find makes for an emotional trip in trying to find them. You should all play this game at least once.
One of the few games to make me cry.
Great storyline. but wait for it to go on sale because it is really short. It took me 1.7 hours to complete it. also very very creepy
Yes, I reccomend this game. If you are reading this do yourself a solid, buy and play this game. You will not regret it. Make more games The Fullbright Company, please.
If you into creepy lesbian love stories - you probably wanna buy it!

A touching and emotional game where you have to explore the environment and find all the answers your questions. Piece together the mysteries from notes and other clues. Discover the story of the Greenbriar family. Dig deeper. Go home.

I have to say I enjoyed the game! The story is classic but believable, although I have to say, I would have preferred a longer game. I think the RRP price for this game is to high, considering the length of the game. To sum up, definitely worth buying if you have a spare couple of pounds.

Without question one of the most touching, industry-changing games of 2013. Gone Home is a lesson in storytelling influencing gameplay, not the other way around. The layers that this game contains are meaningful and human and more real than I could ever describe. If you like games, you should play this one. If you don't like games, I don't know why you're reading this Steam recommendation, but you should still experience what is being presented here.
Great game, love it. I recommend at least a second playthrough with the developer commentaries.  - Emil
Gone Home is the game I've been waiting for my entire life.

Wonderful story; this is NOT a game. It's an interactive story and an excellent one at that. The pacing is perfect and it has just enough tension to keep pushing you forward along the narrative. The choices in music (delivered by casette tapes found around the house) is really unique and made me nostalgic for bands like Bikini Kill and X-Ray Spex. I used to know kids like this when I was in high school, and it brought back a lot of happy memories.  Highly recommended at a sale price point. Not sure if it's worth the full price tag, but you pay almost as much to sit on your ♥♥♥ to watch a movie, right?
Amazing experience. Excellent writing and game design.

if you are a fan of throwing pens and books accross a empty home then this is the game for you. also it is one of the few games that lets you open a refrigirator AND a freezer! also there is a subplot about your sister and liking beavers, but the main focus of this game is how to properly invade a home and brown nose.

Gone Home is an interactive exploration game that is set in 1995. You play as a girl named Kaitlin 'Katie' Greenbriar, who has just returned home from a year-trip to Europe to find her family 'missing,' and your main objective is to figure out where they've gone. You play by walking around an enormous mansion examing objects by clicking on them, which I did really enjoy. As you click on objects, you'll begin to learn more about your family and where they are. The developers did a fantastic job of recreating a nostalgic 90s era house. There are many pop-culture references throughout the game, including the X-Flies, Super Nintendo, Street Fighter, Pulf Fiction, etc. The main focal point is on your sister, Sam, and as you advance through the house, you'll learn about her rebellious attitude and where she has gone. You learn of her and her lesbian lover/girlfriend, Lonnie. It's a decent story and I was actually really excited to see how things ended with them. I won't spoil it, but I was kind of disappointed in the ending and its abrupt finish.   Before giving my review of it, I want to say that this is not a game for everyone.  After playing through Gone Home, I can honestly say, I don't see what all the hype is about. Critics praise this game for it's story and many have even gone as far as giving it the title of 'Game of the Year.' Don't get me wrong, I did enjoy my playthrough of this game, but I don't believe it comes close to deserving that title. Many people complain about its length. It can be completed in roughly 2-3 hours, if you take your time and look at everything there is to see. I beat it in 1 hour and 10 minutes. I don't really have a problem with that, I did rush myself a bit. The game gives you a very eerie atmosphere. You learn of a story about your 'psycho' uncle and how his ghost is still living in the house. There's even a hidden room where Sam and Lonnie were performing a seance/exorcism. The entire time, I thought something was going to jump out at me at any moment. I was very wrong. Aside from random light flickers and lightning outside, there are no jump scares. There are no twists. I was a little disappointed by that, honestly. The house is pretty big and fun to explore. There's all kinds of secret passageways hidden behind bookcases/walls. You can definitely tell it's an indie game, just by the graphics. Not that I have a problem with that, I actually thought it looked quite nice. There's all sorts of objects to pick up and look at. One mechanic I really enjoyed was the ability to fully rotate each object to see it from every angle.  All-in-all, I did enjoy Gone Home, but I don't think it deserves all the praise it gets. It is a nice game to play and to enjoy an interesting story. Exploring the house itself and viewing all the objects was quite enjoyable. The narration is also done very well. One thing I don't really like about the game is the price tag; $20. It is nowhere near worth that. Thankfully, I was able to play it through Steam Family Sharing, so I didn't have to pay a dime. If you like interactive exlporation games such as Dear Esther or Dream, then this game is for you. If you go in expecting this to be something like Bioshock Infinite, then you're going to be hugely disappointed. It was on sale for about $3 earlier this week. If it goes on sale again, I would recommend picking it up and giving it a chance.  7/10
Brief, sometimes tense, touching, a lovingly told coming-of-age story full of detail and the real world.

Atmospheric exploration games aren't everyone's cup of tea, even so I recommend giving this one a shot. The awesome house alone made this one fun to explore. Plus it's set in the 90's, which gave me nostalgic childhood feels.  And I want that house!!!!!

This isn't a game for everyone, that's for sure. Some will find the gameplay as appealing as a root canal. But for gamers with open minds that are willing to play a game that does something different in an industry that has arguably been making the same games for the past 10 years, you will more than enjoy the breif but engaging game that is Gone Home.

Let me start by saying it's not for everyone. If you're looking for an intimate story, this is a definite must-play. If you enjoyed The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us, I highly recommend it. If those sorts of games aren't for you, skip Gone Home.

Gone Home is what one would call an 'Interactive Story' more so than a game. Gone Home is about a girl by the name of Kaitlin Greenbriar as she arrives home from a trip in Amsterdam only to arrive home and find the house completely empty. It's up to you to find out why.   There isn't much to the gameplay per se, this, like Dear Esther, is a game you 'experience' rather than play. You go around the house picking up on clues (much like an adventure game) to progress on the story. These 'clues' are in the form of journals that you encounter through the game that explains the overall story through the eyes of Kaitlin's sister, Samantha. You do, however, have to pay close attention the cues all around the house to find out what was going on with the entire family as well in addition to Sam's story.   The game has a multitude of items that you can pick up and even view up close. The devs for the game went all out on the graphics, a lot of the items you can pick up have very minute details to them which I really enjoyed seeing as well as them looking really authentic - from books you can pick up, to memos, to notices, etc, it's all presented in fine detail bar a few minor inconsistencies here and there with some texture work, but nothing that really detracts from the authenticity of the house. At the beginning, when there's nothing lit up, you have the option of turning on all the lights on every room to track the progress you've made within the house, as well as pick up cassettes and leave em playing music while you go explore or sit and listen to them, it's also very truthful to the times it takes place in aswell, giving nods to old idols like Kurt Cobain and even games like Street Fighter 2 (This includes Mock up SNES cartridges found in the game). I was impressed how much attention to detail the devs paid to the game.   The story itself is a very sad and dreary one that deserves to be experienced atleast once. It's about very realistic issues that take place in real life and are seen pretty commonplace and it's very sad to come home from a trip to what you find out in this game.    Now the game itself, admitedly, is hard to recommend due to the fact that, yes it is, at max a 3 hour game that's honestly not worth a second playthru unless you're looking to see how authentic an experience it really is and to find every speck of detail the developers poured their heart and soul into, very much like Dear Esther. It's not a game in the traditional sense because there's no real way you can fail, and the game itself is fairly linear (you find this to do this to find this and do that, etc) it's an experience. One that I personally am willing to recommend if you enjoy games like Dear Esther, Journey, The Stanley Parable and so forth.
10/10 GOTY would check privilege again.
A short, beautiful, and immersive story.

My favorite part of this game is the environment. The house is beautiful, filled with nostalgia from ths 90s. Exploring is a delight rather than feeling it's a task. The game is narrated very well through journals that you'll find. However, the plot isn't really that compelling as I prefer it would be. While playing the game, I was hoping something dark would happen. Nonetheless, I'm still impressed by the attention to details this game has. From simple things like posters to huge pieces like furnitures and appliances.

I liked it. Very heartfelt and has a purpose in its exposition. The story is simple but profound and well-acted by the voice actors. The house you explore is finely detailed and feels realistically populated with furniture and possessions.  That said, it's quite short and maybe not outstanding enough to warrant such a price. I think it would be more appropriate to sell this game under $10.

Gone Home is beautiful. The less you know about it before playing it, the better your experience is going to be, and while I think it has one glaring flaw (the way the rooms are laid out in the house is nonsensical and drew me out of the experience a little, it's so obviously a level made to funnel you through things in the right order, no one would lay a real house out like that) the overall experience is perfect. Gone Home is one of the best displays we've seen of what games have the potential to be, not pretty visual effects but poignant stories as they could only be told through this medium. Not to be missed, though I'd recommend grabbing it on sale. Even for all my praise, $20 is overpricing for a game that lasts about three hours.

Combat? No. Puzzles? No. Intrigue? Yes. Interesting characters? Yes. Great story? Technically, yes.  Gone Home puts you in the shoes of Katie Greenbriar, who has at the beginning of the game freshly arrived home from a long trip across Europe. She finds her family's home empty, inhabited only by the shadows cast by furniture as well as fleeting shadows of the family whose lives have changed greatly since she last saw them. From the moment you, as Katie, step through the front door, the time spent inside the Greenbriar's home is dedicated to learning about your family, usually via picking up various little objects and observing the myriad notes and paper scraps littered about. You learn a lot about the people who live in this house just by observing the things they own, the things they created, and the things that are attached between and among each of them. Gone Home is part adventure title, part visual novel, and probably the purest method by which a video game can achieve in relaying a story to the player, without the need for traditional cutscenes or dialogue. Also very unorthodox is the story this game tells, which attempts to explore certain aspects of the human experience during significant stages of life, represented by each member of the Greenbriar family.  Gone Home is a true gem among video game stories, and it's sort of an odd ball, at least in regards to the means by which it tries to tell its story.   In regards to gameplay, it all unfolds in a fairly pedestrian pace. You look at stuff, you listen to stuff, you understand stuff. That's all there really is in terms of mechanics. In this sense, Gone Home has less going on than you average point n click adventure title, fps exploration game, or weird non-genre stuff like Ico.  It's short as well, at about 2-3 hours long. Pretty much the length of a feature film.   Don't come for the gameplay, come home for the ambiance and story. Well worth it.

This is an interesting game. If you play this game with the expectations of it being 'thrilling' you'll be disapointed. 'Gone Home' offers something a little different; a piece of the 90s, punk music, and a beautiful message. Instead of seeing this as your mainstream type of game it would be best to think of it as an experience. This type of game will not be everyone's cup of tea.
This is a walking simulator, you have to read journals and documants to unfold the rich story line in this game and it has an excellent ending to this game.

I originally bought this game on launch but I must have sent the Steam key to a friend as I only had the direct download to play, so I recently bought it again...and I have to say, I'd buy it AGAIN because of how much I enjoyed it.   Now, there are no laughs to be had, really, and there's no edge-of-your-seat excitement either, but what I did find is a story with a just-one-more-room grip on me, to the point where I actually fell asleep at 3am playing it because I couldn't tear myself away.  The 3 ring binders, tissue boxes, highlighters and pens got a bit much until I stopped picking up every single thing, but Christmas Duck was fun until he turned out to be a murderer and leaving the skull by the final journal entry just seemed right.   This game, from the outset, really did make me feel like I WAS the protagonist and had come home.  20/10 would duck again

This is one of those games that lots of people would like to deny inclusion into the “game” medium. Well I have a very liberal definition of game, so it gets a pass in my book. “Gone Home” is an interactive storytelling experience. It’s more interactive than “Dear Esther” but considerably less interactive than “Pac-man”. Chances are you already know if you’re into that kind of thing, and if you are it would be best that you not investigate this game before playing it. Best played in one sitting in a dark room late at night. About 2 hours.

Recommended with reservations.  Gone Home is a very competent walking sim with a good, original story. They go down a narrative path that very few games have, and do so fairly well. The problem is that they're asking $20 for this hour-long game with no replay value, and they're also kinda putting up the facade of a horror game, which Gone Home absolutely is not. I enjoyed my playthrough, but I did so after paying $3 for it and without the expectations of the haunted house motif the developers seemed to be projecting.  If you can catch it on a Steam sale sub-$10 and enjoy this genre of games, I'd say go for it.

An excellent 90's themed game with a story told through slow, controlled exploration. It may be criticized for it's lack of 'gameplay' (whatever that means), but it's another one of those games that sacrifices traditional puzzle gameplay for something much more organic and straight-forward, similiar to The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, and to a lesser extent, Dear Esther (Dear Esther however does not have much interactivity at all). It simply uses a bit of interactivity to tell a story without unnecessary filler content.   I think what's important to consider before playing this game is that: You have to play it in one sitting, and you have to pay attention to everything you encounter and read in order to reconstruct the narrative space, to understand the characters, their background and interests, to nourish empathy with these characters.   It's not exactly a game for gamers. It's something that you have to make an effort to play (granted, not much effort at all), it's not a game that will entertain you after work. It's a game that contains a heartwarming message with many underlying themes. A tad of social criticism here, a tad of 90s nostalgia there. It's something that you should play when you have nothing else to do, and are feeling particularly adventurous,   There really isn't much to say about the game, objectively. I can tell you that the graphics are just completely utilitarian, it has everything it needs to have and has a great 90's atmosphere that is likely to resonate well with anyone who grew up in the US in the 90s or even early 00's. And the game is just about 2 hours long. Which is ok, considering the price.   Definitely recommend it for anyone who is patient and remotely open minded.
A fun and interesting exploration story. I'm obviously too used to first person shooters, as I kept expecting something to pop out at me all the time. I enjoyed searching the house for clues.

I may not have much play time, but I wanted to beat the game first for a view of it, I plan to go through and read the rest later.  This game is easily one of the best games I have EVER played. With plot twists, amazing voice narration, and pathing that your allowed to and Supposed to stray off of, it's a game that with an overview has an hour of gameplay, but if your willing to delve deeper and really learn the storie/s and take the time to read the articles etc. You will see that this game is fantastic, you literally Unlock the story by your actions, and how much you are willing to do. This game may not have explosions but it kept me and the people I was streaming it to occupied for an hour or so, once I finished the game I quickly realized that there was so much that I hadn't seen yet, with the Uncle's and the Father's story, the narrated story of the sister is just the dust on the ground, that's the story that many will be satisfied with. But there is SO much more than just that to this game's story. Don't get me wrong, I loved the girl's story as much as the other's, but learning how it fits in to the rest of the story makes it all mean so much more. I 100% recommend this game, especially with how cheap it is. For sure worth a try if your sketchy on it now, but if you want to play it I highly recommend not watching or reading anything about the story as that will most likely ruin it for you.

A lot of the user reviews bash two things about this game: the story and it's pricetag. While I would agree that $20 is way too much for only about 2 hours of gameplay, I have to very strongly disagree about the story. The story is AMAZING. You play as a girl who has come home after backpacking in Europe to find her house empty, and notes and clues scattered about explaining where your sister has disappeared to. People seem to be in a huff because they were expecting some creepy horror game or something, which is not what this game is meant to be at all. It's a point and click story-heavy game about your sister and her girlfriend. The story was extremely interesting to me and it's one that you rarely hear discussed in video games, which was part of why I loved it (not to mention the awesome 90's riot grrl and pop culture references). My best advice is don't go into this game thinking it's going to be scary or that there's more to the gameplay than just picking things up and reading and looking at stuff. Expect a good, interesting story and leave it at that and you'll walk away satisfied.  Especially now with the summer sale going on and this game being up on flash sale pretty frequently, I strongly suggest buying it. But again, the game only lasts about 2 hours on your first run through, so I probably wouldn't suggest paying the full pricetag.
ur family not very welcoming in this gam about coming home
This game may not seem like much on the surface, but the touching story you uncover makes it worth it.
It's impressive how much story this game tells without you ever meeting another character.
This is a game based on if Ellen Page was a snotty white girl. Still lesbian though.

I enjoyed it a lot. This game is what it is, slow of pace, heavily influenced by the Riot Grrrl movement of the 90's, it tells a good story. Recommended for open-minded people, particularly those who are somewhat nostalgic about the early 90's. I had already read spoilers, and still liked how the game unfolded, will play again

A few months ago i played Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes. Now, the game was great, albeit not very long, but the thing i want to emphasize on are the Paz tapes (supposedly from Peace Walker).          YouTube™ Video:  Metal Gear Solid 5 Ground Zeroes MGSV - Cassette Tape (Paz's Diary - All Entries) HD 1080p

Gone Home is an excellent example of storytelling through gaming. On the surface, it is an adventure game with very light puzzles that are easy to solve. But in actuality the game is merely a device to tell a very touching story. As the story is pretty much the main reason you would play this game, I will refrain from giving any spoilers, or even describe it in detail. Just know that you will not regret playing this game. The only downside is its steep price. While being an excellent game with a great story, it is only 3 hours long - tops. Definitely not worth 20 dollars. If this game was priced at 5 dollars base price, it would be golden. To conclude, I would highly recommend playing this game, but only if you can get it for 5 dollars or less through a sale.
This game isn't about scares, or mystery. Its a touching masterpiece.
Walk around an empty house at night during a rainstorm picking up random objects which activate segments on an audio journal.   10/10 Would totally play again.

This game is the single best game I have ever played. The story is the most profound thing ever. After playing this I have tears in my eyes. I recommend anyone who likes a great story to play this game.

I was not sure exactly what this game was going for, but by the end I was immersed in the family of Gone Home. Picking up pieces of who someone is by objects in their home is wonderful concept I wish I could do everyday. I was surprised by what the story revealed, but I must say ~emotinally it was quite beautiful.

First off, this game will only take you around two hours to complete, and there isn't much reason to touch it again, so keep that in mind. I wouldn't buy it for more than $10. Second, this is one of those love it or hate it affairs. I couldn't tell you which, since I hated Dear Esther, which is a similar title, but really enjoyed this game.  Now, without spoiling anything, I will say that this game (some might argue it isn't one, but I won't get into that) offers a very interesting experience that you won't find through any other medium. You experience a story told through notes and audio scattered around, and it is up to you to piece things together. There are several side plots that are more nuanced than the main plot, and I would advise you to really take your time while exploring to make sure you don't miss anything. Some of the story is told through the scenes in various rooms of the house, things that are linked to the notes you find, but might miss if you aren't paying attention. All in all, a great experience in my opinion.
THE FEELS! This game gets real but it is fantastic and if you like narritive this is like the perfect game for you.
Good atmospheric game, with a story that unfolds as you go along.
This is a wonderful game, and it made me cry, honestly. Wonderfully written and i look forward to other games from this publisher.
she was a lesbian THE WHOLE TIME

Fun, immersive experience, but too short. The game took me less than 2 hours to complete. Although, during the 90 minutes, I couldnt put it down or stop playing. I got it during the steam winter sale and don't regret it, but I wouldn't pay 20 dollars for it. It's a video game that plays like a book, and tells a story every step of the way.

Absolutely charming, lovely game. With so much attention to detail, fantaastic map creations and superb voice acting, THis game will more than definetly make you fall in love with it. For the first 2 hours that is. Then the game is over. It's a shame that the game is so expensive for only 2 hours of gameplay. Probably wait for the game to go on a sale before trying to purchase but when you have done that you will not regret it.

Revised and full review.  Mentioned several times during 2013’s Game of the Year award, this indie-title tries a different approach to storytelling than most games.  In Gone Home, you play a family member that enters the home returning from a longer trip. Things have happened while you were gone. You discover what exactly by exploring the house and picking up various items that are scattered in the rooms. Every time you do, you learn something about your family or yourself, like puzzle pieces slowly coming together.  Wandering through the house worked extremely well for me as my curiosity took over. It feels almost like reading a forbidden diary. That being said, this game does not feature a lot of other typical game mechanics: There are no puzzles, no challenges - except searching and picking up stuff - that is practically the only game mechanic. Gone Home’s main focus clearly lies on telling the player a story and using the game environment as a tool to do so - and that works excellent. It is an example that interactive media can offer mature and sensitive entertainment and does not have to feature traditional game mechanics to be an immersive experience.  But with the games nature come a few things to take into consideration: I found that I best enjoyed and comprehended the story while finishing the game in one sitting, basically instead of watching a movie.  This also tells you that the game is not very long: As there is hardly any challenge you can basically walk through the game, and once you know the story, thats it. As the asking price for the game is around 20,- US$, you feel like you don’t get your moneys worth. If it would cost as much as a movie ticket, it would be fairer in my opinion, as it offers around the same value of entertainment. The overall length, the overall theme and the lack of typical challenge based mechanics also means that Gone Home is a very approachable game for people who usually don’t play games or don’t see their appeal. Taking this into account Gone Home offers an excellent stepping stone into interactive entertainment for people who never thought games could be interesting to them.

A short game but a great experience. Hoping for more games like this.

Gone Home is like seing one of Shakespeare's less-than stellar plays, or the number zero. It's by no means bad, but everything that makes it still relevant is signifcantly less impressive than it was when it was new. Whereas Shakespeare invented new words which we still use, however, Gone Home really pioneered the idea of 'video-game storytelling through use of common life elements'. It's a well-written and generally good story, especially for games of the time, but nowadays it's nothing special. Play this game more as a heritage than a new experience, since as far as 'walking simulators' go, this one is not particularly amazing. 'The Beginner's Guide' is a much better example, in my opinion.  If you're a fan of story-based games with minimal gameplay, this one'll be a treat for sure, but there are definitely beter options nowadays.  One last thing about the story, though. I have a rule where 'If a movie, book, game, etc. tells about something which I could experience myself, I won't support it' and Gone Home only barely clears the threshold. Without wishing to spoil, about two thirds of the M.I.A. characters have some incredibly lame payoff as to where they've gone.
Didn't finish this but the game was alright, I love playing games like this and dear esther when I'm stressed but they arent for everyone. Not worth $20 tho.

To begin this short charade of a review on Fullbright's 'Gone Home,' I mean to state that it will not be long, as the game took me roughly one sitting to complete. I reccomend this game, I merely think that the 7$ I shelled out for it is not worth it. You can basically get the exact same experience by watching a Let's Play, save for the puzzles. Its love story was touching, truly, and I really enjoyed it. I have yet to see another game progress with such a pathos. 9/10- torrent it if you want to try, but please support Fullbright. I believe a sequel to this emotional masterpiece is in perfect order.
This is a very good and very unique game, it is by far my favorite narrative driven story, I am probably going to buy a copy for my friend.
A short and sweet game that has quite the emotional impact. Highly recommended.

This game is a masterpiece. Anyone who scoffs at the notion that video games can be art is yet to play a title like Gone Home. Very few games have been able to affect me on such an emotional level as this. Though not a very long or especially replayable game, playing Gone Home is an experience that I will take away with me for a very long time.

Well this game is more creepy than it seems to be. I don't think its a good thing when you feel like your going to see Slender Man every single time you turn around! In all the story line is very loving and touching but running around a dark house without a goal is not my defenition of a game, once you beat it you can beat in like 5 seconds.
This game may not seem like much on the surface, but the touching story you uncover makes it worth it.

While I do reccomend this game, you need to get it on sale, because it is very short. It has a nice story, well I use the term story loosely. I may have missed a few things, that are important, and there is a lot of boring notes too, I can't say it's perfect but if you can get it really cheap ($3 or less) and feel like spending an interesting hour. Then get Gone Home.

'Gone Home' is a short but emotionally rewarding story where you play as the older sister that been abroad for some time and gets home to the new house that her family been moving to while she was gone. There isnt much to really say about the game without spoiling it, but its a pretty basic (and straightforward) story where you wander around in the new house trying to catch up whats been happening while you were gone. Small bits of information that perhaps the family members dont really want to talk about. Its a short game i clocked it at 1h 30mins and from my standpoint there is no replayability unless you want to just go through the story again, check if you missed some small bits of information that you missed the first time around.

Unlike many games these days, this title differs greatly in the fact that is is more like a user controlled film or short story. A tale that (in my humble opinion) is on the scale of the film 'American Beauty'. Something strange is occuring in the suburbs in this rural town, Something strange, yet intimat, and beautiful. This game is not very long, yet it tells a unique story. The game builds upon a setting and a set or circumstances that connect you to a cast of characters which you may only catch a glimpse of, yet you feel attached to them all somehow. Harnessing the creativity of the writers, this game has the power to envoke emotions which may be entirely familiar and nostalgic to you, or perhaps those which you may have never known. This is a tale of exploration and wonder. With my hair standing on end, I entered the next room to learn of its curiosity. Most of all this is a tale of love. A special kind of love that doesn't come around too often. It is innocent, yet dark and exciting. Special indeed. This game was a real treat to play. The story is not long, and may leave you wondering about a few details, however you will come away filled with a new feeling, which is very rich and satifying. I suggest this game for the ones who seek a change of pace and desire a new adventure.
Didn't finish this but the game was alright, I love playing games like this and dear esther when I'm stressed but they arent for everyone. Not worth $20 tho.

Gone Home is a beautifully-crafted story that slowly unfolds as you explore this empty house. The voice acting work is superb, and the details you can discover can really start to make you feel like this is your family, and they're gone. What happened?  The gameplay may be limited to exploration, but I think it serves as a gentle reminder that we are not always the protagonists, even in our own lives. We have to stop and piece together other people's stories, too. This story is a very strong and moving one. Highly recommended, especially on sale.

10/10 Would feel feels again. Actual Score: 7.5/10  Picked this up on sale and did a bit of research by watching some walkthroughs to see how to play it and the best way to do so is to look at every item you can pick up and piece the side story from there. While it's game mechanic is not conventional it still has a distanct objective, interactivity and end state that is relaxing to play. Great main story and interesting side arcs which work well with the sound design and art style to make the game dripping with atmosphere and bring on the feels hard at moments.   My gripes with this game are that I feel it is a little too pricy for the gametime but as I got it on sale i'll overlook this a bit and the main lead can come off as a bit superficial but otherwise a great way to tell a story of a 90's family through exploration.   Aside from that pick this game up on sale if you're curious about exploration type games but on a small, intimate scale or if you like that already buy when full price.

The production values are incredible and the method of storytelling works great for the first 40 minutes of the game, then gets a little tedious near the end which involves a lot of back tracking. I recommend this game assuming you get it on sale for at least 66% off, otherwise the high price will likely leave a bad taste in your mouth. This isn't among the best interactive fiction I've played but it's worth a shot.  Oh, and I'm not a fan of the soundtrack being a separate purchase. The music files are already in the product people purchased, they shouldn't need a separate purchase to listen to them conveniently.

An enjoyable and refreshing experience for a video game. I found the narrative was incredibly rich and well executed and atmosphere was pitch perfect. I found the game also resonated with myself as someone who grew up in the nineties and felt like an outsider. This may not translate especially well to those who didn't live through a pre-internet school experience, but it's difficult to say.   Give it a go, if you don't really enjoy it it's not really very long so it won't feel like you have wasted a huge chunk of time (unlike say, watching Pearl Harbour).

Bravo. There's not much to say about this game without spoiling it entirely. It's a great psychological thriller / detective-esque / social commentary game. It's a fun love letter to us 90's kids. Most of all, it's an AMAZING game for it's storytelling. From the moment you walk in to the empty house, you really will be taken for a ride up until the end. A very important game for the industry.

Finished it after 2 hours and I have to admit that it is an interesting interactive narration. A bit short for the steep price of 17 €, but very strong in making you feel uncomfortable. However, it did not make me feel uncomfortable in the role of someone coming home, but instead of a complete stranger who digs through the personal history of the entire place. To be frank, as with Dear Esther, I have a really hard time to even classify this remotely as a game. It essentially boils down to a fairly mindless 'walk forward and be bombarded by exposition' experience. While the presented story is captivating, I would have like to see this realized in a way that involves the player more and presents some actual challenges. For what it is, I wouldn't recommend it to a friend at the current price for the scale of content that is offered, even if it hurts me to say that, while having to recognize the excellence of the parts that Fullbright got right.

I enjoyed Gone Home. Liking Gone Home naturally makes me the cancer of video games, a hipster and most notable of all; a ♥♥♥♥♥♥.  This awful 'game' features a 'narrative' which some people dare to claim is interesting and believable in a world filled with over the top power fantasies or insultingly simple stories bolted onto games as an afterthought and not as core part of a game. The games developers even have the cheek of not attending certain trade shows because of their personal beliefs. Can you imagine that? People making actions based on their feelings towards something! Ridiculous!  Gone Home is the cancer of video gaming that threatens to bring narrative to the forefront of an interactive experience whilst also keeping it grounded in reality. You should stop reading this right now, go hassle the developers on twitter and call me a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ lessen anybody reading this actually thinks about buying the game, GOD FORBID.

This is a game for people who like going around exploring, taking their time, looking into every closet, drawer and box to see if there's something there to add to the story. It's not for everybody, but I liked Dear Esther and Serena, so this was my kind of game. I liked the story, but the ending falls a bit flat. Also, there were parts in the story that could have been expanded.  I got the game from a sale and I recommend you do the same. The full price is too much considering the length of the game.

I stayed away from all spoilers before playing and this game was pretty interesting. It definitely set in a really creepy guide and many times I was expecting a ghost or something to pop out. As the story progressed, I started to get an idea of what was going on and also expected something horrible to be revealed. The build up was great and the ending was totally satisfying. Definitely gives you something to think about.

Highly unique and well handled subject matter and decent atmosphere/pacing/exploration but I wasn't blown away by it like some. I'd recommend it if it's your kind of game but you should get it on sale.

Gone Home was the first new game i've played in years. It was simple, and barebones and thats why it worked. In terms of game as interactive narrative, it may be a somewhat passive interaction (just reading stuff) but it works. it took a basic and much maligned convention of exploration in games and gave it heart. its not a 'game' in the traditional based-on-boardgames-or-sports sense, but instead it gets closer to what you can do with video games when we stop thinking about them as (gonna be pretentious here) 'games'. is it perfect? probably not, but that doesnt matter. will i play it again? i dunno, probably once or twice. but its definitely a game that sticks with you.
This game is such a ♥♥♥♥ing good experiance to go through with an amazing story. i think this would be a brilliant purchase and is well worth the time spent

If you like short games and mess arround with all the things you see, you definitly should play this game.  The environment is absolutely amazing, and if you are from 80's/90's, you will find very awesome references.   About the history of the game's itself, it's quite interesting, could be better but in the matter of facts it's good, since you start the game you will find a lot of documents that are going to tell you the story, at the begging is not very clear, but as you start advancing in the game you will understand.  In general, 7/10

A lot of people don't get the game. That's because you have to be very open-minded to play it. First of all, you have to see that as an experience, not a game. You cannot expect a big story and lots of scare, because that's not the focus. If you enter the heavy atmosphere you can really feel its objective. Just put yourself in it, without any distractions around. Play it like it's you in that situation. Then you're going to see that this game is unique because, different from other games, it's so close to our reality that it can immerse you and go deeper and deeper inside your feelings. Simply fantastic. 10/10
An absolutely wonderful game. You won't go wrong picking this up, it's easily one of the best games to come out this year.
A narrative experience a bit like Dear Esther. Looks like a suspense horror game but it hides a surprising and sweet love story. Loved it.  4/5
the best three minutes of gameplay ever

Score: 8/10  'Gone Home' was a game I'd been interested in for some time, mainly due to the main character being a female. Little did I know how far that would expand once I'd begun playing the game, but to avoid any spoilers I'll leave it at that.   One thing to note is that the game is very, very short -- only a few hours at most and that's if you scour everything like I did. However, I prefer the feeling of wanting more than finding myself wondering when it's going to end.  -Gameplay- I enjoyed the remarkably simple and straightforward gameplay and controls. I feel as if this game was made just for me, since I'm one of those who have to explore every nook and cranny before I consider a room complete and can move onto the next one. There were a few moments where the atmosphere of the game almost transgressed to 'horror', but it was mostly due to my own over-reactive imagination and the game's superb story-telling. This is definitely a puzzle/hide-and-seek game, as there's no action whatsoever beyond you forcefully tossing objects around.  -Music- I feel like this game was a love letter in many different ways; music being only one of them. Although definitely not the music I normally find myself listening to (very punk), the soft and melodic sound playing under Sam's letters to me definitely hiked up the emotional reaction. There were also multiple music players around the house with plenty of casettes and a record to pop in and listen to. Since I was still under the impression that some crazy ♥♥♥♥ was going to pop out and kill me, I only listened to a few of them for about 30 seconds apiece before turning it off and continuing.  -Story- The story is where this game really shines through. It touches on subjects I've never encountered in a video game, and delivers them through multiple 'artifacts' in believable and easy-to-digest methods. Although I do question why some particular letters seem very out in the open, I found that when I triggered an event that prompted the vocal recording of Sam, I almost completely stopped what I was doing in the game to listen. The voice acting is superb! I also found that a lot of the school notes passed between Sam and her classmate feel as if they've actually been written by high-schoolers. I really enjoyed reading them, as they gave me a small sense of nostalgia as I recalled the notes I used to write with my friends and the weird, dumb stuff we used to talk about.

What can be said about Gone Home without giving too much away?  Basically, it's a first-person adventure ('adventure' in the terms of old point-n-click games like King's Quest or Monkey Island) that for all intents and purposes feels closer tonally and gameplay-wise to modern horror faire like Penumbra or Amnesia than anything else I can think of. You're set to explore all the nooks and crannies of your family's rather large new home, after coming back from an extensive stay abroad, in the middle of the night and when no one else is home. That's the whole premise.  It may seem like a fairly drab and uninteresting concept of a game but from the moment you begin you're enveloped in a thick robe of atmosphere, and the less I describe things beyond that, the better. To put it one way, you're going to feel a surprising range of things that will become swayed in ways you wouldn't initially expect as you explore more and more of this house and learn more about your family than most young adults may find comfortable. But it's okay, because it's a fictional character's family, not yours! ...plus, it's interesting in a way most game's narratives fail to capture -- in fact, most media I've explerienced has failed to capture -- as you get to know these characters, their stories, their personalities, their trials and their secrets through simply poking around their house. The experience is unique and fresh, and this strong character writing plus the subtle yet powerful tonal shifts throughout the game make it feel quite unlike anything I've played before, or perhaps watched, or read. It's NEAT.  There are but two complaints I have for this gem of a game; first of all, and the most obvious one, is its rather short length, only a handful of hours even if you absolutely scour every square inch like I personally love to do, and maybe as short as a couple if you're just rushing through and going through the obvious stuff. The second would be something that's a bit difficult to describe, but basically it feels like, as many interesting things as there are to find and read and listen to, it feels like there could have been *more* -- I feel that there are many stretches of emptiness or rooms/closets/sections altogether that have only one real item of any interest, too many opportunities where extermely interesting little tidbits could have been hidden in especially hard-to-find places for the truly scrutinous.. it just seems, well, not quite 'barebones' by any means but a bit.. less-flowing a cornucopia of NEAT LITTLE THINGS as I feel it could *easily* have been for some of us. But at the same time, once you've finished this game, it may make sense, in some ways, that things weren't as.. saturated as they could have been? Either way, I feel it's a valid point to bring up, if only perhaps as a grasp to justify my own good two hours or so of wastefully exploring every teensy weensy corner, move around every single object in the 3D-held-item-view mode looking for clues that weren't there or looking down every single roll of toilet paper's hole in hopes of finding some kind of mystical bauble from some fantasy world as if I were playing a game that Gone Home, decidedly, is not.  What Gone Home is, however, is a wonderful experience that, despite its brevity, is absolutely worth your time. So, like, get it n' stuff.

I... wow. I just finished playing Gone Home just a little while ago, and I'm speechless and in tears. I won't give away spoilers, but the theme to this story is something very important to me and is something I've been looking for in a game for who knows how long. It may be a bit pricey for the length of the game, but for me it was absolutely worth it if only just to see something like this put out there. Gorgeous dialogue, moving story... all I can do is say 'thank you'.
Engaging, atmospheric, and just full of emotional weight. This game is a worthwhile experience.

It's an intimate story told in an intriguing way which will forever remain a memorable experience in your gaming life.   Many complain It is not a 'game' since there is basically no action, no puzzles, or even decision making, some say it hardly even qualifies as an 'interactive' story. But I would say, interactivity doesn't only come in the form of button pressing. How this game gets you to think, to expect, to corcern, and how it leads you from being a total stranger of the story, to having a feeling for the world in the game, that's what make this game a well-crafted story-telling expereince.  If you are interested, avoid spoilers the best you can, just take on the role of the protagonist, and let the story unfold in front of you.

A nice change of pace game, there is no killing, no ghosts, and not even a health bar. Every now and again we all get bored of our 'killing games' and this can scratch that itch. I mean it's still not for everyone, very slow paced and all fo the story comes through text and 'audio logs'. The story itself is very different from what we've come used to in games and in a way requires a bit of maturity when it's being approached. II dont think $20 is the right price for it, and Clocked in only 2 hours. DONT WATCH any previews or reviews, go straight in.
Amazing. Great atmosphere, excellent story.
This game has such a fantastic narrative. One of my favorite games of 2013. I'm so glad there is a thriving market for non-traditional games like Gone Home.

A narrative game. Beautiful, wonderful storytelling and a testament to the various ways this new medium we call gaming can open worlds through interaction. Clocking in at two hours exactly if, like me, you love picking up bottles and examining them to a ridiculous level; you can also probably clear it in about ninety minutes. The gaming press, politically driven, sadly overhyped this title but it does offer players the chance to experience something new and magical.

well done.  I really was going through some feelings like in a good movie or book while i was uncovering what happend. I really appreciate the 'game' but would recommend it only to those who enjoy reading a good book. But for those ... when there is that rainy evening and you are home alone, put off your phones, grab yourself a beer or tea and set sail for a 2-3 hours long 'comming of age - first love - weird halloween - mid-marriage-crisis' story

Most of the hype is right, it's got a ton of 90's nostalgia, very compelling exploration, and impeccable voice acting. However, even after reading countless reviews (without spoiling the story), I wasn't prepared for how SHORT the game is. Two hours, and I'm the type that likes to explore EVERYTHING. Top quality game, just know that you're paying $20 for 2-3 hours of gameplay.
absolutely beautiful. great story and atmosphere

This game is short but it has a good story. It has been designed to be very creepy in some parts and achieves a definite eerie atmosphere. The story is intriguing and relatable for girls, I think some of it actually came out of my childhood exactly! ^^  The game play is a bit like Dear Esther but a lot more interactive. The graphics are not really the point of the whole game, but sound is used very well to immerse the player. Gone Home is not really good value for money given how many hours you get out of it, but never the less worth consideration for a play through if it manages to hit you in that nostalgic spot.  It is rather immersive and the storyline is very absorbing. It wasn't really the genre expected but it was enjoyable ^^.

I didn't really know anything about this game when I bought it. To say that I was pleasantly surprised is an understatement. Don't purchase if you are looking for combat or intense scares. Do purchase if you appreciate story, fear of the unknown, or just want to try something different. Also, helpful if you were alive in the late eighties, early nineties because oh man. . the references!

I was aware that this would be a 3hr interactive story going into it, and I was definitely not disappointed. The atmosphere of this house was perfect and the story was rich and heart warming. Definitely worth the cheap price when most Hollywood blockbusters cost this much, or more, and don't even come close to the excellent story this game provided.

I spent the first hour expecting a jump scare, but what I found was something else entirely. I look for really awesome story-telling in games that allows the player to become attached to the characters - this game is a clear representation that we've come a long way in gaming from saving a princess from a barrel-chucking monkey (or two lines and a dot if you wanna go back that far). Gone Home tells an emotional story that many of us - regardless of sexuality - have experienced in high school and moving into a new neighborhood. Absolutely beautiful.

Wow!! What can I say about this game? I amazingly made it this long without the game being spoiled. I couldn't wait any longer and the game just happened to be the perfect price on the Steam Summer Sale. It took me about 3 hours to complete the game. I probably won't ever play the game again. The game is brilliantly written but the writing relies on the player not knowing what will happen next. I was filled with so much anticipation, curiosity, excitement, fear, and hope as I played. I don't think I would feel those emotions on a second playthrough as I now know the outcome of the game.  I don't know if the game is worth $20 (or even $10). But for the price I paid, it was a memorable gaming and life experience that I will cherish.
Just buy it. Just... buy it.
Not so much a game, as an interactive story, but amazing nonetheless.

I had heard all the hubbub over Gone Home -- lots of people talking about how it was a very different kind of game that they really enjoyed. When I first began the game, I was partly excited to try it out finally and worried that the massive amounts of hype would ruin my experience. Well, it lived up to my expectations. I'm not ashamed to say that I shed some tears during a few segments of the game. Sam is a very interesting character, as is Lonnie.   The game is a bit short, but it didn't overstay its welcome. As much as I would have loved to learn more about Oscar and Sam and Katie's parents (as what I did get to learn made me want to know more), I think it was right to have the content focus on Sam as Gone Home is very much her story.
Very interesting and fun game.

Loved the game, not the price. If you really want to sink $20 bucks into it for one of the best story-telling games I can recommend, and you actually trust me on this, then go ahead. It's really only worth it to some people, but it's on sale, then go for it!
Break out the Ouija board and contact Roger Ebert. Video games can be art.

In a nutshell, this game is basically lift up things to look at, pick up a few cassette tapes which contains music (relating to the story, as you will see once you play), pick up certain stuff which begins the voice actress to speak, like she is speaking from her diary, but with this beautiful backing music to make each find better than the last, as it continues to the story between these charachers, you also find hints around as to why the house is empy which i will not spoil. Anyway, this is a fantastic game, some may not like it, but if you love a really emotional story with a bit of a twist behind it. There is things some may find boring such as very little action, barely any except picking stuff up and listening. The game has a relaxing feel to it aswell from the stormy weather outside. There is not much to say except it is a very mellow game, and only people who can get attached to a story, and be ok with just walking around will enjoy this.

You are Katie, and you have just come home from a long trip to Europe. But the house is empty. Neither your parents nor your little sister is there. - What happened?  First, this is not a conventional game. Know that going in, or you might be surprised. I'd say that this is closer to a unique way of telling a short story. Your range of interaction is something like pushing buttons, opening doors, picking stuff up and then putting it down again - and that's about it. But that's not important, because as you walk through the house you are told the story in a very natural and quite subtle way. Not all is spelled out to you, but  you definitely have to have the patience to read a lot .  I initially had a hard time finding the different papers, journals, items and rooms interesting, but as my investigation continued, and my understanding of who these people were increased, the story managed to capture me.

I do not recommend this game for people, who care too much about the gameplay itself. This game isn't about action. This game isn't even a game. It is a unique experience, though. Which certainly deserves attention.  Every little detail in 'Gone Home' is made with love and charming wit. The whole atmosphere of this game is full of cosiness and some kind of nostalgic sweetness. Exploring, looking at personal things, reading letters and private notes... It makes you feel a bit like a spy (what a wonderful opportunity to satisfy your inner stalker!).  I absolutely adore Lonnie's drawings! As well as Terrance's incredibly cheesy books. But most of all i am impressed by the epical novel, dedicated to the mysteries of menstrual cycle.  The main storyline is very sweet. It also supports all the young lesbians, who share emotions of the main heroines... I'd better shut up and stop giving out spoilers. Check out 'Gone home', if you are kind and sentimental human being, who understands jokes and finds pleasure in reading sentences.

It amazes me how harsh people can be on a game simply for it's length. Even more bizare is how negative people can be on a story-based game simply for it's gameplay style. But the thing that bugs me the most is that for those simple and closed minded reasons, people can overlook something special and unique.  'Gone Home' is that kind of game. It's not a horror game. It's not an action game. It is nothing more than a story reveal overtime and your part is revealing that story. My favorite type of story seems to always deal with a mystery. The reveal piece by piece to the truth to that mystery is in itself hauting but also rewarding. And this game is just that. It's a well crafted mystery styel story play through interaction, well acted voice work, and if you are willing to pay attention, listen, and embrace the story, You will find yourself moved.

This game has a beautiful, heart-melting storyline. I actually almost cried during the last journal entry. At first, since everything was so quiet and no one is to be found, I thought that someone was going to jump out or scream, or that something else scary was going to happen. I was definitely wrong. I highly reccomend this game!
One of my favorite games from 2013! A must play.

Gone Home is not what you would call a game. It feels like the interactive movies from the 90ies, where you actually just move your character and everything else happens by itself. Here there are no movie bits, but a voice from the off that narrates the story as you find bits and pieces, letters, leaflets and other stuff around the house. The story itself is quite beautiful, you want to know what happened to Sam and Lonnie and you start to feel a lot of sympathy for Sam, who is rather misunderstood by her parents.  Would I recommend the 'game'? Yes, definitely - although have to say if I wouldn't have bought it in summer sale I'd feel I paid to much. The game is really short and has no replay value at all. Still - very nice two hours!

Game was visually beautiful and the story, while making the game seem so eerie and dark, was beatiful as well and amazing. SUch a cute love story amd a great thing to discover from the point of view of a sister. I hope their made up, video game relatiobship did well. :) Writing was amazing. looved it :3

I am not one to normally write reviews however I feel strongly about the experience this game does hold.   It is intriguing because after reading many of the reviews I agree that this does not have replay value and it does seem a little overpriced.  However with that said I completely agree with IGN. That if you take it as an experience it has great potential to trigger 'heartfelt human emotion'. I feel this game holds a powerful message as subtle as it may be. I took the whole experience as an understanding that while life can be a struggle we still hold choice and the end message conveyed was one of hope, knowing that Sam is exactly where she choose to be no matter what the concequence. In the end it left me with that same hope and understanding that I have the choice to be where I desire and need to be.

I am not one to normally write reviews however I feel strongly about the experience this game does hold.   It is intriguing because after reading many of the reviews I agree that this does not have replay value and it does seem a little overpriced.  However with that said I completely agree with IGN. That if you take it as an experience it has great potential to trigger 'heartfelt human emotion'. I feel this game holds a powerful message as subtle as it may be. I took the whole experience as an understanding that while life can be a struggle we still hold choice and the end message conveyed was one of hope, knowing that Sam is exactly where she choose to be no matter what the concequence. In the end it left me with that same hope and understanding that I have the choice to be where I desire and need to be.

If anyone hates on this game, then I'd assume they are the people that skip cutscenes and just want to shoot everything all the time. The story in this game is absolutely amazing, it is easily in my top 5.   You get this very eerie feeling as you walk through the house, and I often found myself doing double takes toward windows and lamps because I was genuinely on my toes at all times. I went into this game knowing nothing about it, and thought that the notes scattered about were nothing more than backstory. I slowly came to realize that they actually were the entire story. It is possible to finish the game without collecting all the notes, but it completely changes the meaning of the game, so keep that in mind.   Anyway, this game was f****** amazing, 10/10, if you don't like story then stay away.

I enjoyed playing this game. It almost felt like reading a book, but being able to discover things beyond the words and actually explore the world of the story. I found it interesting how it really did feel like an old house, and caused me to wonder early on if it was going to allow the monsters, my imagination created, to become real. Not the biggest fan of where the story went, but still a great job of telling the story.
Really good game. A+ 10/10. Would emotionally destroy myself with it again

Having bought the game while it was on sale, I found that the 2.1 hours I spent completing it was okay. I think it's worth playing through once, but don't see myself re-playing again it after that (that is, if you took your time to look at everything in the first play-through).

A 'rummage through someone's house' simulator. Ever want to dig through a stranger's drawers and discover their secrets? This game is for you!  Oddly enough, despite knowing this is in no way a 'scary' game, I did find myself a bit jumpy. Going around a corner, seeing a shadow, you convince yourself you've seen something. The atmosphere of the game is superb.   The story is wonderful and as such, I highly recommend the game as well.

Would recommend but only if you enjoy indie games and like the idea of exploration in an empty house! But on the whole I think the story and how it unfolds is really well done, I was invested in the characters

Touching interactive story, told in 3rd person through voiced journal entries and written notes (with minor problem solving). Can't say much more, because if would ruin the experience.
