Good idea that they set it 1995.  Clocks in at just about 2 hours if you read and listen to everything. Still, i would recommend it, especially on sale. Just don't expect a shooter!

One of the best games I've ever played. The story was done very very well, and as minimalist as the gameplay was I ended up playing it through twice and finding all of the secrets. It has a phenominal atmosphere and really captures the mid 90s. I love it so much and I want more

To open: This is not a $20 game. Do not get it for $20. You will be disappointed and I wouldn't even blame you.   That out of the way, this is story-driven exploration game with you coming home after a year away in Europe to your house being totally empty, and you simply explore it to find out why through collecting notes. Some give narration from your younger sister, a punky late-teen trying to find her place in a new school without her older sister.   This game is well made overall. The house is put together in a realistic way, the voice acting is genuinely without being cheesy, and the music is pretty good (if 90's grrrl punk is your thing). I think most people would agree on these point. The main issues of contention come from 2 things: price/time, and appeal.   Price per hour of gameplay is pretty poor, unforgivably so at full price. It takes 1.5-2 hours to play - wait for an appropriate sale for that playtime if you're interested. It'll allow for a much more genuine experience.   Appeal is more complicated. This game achieves a certain atmosphere that many simply cannot or do not wish to connect with, and that's fine.   Do you like the mid-90's? Do you like punk music? Do you like stories about high school girls learning about their values and what's important to them? Do you enjoy 'showing-not-telling' narrative style and piecing a story together yourself? Do you like teen romance? Do you like exploration games?  If you answered 'no' to many of the above, probably give this a pass. I enjoy this game, and I have a lot of affection for the story, but it isn't so good that it'll convert someone who dislikes the concepts it's built upon. That being said, for those who are exploration game fans with an interest in the mid 90's vibe and coming-of-age stories, pick this up if you see if for a good price. It's a neat story with straightforward gameplay.

Whilst people are obviously entitled to their opinions and call this game a walking simulator, I would have to firmly disagree with them on this one. Personally I really enjoyed the creepy house and the 90's settings, the way it set up a sense of foreboding that was perfectly apt in subverting expectations for the personal and moving story you eventually unravel.  My main criticism if I had to give one, would be that I wish there was more interactivity in the way you piece together the puzzle of what had happened and I appreciate that if the story didn't grab you then you may be disappointed. For me however I felt like a detective creeping around an old mansion, trying to solve the mystery of its past (much like Fox Mulder and Dana Scully, as referenced in the X-Files videos found in one of the rooms). I liked the way it didn't always give you all the information, for all the stories, but just enough to read between the lines and work out the truths for yourself.  I feel that whilst the game and its story might not be for everyone, it is certainly a refreshing look at gaming. It shows us the possibilities gaming has to expand the types of themes and ideas that it can offer insight and discussion on; the rational man with gun, things go boom approach (that we all still embrace and love) can only take us so far after all. Whilst I would not want every game to be like this, I feel that we can only gain by broadening the gaming medium to try different game play styles, embrace new (more complex) themes and appeal to new audiences, as only by doing this can our hobby develop a more nuanced world view that has legitimate things to say about the world we live in and the nature of the human condition and in doing so be considered art at more than a superficial level.
Wow. One of the most interesting, bittersweet, heart-tugging stories in any of the videogames I've ever played. If you enjoy story-based games, this is one of the better ones I've encountered.

You come home at 1:15 AM after a year away to a new family house you do not recognize. Of the three family members you expect to see, you find none. Doors are closed and lights are off. You begin your cautious search of this alien place. Among your first pieces of evidence are journal entries from your sister: apparently, your family has moved into this town's 'psycho house.' Your mind races to dark fantasies of poltergeists and serial killers. All of the clichés apply; it is a dark and stormy night.  Gone Home gives us constant hints that, at any time, it's going to lay it on thick. However, The Fullbright Company's inaugural game is more interested in dismantling and repurposing these horror tropes than reveling in them. We expect a 'video game,' broad and sensational; what we get is an emotional drama, affecting, sensitive, and satisfying – not to mention quietly ground-breaking for the medium of video games.  Nestled within a familiar framework of extreme fiction is an intimate story focused instead on the dramatic of the everyday. You are Kaitlin Greenbriar, coming home from a year abroad to a house you find unfamiliar. Your family isn't there. Gone Home will have you asking, in the most common yet resonant sense, if they are OK.  Gone Home pushes aside the exaggerated in favor of the real. It is not a game of thrills or reflexes, but that doesn't make it any less of an engrossing story experience. You will only experience as much as you find, but that is not to say that the story is hidden away – most of your family's things and thoughts are left in plain sight, though puzzle adventure game instincts will drive you to eventually leave no corner unexplored. However, as your thoroughness uncovers more guarded secrets and insecurities, you may come to feel that your roving eyes are piling on multiple counts of casual voyeurism. You may also feel ever more unable to rein in your curiosity. The various feelings you find laid bare in each successive tidbit, from humor to heartbreak, spur you on to find the next. The stories and characters are the driving force here, falling into place in a way that is nothing short of impressive. If you think of yourself as particularly empathetic, these emotional beats might make you feel as if you were discovering your own family.  Throughout the game, you are never sure if you'll see another person in this empty house, but you will discover a full sense of the characters nevertheless. They are presences absent and missing from the house: not just 'offscreen.' You'll find your father's discarded drafts and the regular distractions he used to dispel his writer's block. You'll find your mother's attempts at artistic appreciation and creation that took her mind off of what she sees as a happy marriage becoming less so. But most of all, you'll find your sister – every aspect of her – as growing up a teenager tends to leave behind many rambling thoughts. It is clear that she questions who she is and what she's doing with her life, but amid the uncertainty is the core of a wonderful little sister who has grown a lot in the year you were away. Her mixtapes of cathartic and immediate riot grrrl singles are my absolute favorite of the family's artifacts.  Human connection comes at a premium. The disconnected lives of our average, nuclear, suburban family have led to the conception of many modern horror stories and the clichés they represent. In a medium so commonly used as a delivery system for escapist fiction, it means very much that this small game has opted instead to tell us a down-to-earth story of love and its byproducts. Gone Home is about connection over separation, and the wonderful contradiction that is extraordinary love from ordinary circumstances. One can only hope that there will be more such stories to follow.
If you spent your junior high summer nights playing Rygar on the NES with girls sneaking into your room while The Cure 'Inbetween Days' blasted out of your cassette player. This is your game.

In a nutshell:  Gone Home is an ambitious indie title, most easily characterized by its use of interactive gameplay and immersive (if not predictable) environment.  A bit of forewarning: If you are not comfortable with, and/or you do not enjoy the idea of a story-driven walking simulator, this game is guaranteed to prompt a big ol' thumbs down 4 u. Most of this game is-- reduced to its core-- walking... and looking at stuff... and walking to another place... and looking at more stuff. Sometimes, when walking, you can click on the stuff and! things happen! but there are no strict 'game play elements' to speak of... if you're one of those people who hate contemporary art or music without words, you're in for a not-treat. Me, I like walkin and clickin, so I can't say that I personally discount the experience in that respect, but I know that many people will.  So, for S and G's, let's say you're cool with all that. Let us move right into the dichotomy between the marketing of this game, and what ACTUALLY transpires.  What I perceived based on blurb and a few short spoiler-less videos:  -spoopy scary??? -mysteries -must piece together clues to solve said mysteries - ?!  What I received based on 2 hours of slow-paced and after much observational gameplay: -creepy environment -familial problems -riot grrrls -must piece together clues to ascertain said familial problems -mysteries -no solving of said mysteries  I laud this game's effort in its ability to create an in-depth and captivating 90's nostalgic mood-- a success owed to the music, scenery and repeated pop-culture references-- but this... setting, this is what really makes the foundation for your entire game, and there are a bounty of other inconsistencies in this environment that break the atmosphere. Without divulging too much, there are simply too many seemingly relevant storylines that pull you away from the main drag and back into the 50's and 60's... with little to no explanation or story progression through the varying arcs, barring the tidbits you might care enough to piece together on your own. To sum it up, this experience was like the one time I got in a cab expecting to get to my house and somehow ended with a cabdriver that took me 15 miles from my destination; neither of us knew how we got there, and no one said anything on the ride down, but both of us knew we were going the wrong way hoping the other would say something first.  Once you get past the old storyline switcheroo, the story in and of itself is endearing and captures your interest enough to effortlessly move you from room to room, collecting clues and building a deeply emotional teenage narrative. Pacing is not an issue, for what I thought would be confusing in a more-or-less open turf (you're just in one house-- but a large one, with free reign). The clues point you in the right direction, without making you feel like an absolute idiot. (Of course, if you do feel like an absolute idiot, you can always consult your map.) I can't say that I felt like I was ever mind-boggled by this short little game, but I wouldn't say it held my hand from beginning to end, either. This is a nice, easy balance for something a bit more casual and observation-based, best suited to people who like to take their time and scrutinize the most minute details of every game before they move on to the next part.  The soundtrack was pretty sweet, I personally wouldn't buy this game for its musical offerings, but I enjoyed the flavor it contributed to the plot.   I would recommend this game to: -people who like to interact heavily with their surroundings in games (a lot of detail is paid to looking closely, down to newspaper listings and full lists of ingredients on food packages) -people who appreciate the artistic approach to these types of games (unique soundtrack, personalized handwriting, and a well-delivered narrative -people who like walkin and clickin  I would not recommend this game to: -people who are looking for a long-term investment or fully-immersive experience over time. (This game is SHORT) -people who approach games with duration:money paid ratio ($19.99 is expensive for this experience, catch it on sale. I picked up my copy for 5 bucks) -people who are looking for horror or mysteries to solve  Overall-- I'd rate this game somewhere in the ballpark of 6.8-7 out of ten. Recommended, with some caveats, and definitely on sale.

This game is not a horror game. It is not a gameplay-based game. It is more of an interactive story.  Now, a lot of people are angry that this is considered a game. But, there are graphic novels and such on the market that people seem to love and are even LESS of a game. I don't see anyone bashing those - but whatever. Personally, I like games where you find clues that lead you to new clues and, thus, unravelling the mystery.  The game (or story) is great. Nostalgic for anyone who grew up in the 90's (references to pop culture, SNES, riot grrrl punk, etc.) But, let's get down to it. As you play, you'll realize that it's a love story. I ain't one for love stories, but this one is damn touching. I'll admit that I cried. I'm a sappy ♥♥♥♥ for certain things deep inside.  Basically, you go around the house picking up objects finding clues that lead you to the next - all for the sake of trying to find out what happened to your sister. There's no combat or anything. Just walking and picking up/moving/reading objects. If you go into this game thinking anything else, you're going to be disappointed. You have to go in knowing you're playing an interactive story.  The atmosphere is pretty great. Being alone in a huge dark house on a stormy night leaves a really earie feeling on the player. I loved it. Especially for the fact that there is litterally nothing to be afraid of. I feel that it taps into our little selves and how we used to be (or still somewhat are) afraid of the dark and being alone, say, in the basement of our house. If that's what the devs were going for - bravo to them.  9/10 nostalgia overload, made me cry, needs more Bratmobile The game is good. Play it.

I bought due to the intrigue surrounding it, and I now consider it to be a great buy. It's a short game but it feels like it's longer then it actually is. The setting is perfect. It conveys a sense of horror and you get goosebumps throughout the many areas you visit. I mean come on. It's dark and it's raining, you're alone in this huge house, and there are shady hidden places. Despite many people not feeling satisfied by it, I enjoyed the ending. Only problem I encountered was the sudden frame drop during the latter part of the game. The lag took something out of it.  Definitely buy it, 8.5/10
An extraordinary journey, very beautifully done.
Wonderful piece of interactive fiction. Touching, compelling, excellently told.

This is a unique game with a good story.  Before you read any further, I should tell you I bought it when it was on sale.  When I first started playing this game, I didn't really like it that much. And when I got a little stuck in a puzzle I almost wanted to quit, but I didn't... I solved the puzzle and after that one puzzle I got caught up in the story. The graphics in Gone Home might not be the best, but in this game it didn't have to be that much better. For me it was all about the puzzles and the story.  However, do mind that Gone Home is a pretty short game and not something you can play for days.  If you are going to play this game, have fun and try only to give up if you really don't like it.  In short terms, I enjoyed it!

In an industry replete with first person shooters whose only claim to fame is the fidelity of its graphics or how quickly the player is required to kill AI characters or other players, it's completely refreshing to see a game like 'Gone Home' come along and redeem one's faith in the medium of games to tell mature, complex stories. This is a wonderful love story, told entirely through the scraps of paper and journals left behind by an absent protagonist. It's a testament to how brilliantly written and brilliantly designed this game is that it elicits such powerful emotions without ever presenting you with a character to interact with. This game transcends the medium and demands serious attention be paid to it, as a landmark for the future of interactive entertainment. My only regret, after having completed it, is that it has made me question just why the hell I'm not making games exactly like this. This game is a must-play.
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Gone Home. A Short Exploration Game That's Not For Everyone.

Gone Home is an OCD person’s nightmare. I ended up cleaning half the house by putting objects back into draws and placing pillows correctly. The Greenbriar’s should pay me for the cleanup because all I got at the end from the developers was their credits and no special achievement or bonus unlock for the effort.  The gameplay can be anywhere from 1.5 to 3 hours long depending on how fast you decide to pace it. It’s similar to Dear Esther except you are exploring a house reading all sorts of notes that cleverly illustrates a story as you progress discovering each room. I didn’t like the hand written notes, they were a pain in the buttocks to read. I also didn’t like the 90’s punk rock music cassette tapes.  I think this game is geared towards girls in terms of target audience. I’m not sure if it’ll even click with guys that are homo, it might. But hey, it’s a big step up like going from Hanna Montana to Wrecking Ball. Overall I prefer the mature poetic-like feel of Dear Esther instead.  Gone Home runs on the Unity game engine. I reckon it was a good choice (but not the best) for what needed to be accomplished. Music and 3D models set the atmosphere more than the story imho.  I would not give this game over 90/100 like many official critics have done. I feel it’s more like a 66/100 type of game. Which according to my classic database of games played is in the same league as Need for Speed: Undercover, Turok: Dinosaur Hunter and Iron Tank: The Invasion of Normandy.

A bit of a shorter game, but really enjoyable story and gameplay even so. It can be a bit creepy at times and I was half expecting some sort of horror twist, but that just shows how good the atmosphere is.
really nice house

This game is not what you expect it to be. It is an exploration game.  I recommend to not watch let's plays of this game, Play it yourself. By the end you will want to do nothing else but finish the story.  The narration si beautiful, there is one main story and multiple side stories to go explore. Definitely worth the time, you can find and read many tidbits that gives you more information.  Explore and search around!

A lot of the top reviews have negative things to say about this game... that is unfortunate. I really enjoyed the narrative and the amount of detail put into every aspect. It's worth it to reserve 2 hours and turn off all distractions while you experience this game. We pay upwards of $10 for a movie ticket these days, I'd say an interesting movie-length game is worth the current 50% off price of $9.99, especially if it encourages more content that is longer from this developer.  The most important thing about this game is that it demands you care about its characters and piece together their stories from the objects you find. You have to be willing to stop and read. There is definitely some fun to be had exploring this game and listening to the story, more fun than I had with Dear Esther (at least in this game you can inspect objects in the environment like Amnesia, this is far better than Dear Esther which I only played because of a Humble Bundle, although Dear Esther certainly wasn't bad).  As for the story, I got sucked in right away. I have a sister, I grew up in the 90s, and I even studied abroad for several months. So it was easy to put myself in the shoes of the girl arriving home to a creepy empty house. At the end there's a message in the game I wasn't expecting, but I liked the emotional impact of it all. I applaud the developers for taking this risk in both the direction of the storyline and the gameplay, and I hope we see more from them soon.  Now, if you don't like story-driven games, you're going to have a bad time. The gameplay involves exploring, inspecting, reading and listening. I'm sure there are details that I missed so I would probably play it again, and perhaps even a third time to listen to the Developer Commentary, but it's not heavy on the replayability (your playthrough will probably only last 90 minutes or so).   Granted, I bought this game for $6 and I might not have felt as positive about it if I had paid $20. But I'm sure the price will go down or it will end up on a Humble Bundle at some point, so it's definitely worth adding to your wishlist for later play.  In short, if you like exploration and an intriguing story, you will like this. If you have a sibling, and/or you grew up in the 90s, you will appreciate the nostalgia of it all. And if you want to play a game that has good emotional impact and a unique story, all without a lot of time investment, you'll like Gone Home.

I can see why people might not enjoy this game as it does not follow traditional gameplay elements. This is a walking simulator rich in story and very real characters even though you don't actually ever get to see them.   The story is absolutely supurb and if you are considering purchasing this, it should be purely for the story. It's rare to find a game that is so human and so believable. The great voice acting used through journal logs, as well as the notes found all around the house make up a well rounded story that doesn't hold your hand.   This is a game without the game. A subgenre in gaming that isn't for everyone.   I recommend this to anyone that has previously enjoyed other walking sims or anyone that is interested in storytelling and games as a medium to do so.

So I cam into this with some plot points spoiled for me to begin with, that being said I did find it somewhat enjoyable.  Of course the gameplay is nothing except walk around and mess around with ♥♥♥♥ you pick up, so yeah you could say there is no actual gameplay here, but even then as a naturally curious person I figured why not I'll keep going despit the controls being fairly crap. Now somewhat spoilers here (and by here I mean littered in this and the next paragraph, so if you want to avoid that skip as you feel necessary), I would say they do an interesting job of covering sams story, but I would have liked if they extended the 'game' with maybe getting some closure on the mothers infidelity or an actual story really covering it, or going through the fathers story of a failing author, or even the story about oscar or whatever his name was. Hell, I would have taken a story on sams childhood friend whose name escapes me, I mean sure 2 hours with clunky controls and not so good performance on my crap machine is plenty, but I was just getting interested in the rest of the family and really trying to see how they are and how they think or feel in this matter.   Really I just see this as a non-game with a cutesy story about young love at this point, and that is okay, it isn't the worst game out there and far from the best for sure, but it has it's merits, the spooky atmosphere really doesn't help, I mean I got jumpscared by a chair at one point cause the door opened funny and it was dark and I peeked part of it off the corner of my screen, and don't get me started on how creepy those secret passeges are or even the damn basement, and speaking about everywhere in the damn house, given how much of sams secret notes and ♥♥♥♥ were left strewn about the house I'm surprised her parents didn't know she was batting for the other team, hell she even mentions how it should have been obvious to them at one point.  In any case I found this 'game' surprisingly enjoyable despite all the negative reviews, It's not the best thing I've played but it's very far from the worst thing, that title stays with 'One Day for Ched'.   I will say this game is nowhere near worth full price but I still reccomend you give it a try some time, you might find parts compelling, or get spooked by a chair, really it's up to you in the end, I mean I played it like I came home and my house was in shambles I basically went around cleaning up and turning off lights to save power, but of course that makes no sense and really just sets me up to spook myself cause you end up doubling back here and there, so popping up in a pitch black hallway is not the best thing.  If you couldn't bother reading all that, well to sum up,   it's an alright 'game', give it a shot if you're interested and find it reduced in price by a lot.  Overall: 6/10

A bit at a loss of words on this one. I can very much say that it ended up being something completely different than what I THOUGHT it was going to be. Every moment, waiting for something to pop out, or scare the hell out of me.  I did not read up at ALL on Gone Home so I literally had NO clue as to what was going to happen and what kind of game it was.  What I was left with was a certain sense of satisfaction and gratitude... and wishing the game was longer. It's too short! :( I really enjoyed this installment even though it deviates from your standard gaming mayhem, FPS, or MMORPG, and that's exactly what makes this game so damn good. It's finally a break from the usual set recipies that seem to have repeated too many times.   Why can't more games have such great atmosphere, plot, and mystery?  Really an absolute -must- play game!
Beautiful, story filled game! There isn't a lot of game play but i think this works, this game is heavly story based, the writing for the characters is perfect!

+ atmospheric adventure + great sounds and music, raining and a few whispers + keeps up tension until the end (from a player who couldn't stand Dear Esther, although a lot of people compare the two) + attention to detail (cereal boxes!) + great feeling of accomplishment at the end + you can feel the devs caring for the game + matching graphical environment + easy interface  - a few storylines untold (that would be a more complicated game, though)  neutral: you decide whether the plot is for you not for teenage girls :)

I absolutely loved this game, but I wouldn't recommend it for everybody. I equate this game to a movie in several ways. You pay $10 to $20 on average to either see a movie or buy one, and it lasts you about 1.5 to 2 hours. This game is very similar. It's very short and the gameplay is simple. But the story it told was amazing.  I would probably advise waiting for a sale, however, because $20 does seem a bit too high for what you get. If you enjoy short story based games like Journey, To the Moon, Dear Esther, or other similar games, this one is perfect for you.  Also, this game is by no means scary. For a lot of the game I thought something would jump out at me, but this is not that type of game whatsoever.

Recommended, but not for full price (19€). This just barely 2 hour long game tells a story that hasn't been told in video games previous (to the best of my knowledge) and tells it in a new (but not really new) way. Though its short length I felt the game dragged towards the ending. 8/10

'Gone Home' happily made me understand thousands of people's romances, even when they go against my beliefs. Well, I guess agreeing wasn't the point — feeling in your own skin is. Great films do that. And OH BOY, did I feel it here! Them strings in my heart got pulled alright, and I was glad each time. This is not a videogame for videogamers. It is something greater, albeit much simpler: a cozy, awkward self-discovery.  Sarah Grayson's performance as Sam's voice is so good it could make the whole thing work as an audiobook. Did you read 'Catcher in the Rye' and felt you totally got a teenager's world in 1940's New York? 'Gone Home' does that on — no kidding — the same level. Man, I'm a 20-year-old dude that grew in Brazil and they had me completely invested in 1990's Oregon-US girlhood — how big an accomplishment can that be?   I agree my investment (emotional as well) is also due to you, the player, being the one piecing clues together. Some well-placed clues, I must add. Expect zero spoon-fed information and get used to working as in the following: Bookmark inscription + Concert tickets = Affair. I see why this game can be classified as a mystery...   As the homecoming Kaitlin, you are indeed playing a detective. But instead of uncovering a muder, you discover your father's cult-followed work, your mother's frustation, and, at the core of all, your sister's candid, amusing and touching coming-of-age story. With that in a weirdly tense atmosphere, I confess me some subtle changes in pulse rate, throughout the board.  You know what? I cannot possibly detatch Gone Home's experience from its format — This HAD to be a videogame.
This is not a game, it's an interactive story. The story itself is lovely and very sweet. I loved it and i can't say i didn't cry a single manly tear at some point in this game. Enjoy!
Without spoiling it, pretty darn good. Bit short, maybe.

I can barely tell you anything about this game without spoiling it. Gone Home is an excellent little story, about 1.5 hours for me, and a true roller-coaster of plotline.  Drop the $4.00, buy this game, and enjoy an atmospheric and nerve-wracking mystery.
2 hours of gameplay and i finished it, but itt was a fun experience and well guided that i never felt lost.
Surprising. That's the only way to sum it up.  It ain't what it appears. You'll either be terribly disappointed or blown away. For me it was the latter.  Saying anything more would ruin it.

This is one of the best games I have played in a long, long time. There's no violence, there's no button mashing, it's just you in an empty house - and not just any empty house, a house with a story to tell. In photographs, notes, and behind loose panels lies this story. It took me a few hours to get through the game, and I enjoyed every single moment of it.  The story was... I don't have words for it. It isn't really your everyday story, it's different, and some of us might have seen similar stories around us in real life, or in movies, or whatever, but this story from the viewpoint of a third-person... it left me speechless.  It's realistic, original, and I couldn't help but shed a tear by the end of this. A certain section of people might enjoy it more than everyone else, a certain section will not enjoy it at all. It isn't really for everyone; some people won't relate and they'll dismiss it for lack of suspense or whatever, but this game has shown me that a story can be told in a straightforward manner, without turns and twists, and still be enjoyable.  Buy it, seriously, it's like $4.99 now and worth every cent.
An interesting, touching game with a fantastic atmosphere and wonderful story, if you're willing to put in the effort to uncover it. 10/10

This game is an experience in storytelling. There is something to bed said about a story told almost solely through items you discover, and the journal of a girl being read aloud to you by her disembodied voice. There are no characters to see, they don't exist in a physical sense, but you will be immersed in a world that is so very vivid, one fleshed out for you by small notes, cassette tapes, and Sam's commentary. I got wrapped up into Sam's story, into her life and her love, her struggles and her successes, and the ways I found myself relating to her. You won't regret becoming invested in her.  The atmosphere of this game screams 'survival horror' in a sense. Massive, old house with secret passages, a house that is vaguely implied to be the scene of some sort of horrific occurrence; exploring, alone, on a dark, violent stormy night. In fact, I was worried most of the game of some sort of cheap jump scare, a ghost or a bloody scene, but it never came. That's, of course, not the point of the story, but my exploration was punctuated by the tenseness I felt, and the quiet, unsure fear of what each room held. There's something to be said about a game that creates an intense atmosphere, fills the world with details (labelled videotapes and Super Nintendo games? Nostalgia) and tiny things to discover, and just...lets you roam free.   Let's just say, for the second hour of the game, I was near tears. By the end of the game, I was crying. This game constricted itself around my heart in a way no other game ever has, especially one this short. It actively blurs the lines of narrative, of the ways to tell a story, and it succeeds - many games have, but this one holds a place for me because of the simplicity of the story and the masterful execution of telling it. Simply put, this game is an experience.

This is not a game, it's not a challenge, it's barely even a mystery. It is, in fact, an exploration of a new mode of storytelling. It's been compared to Dear Esther, and while I might say the two are in the same medium, I'm not even willing to say it's the same genre. Gone Home tells us a story where more than half is told purely through the detritus left behind as photos, notes, cassettes, and thousands of little pieces that come from living your life. It's a very effective medium for immersion and I found myself emotionally attached to the characters and their stories by the end.  If you're just looking to play a game, you won't find one here. If you are interested in reading a short story in a wholly new way; Gone Home is for you.

Would I recommend this game? A tricky question. I really enjoyed this game, but I'm not certain it would be right for the typical Steam-using gamer. I'm finding it hard to pigeonhole this game, and that in and of itself is part of what made it a refreshing gaming experience. I don't want to spoil anything, especially with it being so short and happily I went into the experience knowing little to nothing of the game's premise. Short and sweet, 'Gone Home' really hit me in the feels. For lack of replayablity (the story really is the whole point) and clocking in at just under two hours of play, I would be hard-pressed to recommend buying this at full price, but I picked it up on the summer sale, so what the hell? Go for it.
One of the best narrative games I have ever played. There are both heartwarming and unsettling moments that makes you never want this work of art to end.
One of those games where you think to yourself when it ends: Wait, was that IT? I clicked all around and got a really juicy story, and you end it like THAT? COME ON, MAN!

Learn the past of a young female at the age of 17 in 1995. Kaitlin Greenbriar brings you on a motivational and inspirational experience throughout the game called Gone Home.  **UPDATE** The game's ambience itself seems a bit horror-like. To me, the game can fit into the horror section.

Gone Home only takes a couple hours to play through. If you want to truly enjoy the story then don't rush through it. Take your time, look around, go through things, and do your best to find all the clues hidden around the house to truly appreciate the game. Gone Home does a great job with the atmosphere and I recommend giving it your time.

Feeling lonely, scared, lost, frightened, sad, happy, sad again ...   Gone Home is an art form of it's own like books or movies. Outstanding work of telling a story.  If you enjoy reading books, you will enjoy Gone Home.

Well, at the sales price I definitely recommend the game. I kind of got Life is Strange vibes when playing. I finished it in about 3 hours, but I took a lot of time looking for everything and having no mouse slowed me down. So it's a pretty short game. I found it interesting overall, but I was expecting more. The storyline didn't really shock me, but I suppose it's an emotional game. I was hoping for to see a ghost or something... I was pretty spooked at the beginning of the game, but all of that went away about 10 minutes in. But it's not supposed to be a horror game in the first place so it's not really anything to complain about. I also feel like the description of the game makes it seem like something more intense is supposed to happen and the ending would unfold something shocking, maybe even sinister. Overall, yeah, for the sales price I would recommend it. It was still enjoyable and it genuinely made me emotional at times. I wouldn't have spent 20 bucks on it though.

So CUTE! I felt energy game brings. I felt 90`s with cassettes and buttons. I remembered how is to be a kid, trying to adapt on school. Then, remembered how is to have teenage thoughts, then adult thoughts, adult issues and difference between living intensively your life or just let is pass away like most people. I felt. I felt! A lot of things. And this, for me, it is the most valuable in a game. There is games for passing time, and THE GAMES, which manage to touch people`s hearts with unique experiences and feelings. Gone Home is one of this special games. Priceless sensations. I deeply appreciated!

Such an amazing game! I loved everything about it; how all characters have their own things they're going through, how the game portrays young rebellion and love, and the music, especially the music! Oh and 90's, hellz yeah!  Length is a matter of perspective but full price imo still worth it. On sale, even better. I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves a good heartfelt story. I'm no writer but this had me hooked.

This is not a game about horror. This is a two-hour journey about feelings. It has been made clear that this is not a product for everyone, but for me it was quite the experience.  Through the scattered pieces of paper, I got to know the characters and their personality without even meeting them. I couldn't help to sympathize and identify myself with them and their situations. And that, in my opinion, denotes an awesome job in writing which I even found somewhat innovative. Sadly, the ending felt short of my expectations, probably due to the straight-forward main story.  Sound is where this title shines. Nice suiting music coupled with superb voice-acting bring the main protagonist to life in a very believable and emotive way.  Graphics are nice, boosting a good work in textures but -unfortunately- they don't always seem to blend properly. Occasionally proportions looked off to me, specially at default FOV. The 90's theme the game is set is very well done, so expect some nostalgia. Gameplay wise, there are some annoyances which forced me to disable some options in favour of immersion.  Its weakest point, as already stated by many, is its price tag. We have seen similar products with much more duration and replay value for much less. With almost no replayability, $20 is simply too much. In-game developer commentary has been added, but due to quality issues I wasn't too kin on listening to all of them.  Despite its flaws, this is the kind of experience that will have you speaking and thinking for a couple of days. Best played during a rainy night, and at the same time as a friend so you can then share views. I strongly recommend this title, but at a discounted sale price.

I don't know how I feel about walking simulators. I've played many and found them...meh. If you go into Gone Home understanding that it's more of a 3d tour than a game and allow yourself to get invested in the story you may come away content with the experience. The home you travel through is convincingly detailed. The story is well written,paced and voiced. Overall a worthwhile hour and a half.

While many people don't call it a game, Gone Home plays like a circle, everything being resolved at the end, and meeting back up at the begining. It's an experience, a story told to you and only you can turn the page. It is a big fetch quest, searching rooms to find x to backtrack and enter y, but the story goes along with it so well that I didn't even care.

Quite short and no replay value, but the story is worth it. It is extremely linear, but this means that you don't get stuck trying to solve a bizzare puzzle and taken out of the story. Worth dedicating an hour to play through the game in one go.
this game was pretty therapeutic --     i was scared that this game would add to the huge pile of corpses on the bury your gays trope pile, but you's gonna be okay

I played this game in one go. Once you start you want to know what happened. It is a story based game, if you like exploration game with a bit of investigation, then you will have fun for 2h. Definitely recommand it.

It's definitely a story game, not an adventure or scary game in the slightest. It's also rather short so if aren't interested in a game like this I wouldn't purchase it. I found it rather enjoyable and it really showed me some 90s culture. Grab it on sale though because $19.99 is rather pricey. I got it for $5 so I was pleased. Check it out some time if you want. 8/10

While I expected something along the lines of something from Frictional games I instead found myself moving along with the story and moved along by the great attention to detail through to the end. While the 80s nostalgia was a nice touch I found myself interested in the unraveling storyline of a family broken apart while attempting to peek through every little detail the developers made accessible.  There's no way I can explain how good of an experience this game was better than what you'd find perusing online reviews but I recommend the buy—as long as you don't have ADHD. Have a great day.

Engrosing story, couldn't take myself away from the game until I finished, which only takes about 3 hours. Just exploration and story, but the house you explore feels so real (especially if you remember the 90ies), and wow what a story, Indie game of 2013.

Learn the past of a young female at the age of 17 in 1995. Kaitlin Greenbriar brings you on a motivational and inspirational experience throughout the game called Gone Home.  **UPDATE** The game's ambience itself seems a bit horror-like. To me, the game can fit into the horror section.
A beautifully told story. Highly recommended.

First and foremost, if you're reading this review, it should be known that Gone Home is best approached with as blank as slate as possible. The player's imagination is critical and any prerequisite knowledge/bias towards the game will have an effect on the experience.  So stop reading right now and go play it.  ...but if you insist on hearing my opinion or you've already completed your journey through the Greenbriar household, here's a little something:   Let's see. How do I rave about this game without spoiling anything. Even after hearing the glowing reviews and critical appraise about this game, it still caught me completely off-guard. Never did I expect a few hours exploring an empty house to turn into the raw, emotional and utterly breathtaking experience. Telling a story purely through player interaction with the environment can be a tricky thing, but The Fullbright Company accomplishes this task tenfold. There is a beauty in the simplicity of this game that I haven't felt since Journey (which you should also go play if you haven't already), and though it might not work for some, I will aggressively recommend this game to whoever will listen.   Also, I purchased the $30 special edition box set within ten minutes of finishing the game. It's worth it.

Its a lovely lovely story. Great exploration and awesome 90's feel to it. The house felt like a house! Crazy, yes? I recommend playing it, but for the price.... wait for a special or just play it at a friends house (ask for no spoilers if you have those kind of friends!). The game is short and you would want to play it maybe twice, so think carefully before you purchase. Other than that, its a solid STORY.

A short narrative experience. Very good game, but feels a bit like gaming homework. If you are interested in how games can evoke an emotional response then this is a great choice. Very much like an interactive novella.

A very nice but short little narrative game. There's nothing flashy to be expected. No big plot to uncover or enemy to overcome. Just a beautiful experience of a girl who has come home to find her sister has just left.
Really enjoyed it from beginning to end. Got really invested in the characters as well.

First of all, let's all recall that this is 'a story exploration game' (quote from description, and that's completely accurate and should by itself give you a very good idea of what to expect). It is about exploring the home of a family and gleaning a very realistic and personal understanding of the various members of that family: who they are, what they love, what problems they are facing. No, there are no monsters to fight in it. Yes, if you want to finish it as fast as you can, you could probably get to the end in 20 minutes on your first try and get absolutely nothing out of it. This is not a game about running through as fast as you can. If you enjoy taking your time and examining rich environments in depth, then you will enjoy this game. If an emotive, personal, and down-to-earth story sounds appealing to you, than you will probably enjoy this game also.  I finished the game in about an hour and a half. Yes, it is short, and no, it has no replay value. Once you've heard the story, found all the hidden crannies, read all the papers, and thrown all the toilet paper on the floor, that's really about it. However, I am hesitant to say that it doesn't have much CONTENT. It has a lot of content; each scene is packed with tons of detail, and brings the never-on-screen characters to life to an incredible degree. The writing and voice acting is all also quite good.  I've been reading a lot of really good, detailed negative reviews of this game, and I want to say that many of those people have really good points! I agree that the game seems to go out of it's way to include creepy elements that tease you into expecting it to turn horror at any moment, but then that never goes anywhere. I think this is a symptom of the game's biggest flaw, which is a lack of unity (also maybe a tad bit of misleading advertising). While it includes lots of rich detail, several elements of the story start to feel incidental by the end, when you start to realize they're not all going to tie together after all.  However, at the end of the day, I think this game was emotive and believable, and it told it's story elegantly and eloquently. I would recommend it, although I would not say the game is for everyone. -- 7/10

This game deceived me! And I really enjoyed the way it did it, luring me into this creepy mansion, tricking me into thinking this was another paranormal/supernatural setting, while it turned out to be something else entirely. Yes, probably it's gonna have a different impact on a female audience, with all that sisters' stuff, but men shouldn't complain, as they get to explore a young girl's intimate world, things she could share only with her big sis, as exposed as it can get while keeping all the underwear still on.

What a wonderful experience that 'Gone Home' offers. More story than game, and I was drawn into it and couldn't stop till the end. In many ways it felt like I was getting to sneak around and learn about real people and their lives...it never felt fake. Pros: Extreme attention to detail. The 'Home' is more like 'Mansion' due to it's size and complexity. The emotional involvement I felt is rare for this kind of game. There was a reminiscence to 'Myst'. Cons: The game was rather straightforward, and lacked serious puzzle solving. It was also rather short...I finished the main story in less than 3 hours and that was with me carefully examining everything I could get my hands on!...if only I could have experienced more of this 'world'!

Don't buy this expecting a videogame. Buy it expecting a movie. Sure, the $20 price tag is a lot for a short videogame, but it fits right in with current blu-ray prices. You're not paying for a game with endless replay value (or any replay value at all). You're paying to laugh and cry and learn and have a beautiful 2-hour experience.  The story is immersive, the atmosphere is the perfect blend of spooky/mysterious, and once you play for a few minutes you'll want to finish the game. And you'll be able to, because although most people don't have the time to attention span to devote 10+ hours to a normal game, almost everyone can find a couple hours to watch a movie.

A fun exploration game with an interesting story and fun method of telling it. If you liked Dear Esther, you'll probably like Gone Home.  Just don't pay full price for it. $20 for a game that'll last you maybe two hours is just an awful deal. I paid $5 for it during the summer sale, and I'd say that's a fair asking price for it. Anything more than that is really pushing it.
A great short story told in the medium of video game. My wife and I played this together over our Holiday break, and we enjoyed it very much.

One of the most personal stories I've ever experienced in a video game. Although short, about 2-4 hours, its still a masterfully crafted game. If you know about 90's pop culture, this game will resonate a little better with you but I would still recommend it to anyone who wants to experience a story that is very unique in this medium. If you need your games to have action or huge amounts of replay value however, I probably would stay clear of Gone Home. 8/10

Having heard a hell of of a lot of chatter about Gone Home, I thought it about time to finally to check it out. One of the big criticisms is that it has NO gameplay. Ok, so there's no jumping, no shooting, not really any puzzles and limited interactivity, and whilst I can kinda see their point, I wholeheartedly disagree.  Discovery is the gameplay, much as it is part of Resident Evil. Uncovering the mysteries is the gameplay, as seen in everything from Myst to Bioshock to Heavy Rain. Finishing this game filled me with joy. A different kind than I get from defeating Corypheus in DAI, or getting a KD ratio higher than 1:1 in (insert FPS of choice), but nevertheless joy. Alongside Telltales' games and Life is Strange, I am very happy to have these new and different experiences in gaming.  Thanks Fullbright, I can't wait to see what you do next.
A fantastic game with a lot of heart. Runs about 3 hours and tells a very deep and immersive story. A remarkable use of the medium to tell an engaging and heartfelt story. I highly recommend it.

Incredibly moving story Superb writing Nice visuals, great audio You get a sense of each of the character's narrative arc throughout despite never meeting them  Mouse controls a little janky at times when hovering over objects A little short - but worth it during the sale

I just finished playing this game (straight playthrough, no breaks) and so I'll sum up what I'm feeling right now:  Wow. Simply, wow. This is truly an amazing game, and I say that with the utmost sincerity. With its simple controls and consistent stormy ambiance, it makes a fantastic choice for a casual play. Combined with the gripping plotline, I can say for sure this game will keep its players enraptured quite easily with its emotional rollercoaster of delightful twists and turns.  The soundtrack is perfect, with none of the horrible glitched bytes or overpowering segments that are unfortunately found in some games. Don't want to listen to the music you just started? Turn it off - it won't effect the game.   If you have a few hours to spare, or are looking for a new game to pull you in, play 'Gone Home'. I can assure you, it's well worth it.  **EDIT** I just noticed that the discount I had when purchasing this game was much higher than realized, and am inclined to agree on one point with the various negative reviewers: while a delightful game with excellent ambiance, it is too short to charge $20. Buy it on sale.

It took me a while to buy Gone Home after all the positive discussion surrounding the game, and I'm a little sad I waited so long. This tale of discovery while exploring an unfamiliar home on a stormy night is incredibly focused in what it wants to say, and keeps you engaged right until the end. It ended up being my second favourite game of 2013.

'Gone Home' has some excellent characterization and environmental storytelling. The gameplay isn't much to write home about, as it's mainly walking around and looking at stuff, but that's mainly just a vehicle for progressing through the narrative, which is the real draw here. It's not a very long game, clocking in at MAYBE two hours, unless you find yourself in a rut, so this is probably a Wishlist game, to buy when it goes on sale, unless you've got money to burn. All in all, though, definitely recommended for people who like exploring and watching a story unfold largely through context.

The way this game started did not have me expecting what I'd learned by the end. It was surprisingly sweet and emotional at times. The voice acting is amazing - I don't know how many times I got goosebumps (with Sam in particular). The game itself is simple, but the way the characters' stories are told is unlike any game I've played. It's short, different, and will stay with you.
I'm not crying, you're crying.

Admittedly, this game appeals to a niche group of gamers: those who value story over action. Being a member of this group, I enjoyed the five or so hours I put into the game very much. I do feel I should mention that, 1) I am a very slow and methodical gamer, and 2) I began playing at midnight and refused to go to sleep until I had milked the game for all that it had to offer. The brilliant music and voice-acting complement this nostalgic joyride wonderfully, and I believe it makes a strong argument in favor of videogames being the superior mode of story-telling. The pace at which information is revealed to you allows for plenty of time to ponder the many mysteries of the plotline and form your own theories while searching for the next clue. When reading a book or watching a movie, such contemplation is best achieved by interruption (i.e. setting down the book or pausing the movie,) but this is not necessary when enjoying this medium of interactive narrative. If you are homophobic, I suppose the storyline would put you off a bit, but personally, this game resonated beautifully with my soul, simple though it may be. Obviously, it's always best to wait and see if it goes on sale, especially for such a short game, but I give it my strong seal of approval.

Trigger warnings at the bottom may contain spoilers.  I probably wouldn't buy this at full price because of how short it is but it is a good game and well worth the time and money if it happens to be on sale. There are no puzzles or combat in the game. The only goal is searching for clues about the lives of the mother, father, sister, and great uncle of the protagonist. It's a light mystery about a teen romance and a troubled marriage. While there are a few times when the player may be startled by thunder or power outages it's definitely not a horror game. It's a story driven game about people and how they change over time.   The largest part of the story is about Sam, the protagonist's sister, discovering herself and coming into her own. Which wouldn't be half so compelling if the romance in the game was a conventional one. The writers did a lot of things right with the romance. They gave the characters time to develop as friends so they had chemistry and put a little twist on things which made it more interesting. Over all the story is well written.  Most of the story is communicated through text documents found throughout the game many of which are private things written by the protagonist's family. This gives the story an intimately personal air. It's wrong, and rude, and awkward to be going through someone else's things but at the same time it brings the player closer to them because the player is learning about their lives and what matters to them. Because the story is communicated largely through text there is a lot of reading. Fortunately, there is a feature which can be switched on and off that puts easy to read bold text over documents. For anyone who is dyslexic, can't read cursive, doesn't have the best eyesight, or is just not good with hand writing this could be very helpful. This feature does have a tendency to glitch out after a while but restarting the game seems to fix it.  This game does push a lot of nostalgia buttons for the 90s but also just for being a kid which probably doesn't changed much. For the right audience this can be a very compelling game like it was for me but that's not going to be the case for everyone. It's not a must play, its audience is too narrow for that, but if it sparks you interest it's worth a try.  Triggers: Marital problems, cheating, some homophobia, childhood punishments such as being grounded. No suicide or sexual assault.
A confidently told, engaging interactive short story told through exploration and hunting for clues. Just don't get upset about the length.
You need to play this game. Stop whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you are doing and buy it, then play it all the way through in one sitting, then maybe cry a little.

Gone home is a great immersive story exploration game. It will not be to everyone's taste as the game play is solely based on you moving around and piecing together the clues of what has gone on in your absence. If like me however, you enjoy a break from big games and want a good story or puzzle game to immerse into for a short while then definitely give this a go. The atmosphere is tense and kept me on the edge of my seat for most of the game. Trying to figure out what had happened was interesting and for the first half of the game had 2 or 3 possible ideas. Towards the end of the game it became obvious where the story was heading and while I did enjoy how it ended I did feel like I would have preferred the other direction the story could have gone. The music was great in game and really enjoyed finding the tapes to listen to the next song. Bottom line, I really enjoyed the game, the atmosphere, tension and overall story was enjoyable. If you like games within this genre it is worth a try especially if you see it on sale as I did!

I started it up, played it, finished it, adored it and wished I could be with my girlfriend that is studying abroad in Denmark.  Makes you think about the people you love. How many games do that?  10/10

Gone Home is short but sweet. If you can pick it up on a sale, I recommend giving it a try. Know that it is not a traditional game. There is an immersive story that feels like a short indie movie, and there are multiple layers to the story that reward careful exploration.   If you prefer action titles and don't care for exploration, this may not be the game for you. However, if you enjoy narrative, you may just be surprised.

A short and fun adventure game that gives about 150 minutes of gameplay. Has a unique storyline and progression although a fatal flaw in game design allowed accidental 'completing' of the game by hearing the last journal entry before finding its prior entries. Sort of like reading the last page of a book before finishing the first half.
Brilliant story based game that will not let you put it down until you've finished. A must play.
This game was worth $2.99 and four hours of my life. Have a couple beers first.
I did like the story. The gameplay... not so much.

Although it was a really short game (only took like 2-3 hours to complete it), I really liked the story. It's not one of the best games I've played since it so different from the rest out there, but it sure is one of my favorites.

I haven’t felt the need to review a game until I picked this up with a Humble Bundle. It brings you into an intimate examination of one family’s life as you explore their new home, while discovering each members’ inner struggles and thoughts. Masterfully crafted with unexpected depth and charm. Highly recommended.

As the game advanced, it developed a sensation of uneasiness and tension in myself. The story was full of the most carefully planned details, the makers did a great job in the making of the characters, specially Samantha. In the whole experience you feel that there is just way to much 'evidence' and as a downside, it's a quite short game; although each of those two details balance each other.  I liked the experience and they way it developed. It's all about the story, and it's a really good story.
this game has a realy capitivating that will keep you going, make you yern to reack the ending.
Something you must take the time to experience. Being in the right mindset is key.

A mildly interactive short-story game set in the mid 1990s, lasting about 3 hours. If that sentence didn't turn you off, then you'll probably really enjoy it... I did. Piecing together the story and the characters almost solely through bits and pieces left throughout the house was suprisingly engaging and enjoyable. The sole-character voice acting is superb and lends depth and genuineness to the story.

A thoughtful game with a great story, Gone Home is an experience as much as it is a game. While the player may feel that they are not actively participating enough, the story more than makes up for the lack of player agency. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a fully immersive world with a great story.

I wasn't too sure I was going to enjoy it when I first saw it but after forcing myself to sit down and play this I was hooked right from the off. I knew this wouldn't take me long to complete but at least the story kept me interested throughout especially as you explore this absolutely massive house.  Pros - Quite an enjoyable underlying story - Area of exploration is bigger than expected (level design was definitely one of their main focuses) - Plenty of Punk music (be prepared for some loud stuff)  Cons - Even though I completed the game I didn't really get a sense of achievement, more satisfaction.
This is more of an interactive story than a game, but it has a great atmosphere. It's also short, so I would recommend getting it while it's on sale.  Definitely worth buying, though.
SImple and short game that is exciting and interesting from beginning to end, Highly recommended!

I enjoyed the story quite a lot, although very short (an hour to two hours long depending on if you like be thorough). The graphics are nice, and as was the voice acting. I would recommend it more if it was less expensive (due to the short story), so get it on sale.

This was quite possibly one of the most emotionally satisfying roller-coasters I have ever gone through in a game. As I entered the house, I couldn't shake the feeling that something was meant to shock me, throw out a cheap scare. But as I explored Sam's story, that fear blended with intrigue, a delighted curiosity about her and her family. (Btw, was the mom flirting/cheating with Ranger Rick? ((great name choice.)) I won't give anything away, but near the very end, I fully expected the scare, the jump moment. Instead, my heart melted into a pile of 'Awww' goo.   9.9/10, there were some model collision issues where I dropped a book that fell through the desk or cabinet, but let that not take away from this brilliant short story of a video game.

I got this game when it first came out. I don't regret it. I enjoyed the storyline and the characters that went along with it. For most people, they didn't care for the atmosphere (I think mostly because it gave this freaky vibe when there wasn't actually anything to fear).   I also can't say I was disappointed at the end, but I definitely thought something else was going to happen. It would have been nice if the game was longer, had DLC, or at least had different endings.  All in all, i really enjoyed this game. I thought it was nice from my usual killing zombie games (:

I picked this game up, cause I wanted a storyline in first-person, which is what I got, but the mystery behind the game is basically fed to you with a spoon... which also means you can guess what's going on or happened before you're told. It's not going to be like The Stanley Parable, where every turn is going to be different, no; this story is very linear, and by the end of it you will probably get bored. The whispers, noises, and the lights that flicker keeps you on your toes, but the narration dulls it because this is not a horror game.   tl;dr: It does some things right, some things not, so you may or may not enjoy this game.

Gone Home is a very well crafted and important game. If 'gaming' as a storytelling medium is to be taken seriously, more games that aren't Master Chef VI or Crab of Duty VII need to be made. The stories that can be told with games are more than how many aliens or teenage boys you can frag. This game tells a story, and it is beautifully done. The game is short, which is fine. Not all games need to be 80 hours long. People looking for a standard game can go play God of War Effect III. or whatever. THIS game has amazing atmosphere and as you explore, a real sense of dread giving way to connecting with very fleshed out characters. You really learn about this family.   In short, this is a great experience, a different type of game, and speaks well for the gaming medium in general as a vehicle to tell all types of stories instead of Counter DOTA LOL Strike.

I guess i was lucky i came into this game without any expectation. As i grew up as a teenager in the 90ies, this game resonated with me. Confusing at first, i actually liked the story and the atmosphere of it. True, it's nothing exceptional, but it's for once a realistic story without game-typical concessions. No zombies, no horror, no parapsychological, no hero's journey, no fantasy, scifi or aliens. Just a story of humans, told in a convincing, non-pretentious way.  You really have to take a quiet evening to enjoy this game. It hardly develops its story in hurry. It's not for the average gamer expecting to be entertained or logically challenged. Are you a sorta voyeuristic discoverer? Do you like to go through other people's stuff? Do you enjoy drama novels? Do you have a quirk for the 90ies? Is reading several pages of various style no problem for you? Are you a girl? If you can answer several of those questions with 'yes', you might like this game.  Then again: Is it worth 20 bucks? No. It's seriously too short to be priced that way. Is it the revelation the critics make it? No either. It's a well crafted story experience, not more. Is it the 'walking sim' self-called gamers make it out to be? Absolutely not. My recommendation is: Get it in a deal, i know i'll get it for my sister on the next one.
+ Impeccable writing + Fantastic voice work + Original, powerful themes + Amazing sense of exploration + Evocative score/soundtrack   9.5/10

What can I say about this little indie Game. Well at first i was a little sceptical of how well it would be put together along with the whole structure of the game itself. Howevver this game somehow manages to draw you in slowly. Perhaps its when you first read the note thats stuck to the front door or when you are hearing your Sister's (Kaite) monologue as you try to find out what is going on. At first the game had me questioning as to what genere this game was going to be but as I uncovered more and more I just aimed to try and find out what was going on. The story is this game is something close to a work of art. I dont think I have ever been touched this way in terms of how a Game interacts with the individual.   I found that this game got the story line down to every correct letter and im surprised that we havent had something as powerfull as this before. If people are contemplating getting this Game i would recommend you to get in a hearbeat if you find overwhelming storylines your thing. Theres no action jut some good old investigation work that is required throughout. I mean as i got to the end of this game I my mind had started to peice together this relavtivly simple but powerfull story. I wanted to run to where I needed to go just to hope is was not as i thought it to be.   After all this I would recommend this Game 10/10 I do hope these indie dev's do make another one.

Just finished the game with completing all of the journals and other eastern eggs stuff %100 completed with spending nearly 4 hours to read every single paper or to inspect all of the items in da house; I enjoyed the game pretty much. But I was expecting some thriller elements in it nonetheless. The atmosphere was fine, the soundtrack was nice enough, and the story was intriguing at first, but the finale was not so surprising, so it was a little disappointment. If you like exploration games like this, give this title a try, especially if your childhood was majorly in 90's, because there are so many elements integrated into the game's world with that era's famous phenomenons. A 7/10 for me. The reviews on game critic websites are overrated IMHO.
A powerfull narrative experience, which is tailored only by your own curiosity and your attention to details. Totally worth to play if you enjoy games with rich character backstories.  9/10
This game is asthetic gaming at its finest. Instantly made it into my top 3 favorite games of all time. I got shivers from my head to toes for a good 30 seconds at the end.
This is one of my all time favorite games. Didn't think much of it at first. Alright another cheap indie game. Nope, 10 minutes in and I was hooked.

Hmm. I quite enjoyed this 'game' after all. Not because it can be seen as artsy, I really disliked The Bridge for that very reason. The exploration mechanics are neat (would love to see the same thing in a larger project) and there's been a lot of detail put into the house and subtle little jokes thrown in that I giggled at. There's not so much of a story unfolding in the game, you're just unraveling details about what has happened previously. It's cute at times and quite serious also. I think the game handles the topic very well and makes it seem realistic or at least believable.   Puzzles... are dreadfully easy. If you can call them that. It's really just looking through drawers and stuff finding codes and clues. Seeing how short the game is (I think I was quite thorough in my reading of the back of chips packages and still only clocked in 1,5 hours) this really isn't something you should get this game for. It tells a story and does so pretty well, but it offers little else. Replay value is pretty close to zero, but there is dev commentary and some other minor options to change.  But then there is the issue of pricing which a lot of other people have brought up. I picked this game up in a bundle with other games for a price I can't remember - but had I picked this up for the 20€ the steam store is asking for I would have been horribly disappointed. I would again stress that I don't find the game really bad in any aspect, but in the grand scheme of things the attention to detail doesn't excuse the poor length and lack of replay value. I don't want to spoil things for anyone else, but I enjoyed the game the most early on when you didn't know what to expect from it. Looking back... it's ok.  So to sum up, great exploration with much detail put into even small objects. Super short. Great atmosphere, but doesn't do much with it. Probably horribly disappointing if you were expecting more of a... well, game.   I really wish you could do neutral reviews on steam.
not bad but very short !!! 4/10

I don't think I've given anything a 10 since To the Moon, but if my only complaint is 'sometimes walking up/down stairs felt too slow because I was impatient to see what happened next', now's a good time for another. At the beginning I kept expecting something schlocky to happen at some point, with an empty house, a stormy night, and more than one mention of ghost stories, but none of that really has anything to do with the story and is just an excuse to have you alone and able to explore at your leisure. Instead, the storytelling keeps getting better, more relatable, and more personal as the game goes on. They nailed what they were going for. It was also full of plenty of 'I remember being a teenager in the 90s' moments for me, which was fun.
fricking loved the game, 10/10 would look up Sam's naughty note to see what it said again
Excelent game! One of the first to make me feel the same sense of intrigue I felt whenplaying myst all those years ago.

A thoughtful game with a great story, Gone Home is an experience as much as it is a game. While the player may feel that they are not actively participating enough, the story more than makes up for the lack of player agency. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a fully immersive world with a great story.

This isn't really a game, so much as it is an immersive story. There are a few 'puzzles', but skipping them wouldn't detract overly from the general story arch, and they are unnecessary for completing the story. As to it's atmosphere, it's very 90s. The story is well plotted and the diary entries are beautifully voiced. And while the primary focus of the story was told well, at the end credits, I was all 'well, fine fine, but what about X? Why won't you tell me about X, which sounds like it would have been a WAY more interesting story?'

To play this game you have to be in the right state of mind. It's not about achievements, or pushing through it until you 100% everything. If you take it slow and take the time to pay attention to the little things it can be an interesting view into the lives of a family. True the plot may be somewhat predictable, but the way in which it's presented is enjoyable. Even if you do have to crawl around for bits and pieces. For those like myself who have dealt with a similar situation as the main plot it can be emotional at times. Take your time and ease into it at your own pace. There's no rush to see the end, no race to the finish. A slice of life game that is very relaxing if played the right way.
Wow. Just, wow.  Beautiful little piece of storytelling. Definitely a must play, but only contains about 1-2 hours of play. Grab it while it's on sale!
Very fun with a spooky atmosphere

Great story. great atmosphere. great game.   This game makes you question whats happend to the main character's sister, and just keeps you wanting more. After I finished this game, I wanted to play it again, or something very similar to it.  This game really makes you think about what to do with your life.  This is a game I would recomend to anyone.
Amazing game, well worth the money. Took me a while to play it, because I was getting a silent hill vibe from it, and it did make me ♥♥♥♥ my pants in one spot.  I <3 Lonnie and Sam!

Excellent way to tell an interesting Story. A nice retrospective into the 90s. Don't expect much action or hard puzzles to solve. In my opinion the game didn't really need that. The story is well told and the atmosphere in the 'Psycho House' keeps you playing until you see the credits roll down the screen.

It's been over 15 hours since I finished Gone Home, and I haven't been able to stop thinking about it since.  Gone Home is a small indie title published earlier this year by the Fullbright Company, but no-one has really discovered it until about a week ago. That's when everyone started buying it, playing it, and loving it.  But, firstly, let me talk about the fact that you either love this game, or you hate it. It all depends on what kind of person you are. If you are one of those guys who religiously plays Call of Duty for ten hours every single day, and only thinks a game is good if it has blood, explosions and swearing, and sex; you probably won't enjoy this game. At all. People like these can be described as 'Action Junkies'. Now, I'm not saying that all Call of Duty players are Action Junkies; not at all. But, there are some of those people out there, and the majority of them do play Call of Duty. However, I'm going to call these people Action Junkies simply because most of them don't appreciate games that don't focus on killing ♥♥♥♥, but focus on telling a more emotional story, or focus on telling a story that's designed to make the player think.   All of the Action Junkies can stop reading right now, because Gone Home has none of that. It has no gore, no blood, no shooting, swearing, explosions, ect, but It's still one of my favorite games of this year. Let me explain why.  Gone Home is a beautiful indie game that has conveyed the most believable and incredible emotional experience I have ever had. It blends story with design in a way that I simply can't describe. It tells a story that feels real, and true. And it all takes place in a little house for about two hours.  In Gone Home, you play a young college girl called Katie who has returned home after a year abroad. However, your family has moved while you were away, and you find yourself in a brand new house. However, when you arrive, the house is empty, and riddled with clues and secrets to uncover. This is genius. Because your Katie's family has moved, Katie has never been in this house before, and the character that you're playing is just as unfamiliar with the house as the player. But, even if you're unfamiliar with the house, you're still familiar with the characters, and you still feel part of the story, because you are the other main character's sister.  As gamers, we have these instincts and assumptions about games that we don't even realize. Gone Home takes all that and flips it upside-down. For example, near the beginning of the game, you walk down a dark corridor. Bam. I instantly thought that something was going to leap out at me from the shadows... But it never did. This game is NOT a horror game. However, it still has this keen sense of nervousness and uncomfort to it. Just the feeling of walking around a house, at night, while a storm rages outside, when no-one else is home, kept me on the edge the entire way through the game, especially when I had headphones on. Gone Home also places brilliant hints to scenarios, and you instantly suspect things are something they're not. For example, you eventually come across a bathtub stained with blood. However, as you explore the room a little more, you find out that it's actually not blood, but red hair dye. That then triggers an audio diary that explains the situation. It's a great way to tell a story, and I fear that it's some thing that we, as gamers, are seeing less and less of these days.  As you walk through the house, you find secrets and pick up clues (Key story clues/secrets are accompanied by brilliant audio diarys). And as everything starts to add up, as everything starts to piece together, and as you start to understand what happenned in that house, you finally understand what an amazing and beautiful story has taken place while you were gone, and you finally understand what a brilliant design feat that this game is.  If you ever get the chance to play Gone Home, trust me. Do it. You'll come out of it with a completely different mindset and outlook on life, and you won't get it's beautiful story out of your head for weeks. Playing Gone Home is like watching the most sad/tragic/emotional/uplifting movie ever made, but you're part of it.
