Think of it as watching an interactive movie and you do get invested in the story. Don't expect anything super natural or super scary. But I love the interactive story that it is, and my girlfriend loved it even more. But that's because she loves drama shows.   Less than 10 bucks? Get it. More? Wait a while.

Gone Home offers a rather unique way of exploring it's multilayered story.  It plays more like a traditional first person point and click game in the vein of the latter 'Zork' titles but with the freedom of allowing you to explore every nook and cranny. I found the game to be quite atmospheric, creeping around an empty house in the midst of a storm finding clues as to where everyone had gone.  It's not a game for everyone and you'd be lucky to squeeze more than 2-3 hours out of it, but if you want something a bit different then I highly recommend this one.

Gone Home tells its story in a way that only a game can. With the exception of some limited voiceover narrative, the entire story of this game - and there's a lot of it - is told through found objects in the game's world. It manages to convey an enormous amount of information about several people's personal lives without ever explicitly narrating it to you. If nothing else, you should play Gone Home just so you can see how well games are capable of telling stories in ways that aren't parroting other forms of media.

Gone Home is a slow burn ... that is the best way I can describe such an amazing game in a single sentence. Taking just 3 hours to finish it is a journey that I feel better after completing.   Gone Home is basically a 1st person point and click game, but saying that doesn't do it any justice, it's more than that. It's a mystery about a young woman trying to find why her parents house is empty. It's a story that is very confronting at times and I think this story will stick with me for days to come.  I recommend it to all but I feel that it will not be appreciated by people looking for anything more then a good action-less story.  Do yourself a favour and give it a go
A slice of fried gold.
Decent story, 90 minutes long, that is if you check every corner. Catvideo makes the game. :P
a great game...totally not what I was expecting

DISCLAIMER: Unfortunately I bought this game after the Winter Sale, so I paid the full £15 for it (so this review may have gone a little differently had I gotten it cheaper).   The story-telling in Gone Home is absolutely fantastic, and the atmosphere inside the house is incredibly eerie. The main storyline is almost wholly narrated, and the voice acting is really believable. There's a decent amount of exploration, especially given that you don't  really  need to go hunting too much for the primary stuff, but when you do spend some time looking around and opening drawers and reading little snippets of paper, you end up uncovering several side stories that are only progressed by finding further objects.  The issue I have with this game is it's length/price value. As a completionist kinda guy, I managed to get a good 90 minutes of playtime out of Gone Home, but I can imagine that anyone not interested in reading the entirety of scraps of newspapers would easily finish the game in less than an hour. That said, I don't really know what the developers could have done to expand on the game. The story is very well told, the house is reasonably big (only very slightly bordering 'unrealistic') and the setting is great.  My gut instinct still says to give this a thumbs up, but at full price I would  only  recommend this to fans of slow-paced, heavily dialogue-based indie titles. Anyone else would feel it was an absolute waste of £15.

Gone Home is the epitome of story being greater than the gameplay. It is subtle, slow-paced, well-acted, and arguably charming. You are given the freedom to explore, touch, read, analyze and interact with a plethora of househould items, most of which exist for aesthetic purpose. Due to this reason, if you so desire to explore every crook and nanny of the house, you may find yourself entranced by the occassional narration of the notes and letters you find. Approach this game as if it were an interactive movie as that is its essential purpose.  This game is not for everybody, but those who are fascinated by story-driven games, especially with a heartwarming and relatable story as presented within this game, will be thoroughly entertained in playing the game through to the end. Definitely a one-of-a-kind game, and the nostalgia it produces is enough for anyone insightful of 90's pop culture to enjoy. *yes, there is a reference to Pulp Fiction in this game* I would recommend this game to anyone in need of a casual gaming experience, albeit heavy on story. This could fall into the same category as the Telltale games' Walking Dead, Back to the Future and Wolf Among Us, but much more freedom given in Gone Home compared to the others.

I REALLY loved Gone Home, it left me quite impacted at the end. I enjoyed that it had a lot of relateability, it gave me a nice sense of nostalgia with it's 90's setting and I relished in being able to find every single tiny piece of hidden information within the game. Some people might not like to call it a game but even if you don't believe it is (I do) it is definitely an interactive experience I believe everyone should try sometime...it's only about a 1.5-2 hour game guys come on =P
Get it...but get it cheap. Word to your moms

Truly great. Masterfully crafted. Really well thought out. I absolutely loved the whole premise of the game and the whole journey through the game. There need to be more games like this one. TWENTY THUMBS UP!

Not a game in the traditional sense as there are very few things to solve. The pacing is slow and you can explore the game's world to your heart's extent until you put all the pieces together to uncover the truth behind main character's sister suddenly going missing.  Much better than Dear Esther.

It's easy to say Gone Home isn't for everyone. Not so easy to say why without giving away part of the experience. Sort of a dilemma. It's heavy on the story, and very atmospheric. Someone else on here recommended playing with headphones. I agree, although speakers work as long as there's not much going on in the room with you.   It takes about 2 hours to beat. I did it in one sit-down. I went into it not really knowing the time it would take, so that took me a little by surprise. That may turn some people off to the game. But, consider the cost of going to the movies. New releases cost ~$11 here, and if you think of Gone Home *sorta* like an interactive story and less quite like a game, that price feels about right. I grabbed it from the holiday sale, and don't regret it.  I don't think I've played something quite like it, and that's worth the price of admission that I paid to me. As realization slowly set it, I felt a little silly but also impressed. Manipulated, even. Give it a shot if you catch it on sale and maybe you'll understand why I'm vague and can't really say much on what goes on in it. Thumbs up.

Gone Home was a powerful experience for me filled with great writing, voice acting, and atmosphere that can get under your skin. Some moments felt like those nights where you're up too late and suddenly become hyper aware and paranoid in the dark of your own home.   Throughout Gone Home you roam around your family's house learning about what has happened as you've been away from them for about a year. The game is very short but that did not take away from the experience for me. The story is told pretty much entirely through notes, documents, books, and more. So it definitely helps that voice actors did such a great job.   It's a very real and personal story that encourages speculation and for you to infer some of the details through clues. Gone Home has become one of my favorite games and one that I highly recommend, if it sounds like something you'd enjoy because it is NOT for everyone.

In the hour and a half it took me to go through the experience provided by Gone Home, I have felt coursing through me more emotions than anything I may have done in 2013. Playing this game has left me feeling empowered and shaken, and the goosebumps have yet to dissipate. A story that comes and sweeps you off the ground, and one that I shall carry with me as a catalist to stride through 2014 with renewed energy.
Finished this in 90 minutes.  It's not scary.  It's not aventurous. It's a story.  I'm not sure if I liked it or not ...
A nice but rather short adventure!

Caution: NOT A HORROR GAME AT ALL  I only selected 'no' for this game only because the description on Steam inferred that it might be scary and suspenseful. Unfortunately, it was neither. There was definitely good atmosphere for it to be scary: occasional thunder, creeky floors, weird noises, etc. However, the other reviews are accurate in that you basically walk around picking up certain notes and triggering audio journals of your character's sister. No monsters, no serial killers, and no vengeful spirits.

I really like this little game. It was a really interesting narrative. I kept waiting for something scary to happen, maybe thats just what I am used to when I am in a game like this. The house looked a lot like the house from Resident Evil. I am really interested to see what they do next, maybe something larger in scope and grander in story.

I've never played a video game like this before. What this studio has acconplished in roughly two hours of gameplay is nothing short of astounding. The developers expertly play on the tropes of video games and the expectations of we have as gamers. This is, so far, the best example of an interactive story. I would recommended this to anyone. Especially hardcore gamers. Although I will say that the $20 price tag is too high considering the length of play.

Suprisingly moving title. If you're expecting a game, don't bother. This is one of those interactive movie deals where you're really just along for the ride. The story-telling is touching though, and it's actually pretty neat to explore this house. Unless you're a sociopath or a bigot, expect to be moved by the ending.
Quiet, simple but quietly, simply excels at what it sets out to do.
It's a really good game with such a good story!!! A the beginning you might think ''ok what should I do'' but you just have to open everything and search. I recommend this game to everybody!!

Gone home is a beautiful game.yes it might not be the what we concider a game persay but it is still a game.This what I like about this sure the game play is minimal but going around the rooms and checking things out is what I love to do somtimes in mainstream games.  This game is a game I hope to see made more of ,it gives us a game where a grew up can sit for a couple of hours and enjoy.Yes I said it ,the game is a grown up game.I wish more games tackle the issue of what Gone Home has but more deeper.I do really whish they made it longer(not too long maybe a couple more hours will been awsome) but oh well.  I hope this game ,get more advanture game made agin.we surly miss u point and click adventures.

Although it is definitely too short for the price (takes MAYBE 2 hours to beat if you go very slowly), this game stands out as being one of very very few games that is just about normal people living normal lives. It pays tribute to the nineties and tells a thought-provoking controversial story about a family living in that decade.
Awesome story. Recommend it!

This game is amazing! Try and pick it up during a sale(if you don't then your paying a lot of money for 2 hours of yourr time). It takes an hour to get into it, you will be so sucked into the experience you will probably finish the game in one sitting.
An amazing story and an even more amazing way to tell a story. It's a very short game, but those will be well-spent hours.
Great atmosphere and story, really immersive.

Its cool all the mistery that have and how the developers play with your mind to spect something that its not going to happend. This game have a sweet and amazing history, if you dont care about the history i recommend dont buy it, maybe your get bore.   There is no puzzels, you just go conecting points to discover the history.  I loved the game.

This was certainly different, and a great bit of nostalgia from the 90s. If you are expecting something typical, then this might be the game for you. This managed to draw me in to where I felt the immersion of being in the home and discovering things about this time in the lives of the family described in the game.   I wish that the story had been longer, but that isn't a bad thing, I think, to want more from the game. I saw that this had a lot of negative review, but I have to disagree with that.

Short and sweet. It's got a fantastic narrative, and I found myself nearly crying at the end of it. I don't normally leave reviews, but this game absolutely deserves one. I can only hope that the next game is as fantastic as this was, and for everyone on the fence, get this game, play through, and you won't regret your purchase one bit.
This is an amazing story. YOU SHOULD ALL PLAY.

I think I would only really recommend this game to those that I know will be able to connect to the story as I was able to. I definitely don't see it as a 'game' that everyone would like. For myself, it was very enjoyable. It brought back a lot of memories that were similar to Sam's and so, very nostalgic. I purchased Gone Home when it was on sale, so to me it was a good buy. I don't think I would pay $20 for it though.

First things first, this is not an normal game per say, there is no discernable gameplay evident. Do not play this game expecting it to be anything remotely similar to anything else you have ever played.  So what is this then, you may wonder. This game wants to tell you a story, a story in exploratory game form. As you explore your family home, bits and pieces of infomation will be revealed to you as you explore its' depths and nosey around in people's stuff.  The core story itself is not particularly amazing nor inspiring, however the delivery and excution made an otherwise unspectacular story seem particularly moving and touching.  If you liked interactive storytelling games like Heavy Rain, you should definitely give this a try.  TL:DR - Good storytelling through exploration. Play for the feels. Instant gratification buffs walk away now.
amazing game with a great story i recomend :D

Great game that really stretches the definition of what a 'video game' is. A very important release that will hopefully open the minds of future developers. This is truly a work of art. If you're looking for a game requiring or testing your skill, you shouldn't be considering this game at all. This game is about exploring the environment and uncovering a story that keeps you on your toes the entire time. This game is a brilliant piece of art that every gamer should enjoy. A very refreshing, mezmerizing experience.

As a fan of first person adventure games and endless exploring I really loved this. It's not so much a game as it is really smart, interactive storytelling that literally puts you in the shoes of the main character trying to to figure out what's transpired with her family during a long absence.   This is a beautiful work of art that captures a specific time period. I found it to be a profoundly emotional experience and would equate it with watching a really good movie or reading a really good book. The sound design is incredible, definitely needs to be played with headphones. The lighting effects and the house in general really set a suspenseful mood.  Also, kudos to the developers for it's female lead and storylines. We need more of this in the gaming industry.  I look forward to more interactive storytelling in the future.

Ok - forget about the haters who say 'Not worth the money, too short' and so on. If you are a gamer who looks for the special kind of games, like Quantic Dream's Fahrenheit or Heavy Rain, that means if you LOVE good storytelling and don't care only about gameplay, if you like games exploring human emotions - if you can answer these points with yes, then Gone Home is just right for you. It's really very short, took me about 3 hours or so to complete, but man, I will NEVER forget those 3 hours for the rest of my life. And some might say it's not really a game, and they are right: this is a piece of art. Think of it as the gaming equivalent of a short story, a poem or a short movie. This is as good as it gets, the developers of this masterpiece should be instantly declared gods of storytelling. If you don't want to pay the 20 bucks for it, fine, wait for a steam sale and grab it there, but definitely give it a try. It just blew my mind.
This game is increbibly beautiful.
Extraordinary. Any other comment would be spoiling it.
That kind of games I want to make.

The only premise I had read about this game was that you arrive at your new house after being away for a year, only to find it deserted, and you have to explore the house and investigate what happened. I approached this game with quite an open mind, and am glad I did because, even though gameplay is quite short (it took me 4.5 hours to finish the game and find all 24 journals) the quality of narrative and voice acting really helped make the game for me. It's difficult to write anything else about it that won't spoil it, save to say that during your investigations a picture builds up of what happened, not just recently, but over the years. Storyline aside, the graphics are good enough, the controls are straightforward (don't expect any 'change weapon' or 'jump' keys!), although there wasn't really much need for an inventory key. I can understand a large group of people not liking this type of game at all, especially those that paid a two-figure sum for the download, however if you're a fan of an independent, moving, graphical story then you can't go wrong with Gone Home. It'll be on my mind for a long time, and for all the right reasons!

It's a short story. That's really it. It's like a piece off 'This American Life' or something. Not being sure what to expect definitely improved it for me - I wasn't sure if I was going to be terrified, cry, or cheer by the end. If you're looking for an exciting game or high art, you're really not going to find it here. Like I said, it's just a short story.

This game is a work of art. I have never been more immersed in a game, or cared more about a character that you never even see visually. This game legitimately got me to shed a tear, and I've never even come close to that with any other game. Masterful.
Gone Home is a gripping, environmentally engaging and really interesting look into family life. I was happy to play through it non-stop.
Fantastic story. Well worth picking up on a sale.
This is one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences I've ever had.  If you haven't played it yet, you need to.

If you're wondering what the gameplay is like in Gone Home, it's exactly what you see in the trailer and photos above. The reason such benign gameplay is so remarkable is that it actually does an amazing job of telling a story. It is so simple, that it stands out in it's uniqueness to expand what it means to be a 'game.' To give away what the story is really about would be unforgivable, because half of the game is spent pieceing together the mystery of the world around you. What I can say is this: despite what anyone else says this game can be an amazing experience for you, if only you give it a chance. 5/5

I find that this game has offered one of the more beautiful and human experiences that I've had in 15 years of playing videogames. However, beautiful and human isn't for everyone, and considering that exploration was 100% of the enjoyment I had, reading any kind of detailed review will most likely ruins the experience.
Lesbian coming of age love story. Not what I expected but very good.

This isn't a game but an interactive story. I thought the story was interesting and the environment was well crafted. My first play through took about 4 hours, and I spent a lot of time reading things, however there were still a few mysteries I didn't unravel.  I would recommend this to someone who wants to experience a mystery story told in a novel way.

This game (more interactive story) is heartfelt and touching in a way that I did not expect. Also, a storyline that is very atypical for video games. Beautiful art and exposition. The gameplay itself is a little clunky, but the game is short enough (rather, it is an appropriate length) that I did not mind it.
AWESOME GAME. Couldn't stop playing until i finished it in one setting.
For a short game this is pretty fun. Cleared it in one sitting. Enjoyed the narrative. Liked the voice overs. Not so much on the music. Yeah good game.

Kudos to the developers for having the courage to make this unique game. They could have taken the wrong turn in so many places, but it stays true to itself instead of trying to appeal to the masses. The story is touching, the environment is wonderfully detailed, the voice-acting spot-on and it has game-play mechanics that actually works great with the story.  The story: You are the older sister in a family of four living in the States in the mid 90s. You have been on a trip to Europe for a year and while away your family has moved to a new home (a large mansion). The night you return home you find the house apparently empty, and it seems that something is amiss.  It is a game about exploring an environment and learning about the people living there, particulary your younger sister. The clues are subtle, but not obscure. For this is not a puzzle game; you won't likely fail as long as you take your time and pay attention. Still, it is very much rewarding assembling the story this way, bit by bit, in your own pace; something I attribute largely to the diligently crafted environment. Also, the characters are very well written. (One example that comes to mind is Lonnie's postcard from the school field-trip. Love that one.)  So, to sum up, this is a very unique gaming experience. Admittedly it is not a game for everyone. That is a good thing.

Pretty short 2h and i didn't rush it but it was fun .The environement is a beauty,the gamplay is fine nothing complicated and the history of the game is nice evry thing is greacfully describe nothing can ask for more explaination ! pretty worth it for my 5$

This game (more interactive story) is heartfelt and touching in a way that I did not expect. Also, a storyline that is very atypical for video games. Beautiful art and exposition. The gameplay itself is a little clunky, but the game is short enough (rather, it is an appropriate length) that I did not mind it.

A unique interactive experience well worth the price. You play as Katie, a college student who has spent a year abroad. In that year, your family has moved into a new home. When you return, you find a cryptic note from your younger sister on the door, and an abandoned house. You must search the home and unravel the mystery of your family's disapperance. A triumph of interactive storytelling, you will be thinking of this game and it's characters long after you've finished it.
Very short, but the soundtrack was lovely. The plotline was very well executed and bittersweet. I very much enjoyed this game and recommend it to everyone.

Very short, it took me a bit more than an hour to explore (probably) everything the game had to offer. I even resumed after the ending to explore the house some more. It's a well written story that is only interactive in the sense that it only continues when you find something. It kept me entertained throughout and I enjoyed it, but I would never recommend it to anyone for the full price which is quite steep for a game that won't last you longer than a movie and has no achievements, collectibles or an interactive story to keep you coming back.  In short: Good? yes, worth the price of admission (IMO)? not without a sale.

Want to play a game with a great story told in a way that couldn't be accomplished well in any other type of entertainment media? Then play Gone Home. It's unlike anything else I've played and I love it. I highly reccomend it to anyone who doesn't mind playing a game without combat.

I would recommend this game with a big caveat. This isn't really so much a 'game' as it's an interactive storytelling. Yes, other games have stories, but here you are literally being told a story as you fill in the blanks. Most of the objects you interact with have no real effect on the game nor are there any actual puzzles to solve. Being someone who grew up in the 90's, this was a great nostalgic trip back in time and much of the voice acting felt truly genuine to the times. I agree with many of the reviewers that the game is pretty short, only a few hours long and that's IF you obsessively checked everything like I did. Also the price tag is a bit steep at $20, but I got it during the steam sale for about $6 and for that price I thought it was fair. It's a refreshing break from much of the games out there and Indie games have had an amazing run in 2013. I think it's a worthy pickup if you can get it on sale.

The game isn't for everyone and, at $20, can be a bit expensive for what it is, an interactive story. There's little to no replay value but there is something here that is hard to describe. More of a visual novel, Gone Home is a game where every player takes away something different. But if you allow it, Gone Home is a good example of how games can teach something through play.  Reminiscent of Dear Esther, Gone Home is a simple, narrative-focused game whose themes of loneliness, turmoil, and confusion subtlely creates an atmosphere of tension that doesn't let go until the credits roll.   Gone Home is a treasure hunt. One clue leads to another as you explore the mansion and try to piece together just why it's so quiet.  Items strewn around the house are the only things the players can interact with besides doors and light switches. There are a few items that are inconsequential like mugs, drawers, and faucets that exist with no other purpose other than to be picked up. That said, most of the items give insight into who the characters are and the issues they face. The one character that doesn't get much elaboration is the one the player controls.  There is one weird aspect in the game. You play in first-person and when you move your camera normally, everything is as you'd expect. However, if you mouse over an item or a door, the camera slows as if your mouse suddenly jumped into a bowl of molasses. And this isn't something that the player can control either. As you're moving your mouse around to survey your surroundings, you'll hit a closet door or some other item that causes the player-camera to abrubtly slow down only returning to normal once you've moused past the 'hit box' so to speak. It's a bit jarring but it isn't gamebreaking by any means. Just something to consider/get used to.  If you're looking for a game with deep, rewarding game mechanics/gameplay, Gone Home isn't it. But if you're looking for an interactive story about the human condition and what it does, Gone Home is a fantastic example of what video games can do outside of rewarding gameplay. It causes you to think about being human.
You don't have to 'save the world' to have a great experience.

Good game. Narative is a litle bit predictable but they try to keep you guessing. Even if you know were it's headed in the first 5 minutes the narative is still really well done and the atmosphere perfect.

An interesting point and click adventure game. I really like the setting of the 90s and the story has an interesting twist.   Only major gripe is its a short play but I would still suggest to try it out.

I like this game, this is more the style of adventure game that appeals to me. I found the story very touching and I like the pacing of the game. It is short, about some 2 hours long, but it really do not need to be longer. If you have nothing against micro games where you explore and pussle thing togather then I do recomend getting this game.

Very good written narative experience. Recommended to people, who like a good story. The game break conventions. Everything turned out quite differend from what I thought. Beware that the game is really short - took me around 2 hours to finish. Also hated some of handwriting - I was unable to read some letters found in the game.  Verdict: very short, but trully amazing narrative experiense.

I liked it but I beat it in about 2 hours. I don't see how there would be any replay value whatsoever. I have never played anything quite like it before. If thats the experince your looking for then go for it.
Captivating.
Such a great story driven experience. I went into the game having no clue what to expect and really enjoyed it.
This is fantastic, a beautiful, subtle story. Love it to pieces.

Gone Home is a great game to play if you're bored one night and want to burn a couple hours, beating the game took me roughly a little over 2 hours, and although i really enjoyed the experience I was really expecting a little something extra to come from the game, and wasn't really as satisfied with the ending as I would of wanted to be. It's worth buying for the some odd $6 I paid for it, but probably not the retail price of $20. I'd give it a 7/10.  Edit: Needs DLC...PLEASEEE!!!!

I really enjoyed playing this game, the atmosphere is great, it kind of felt like coming home. I love the story and the characters, at one moment I had tears in my eyes. So did I enjoy it? YES! Would I recommend you to play it? Yes, but not for more then 5 Euro. So, the only problem I see is the price. Playing 74 minutes for 19 Euro is a bummer...

Not so much a game as it is an experiment in story telling. The premise is simple, you play an older sister of a family, you've spent time overseas and while you were away your family have moved into a new home and countless events have occured. As the game starts, the home appears empty, it's up to you to explore the new environment and discover the secrets of the home and what has been happening to your family while you were away.  Most of the narritive is told in letters from your younger sister or written in journals scattered around the home. The interaction with the environment is pretty limited but good enough to not make the home feel like a bad backdrop. The entire experience shouldn't take you more than a few hours tops. I finished my playthrough in less than 3 hours and I felt I had searched every nook and cranny. I enjoyed the experience but if you're looking for a interaction to burn several days of time up, this isn't it.

It took me a week or two to beable to write this review, and give this game a well writen that this game deserves. If you like the idea of wondering a home, and exploring this game is for you. Yes, the game this extremly short, like you could beat the game in less then two hours, but the game is still fanastic. Also, if you love a heavy story driven game, it is for you. To not spoil anything you are Katie Greenbriar, and the first thing you see is a note, from your sister. The house is empty, and the house is scary, you read notes saying that the house is haunted, and what not. The game takes place in the mid to late 1990s, so if you grew up in that time, you will have some great throw backs. As you get farther in the game, you become so in to the game, it feels like you are there. This game is what some people would say a masterpeice.
Really great game,very emotional ending,a must play.Highest Recommendation.

Gone Home is a powerfully moving interactive story that, quite honestly, left me speechless. You simply have to experience it for yourself in order to understand the gravity of which I am talking about. Buy this game, NOW!

Simple but highly effective story telling. More games should allow for some intelligence in their audience as this one does. The story of Katie's time away comes together in the player's mind without feeling forced or spoon-fed. Well worth the time to play through.
Gone Home is pitch perfect. Soundtrack is excellent in it's minimalism. Despite all the hype, it's still a great game that had me guessing right up 'till the end.
Beutiful and atmospheric. Do not rush through it.  One of the better things I've played in quite a while.
I didn't know it was a narrative game when I bought it. Short games where a story unfolds before you is not really my type. If you're into that then it's a nice game. A bit short though.
Fascinating game of exploration. I was really gripped through the whole thing. Gameplay takes about two hours.

What can I say about this game without giving too much away? Gone Home is without doubt one of the greatest games I have ever played. While neither a long game nor a large game world, it is ultimately a deep, emotional, and rich experience. The great genius of Gone Home is ultimately its use of its setting: A Family Home in the mid-1990s. It quickly becomes apparent to the player that to explore the Greenbriar House is a highly interactive experience. A huge number of objects in the game-world can be picked up and examined. Most of these objects are small, average things, such as badges and cassettes, which are a real throwback to anyone who was young in the 90s. What Gone Home does skillfully, however, is showing the sentimental aspects to these objects. Even objects such as ring-binders are shown to have attached memories. This emotional investment in such inanimate objects ultimately turns the House into a Home. Some negative comments have been made about the length of the game in relation to its price. However Gone Home's length ultimately relates to how much the player wants to explore. A high level of exploration is the ultimate reward for the player, as they gain a deeper understanding of the family members, their own trials and developments. One will find oneself truly engrossed in these characters, if they are willing to devote the time to uncover more about them. It's difficult to discuss the game's story without spoiling too much. The story is Gone Home's most central and greatest aspect. The player takes the role of Kaitlin Greenbriar, the eldest daughter of Terry and Jan Greenbriar, as she returns from a year backpacking in Europe. She finds the house her family moved into during that year empty. As the player searches the house, they discover what happened with the family during Kaitlin's year away, and why her parents and younger sister Sam are gone. The story the player uncovers ultimately debates such themes as love, acceptance, and maturity, with many of the character's stories mirroring each other in some way. Gone Home is an eye-opening experience. It pushes the boundaries of what a game can be. It will make you laugh and cry, and hopefully make you think a little. 10/10

I think it's good to know up front that this is not a horror game, nor can I really qualify this as a 'game.' Challenges are kept to a minimum, while story is placed front and center. There is no way to lose in this game, just a poor way of playing this game. That's not to say that this is a bad game. I do recommend experiencing this game, after all.  It tells its story through a series of objects you find in the house, and I must say that the story tells itself quite well. The main plot unfolds through a series of narrated diary entries, while the details are in the details around the house. If you don't like to read, I hope you reconsider. There are a number of things you can piece together through little snippets of text.  Take the tour around the house. Find out what happened. Be the creepy sister/daughter opening every cabinet or drawer that does not belong to you, leaving no stone unturned.
An amazing atmospheric game. Perfect for anyone who loves a game for it's story and for anyone who grew up in the 90's.
Wow. I can't remember a game that left me with this much emptiness. Just play the game. Don't look into anything. Fantastic game.

This is the best game I have ever played, as well as the best novel I have ever read, at the same time. Everyone should play this game at least once. If you think you understand the full story after one play through, you are most likely wrong.

Great game that really stretches the definition of what a 'video game' is. A very important release that will hopefully open the minds of future developers. This is truly a work of art. If you're looking for a game requiring or testing your skill, you shouldn't be considering this game at all. This game is about exploring the environment and uncovering a story that keeps you on your toes the entire time. This game is a brilliant piece of art that every gamer should enjoy. A very refreshing, mezmerizing experience.
This game is beautiful, gave me the feels big time
A thoroughly enjoyable experience from start to finish.

I was recommended this game by a large amount of people, and I'm glad it was. Despite that you can easily play through the entire game in under three hours, the story that the game has you play out has left more of an impact on me than games I've put hundreds of hours into. It's a simple exploration game, but each and every item and/or room that you interact with has the potential to tell an entire story. It's a rather emotional game, and it even has some very subtle creepiness to certain areas. Highly recommended.

A unique experience. I enjoyed it most for the nostalgic elements, it conveyed youth through to adulthood very well. I would have liked more resolution at the end, but that's just personal preference. I really enjoyed reading this game :)

9/10 - Truly original    +  Finally I can just turn a game on and start exploring, solving the ultimate mystery without having a game hold my hand. Genuinely creepy environments in many places, excellent ambient sounds and soundtrack. Clever nods here and there to other games. Genuine honest emotional attachment to the characters.   -  Not much. Maybe a little short, but it needed to be because of the type of game it is.
A slow moving, yet incredibly intriguing and emotional story, narrated wonderfully in past tense.

While I can't say that I was utterly astounded at the length of the game, I actually wouldn't want it to be any longer or shorter than it is. Once i got over the fact that nothing would jump out at me as it would truly be the scariest thing in the world, I kept jumping to conclusions over where this story was taking me. When it finally unraveled, I was heartbrokenly happy, and I instantly wanted to share the game with other people, which is what a good story should inspire us to do.  I should add, I wouldn't be excited to pay full price for the game, but people spend 15 bucks on a few drinks at the bar they pee out, this is worth the hour or two of your time and in the end the story stays and the game is still yours as opposed to aimlessly flushed.

If you are interested in games as a storytelling medium, or if you are a game developer who wants to become better at visual and environmental storytelling, I highly recommend playing this game. We need more games like this. Games that tell mundane, human stories in approachable way to act as a counterpoint to countless renditions of the hero's journey monomyth or escapist power trip fantasies.   Full review.  [www.terminally-incoherent.com]

Gone Home is the very definition of story exploration. You are Kaitlin, a girl who comes home after a year abroad to an empty house. Your sister, Sam, has left you a series of notes that you find by exploring your large mansion home. The atmosphere immediately makes you think you are about to walk into a horror game but there actually isnt any kind of combat or scares. The goal in the game is simply to explore and find clues.  Let's get on to the more critical things. The graphics are pretty good and I didn't experience any bugs or glitches in the game which was nice. The story sucked me in from the beginning and I found myself trying to put the pieces together and wanting to know more about this family. The characters are deep and all have something about them to be discovered. I didn't find any characters that didn't serve a purpose.  The only negatives that I found is that the game is incredibly short. I finished in under 2 hours and I explored all of the mansion and I am assuming I found all of the letters because the story progressed in a way that made sense. The ending leaves you wanting more which wouldn't be bad if this were the type of game that you could get DLC for and keep playing from where you left off but there isn't any replay value to this game at all.  Overall for the price I payed which was 3 dollars the game delivered what I would expect from a game so cheap. During sales I would recommend this game because it is a nice break from the stressful games that require strategy and good timing. It is as I said simple exploration which a good story. However, if it is much more than 5 bucks I can't say you are gettting your moneys worth out of it.

This interactive novel presents a touching mainstory about a young woman's struggles in life, and rather interesting peripheral stories to be found in the abandoned, and sometimes really creepy house where it all takes place. It's neither very original nor satisfying, but it's all weighed up by the immersion.

Just finished 'playing' Gone Home. The reason for the quotes is because it's not really a game as much as a guided interactive narrative story. You are a 21-year-old girl who's gone home (heh) in June 1995 from a lengthy trip across Europe to find the huge family home empty with a note on the door to not look for your younger sister.   As you walk around you can pick up objects (most are irrelevant) and read many, many notes and letters; listen to cassettes; hear what seem to be audio diaries from your sister as she tells a tale of her falling in love. As you discover secret passages and learn about supposed ghosts, the tension builds and the 'game' frequently gets spooky.  While game critics have fallen all over themselves to shower Gone Home with effusive praise, a LOT of gamers are hating on it pretty hard. Part of it is because many gamers are caveman mookheads who are used to shouting profanities at their Madden Warfare peeps and a story where you aren't the real protagonist that deals with grunge-era riot grrrls and middle-aged marital and life troubles doesn't interest them.  A greater part though is that it is an extremely short experience, taking no more than 2-3 hours to complete. For a game that retails for $20 - it's currently $5 on Steam; I got it for $3 on a Flash Sale - that doesn't really have you do much more than walk around looking at stuff, that's a hard sell. (The excellent Spec Ops: The Line is another example. It takes about 6 hours to beat and at $60, that's a terrible deal, regardless how good the story is. However for the $6 I paid on sale, it's a must-play.) Other than a couple of locked areas that need combinations to open, there's almost no 'gaming' in Gone Home.  I was fascinated by how they laid out the story and understand why screenwriters I've heard talk about it enjoyed it. While it sets out a clear trail for you to follow, it relies on you to pick up the crumbs and understand the loaf they fell from. (OK, that's a yellow card for terrible metaphors there.) I think I missed a few things judging from the reviews and videos I looked at elsewhere; I never found one safe's combo. The way some things are scattered around are clearly for storytelling than logic's sake and the way the sister's journals are presented doesn't make sense until the very end and even then doesn't make total sense.  That said, if you can pick it up for cheap (like $3) and you understand what you're signing on for (i.e. not a GAME game) and you want to hear some Bratmobile, then you might want to give Gone Home a home in your home's game collection. (Suck it, Gene Shalit!)  EDIT: I just realized there's a Commentary Mode. I'll have to cherk that ert.

With very little actual gameplay beyond a few puzzles and moving some items around to uncover others, Gone Home might put off some people, but it's very much worth your time. It's an incredibly touching love story told through the diary entries of your younger sister, set against the backdrop of a struggling writer, an unhappy marriage, and a dark family history. It only takes a couple hours to get through the game, and that's taking your time and inspecting pretty much everything, so if you're in the mood for a sweer, queer-positive story about taking control of your own life and following your heart, please give Gone Home a look.

This is not a game. It is a beautifully written story which happens to use the gaming industry as it's medium. Everything in the house brings you closer to the family and the struggles they deal with. The story is emotionally moving and you become attached to each letter left by Sam and I found myself pushing the pace of the story in search for the next audio log. The Greenbriar's have personal issues many can relate to and that is why this 'game' is so enthralling. Although short, the ending will leave you with food for thought and I was left feeling like Samantha could have been my sister.   The voice acting is top notch, and along with the environmental clues, the Greenbriar's home screams 90s nostaliga and really comes alive. If you have two hours to spend and want to feel engrossed with a story and a wonderful environment I encourage you to purchase Gone Home, it was an absolute pleasure to play.
I really enjoyed the concept and game play. It was genuinely interesting. However, disappointingly short. I do not regret my purchase though.

I went into this game only knowing it was well-reviewed and the most basic premise of the story. I came out absolutely stunned and impressed. The only downside is that $20 might be a little pricey because of the short length but I would still recommend this game to anyone.

This game was a bit of a suspense for me as I suspected something would happen, which never did. As I went along the story came together nicely and I rather enjoyed the twist in the ending. Although rather short for my liking, it was a nice short game to kill sometime.

Let me start by saying this isn't a puzzle game, or a horror game, or anything like that... This is an interactive story, and a damn good one at that. The game was short, but I don't see it really being any other way. There are a lot of fine details that really make it great, certain things you'll need to keep your eyes open to really notice.   All in all I'd give it a 8 out of 10. The game itself wasn't anything amazing, but the story it tells needs to be told, and I feel Gone Home does a pretty good job at doing so.

This game really had me on edge until I googled and found out it wasn't, as I feared it might be, a horror game. This might make some people unhappy, but not me. I'm no great lover of jump scares. I don't know if this game will appeal to most, but it's a quiet, difficult story about a teen struggling to find her identity in the mid 90s and the older sister who comes home to find her family has changed dramatically while she was abroad. Or did they? We think we know so much about our own families, but once we start looking for answers, we may quickly find that we now know too much. Good music and atmosphere, and once you mess with the control settings a little, things work well. I recommend turning mouse sensitivity up and turning sticky targeting off. You can race to the finish, but if you do, you'll miss the whole point of the experience. I really enjoyed this game and will never forget it.

It's an interesting ride. The story gets a little hokey and the ending is lackluster, but overall I'd recommend the game (if it's on sale). It's got the feel of a horror game with no actual horror - exploring home with the storm in the background adds to the atmosphere and the creaks of the empty house combined with paranormal elements within the story make you wonder if something exciting is about to happen (it's not). If you're open minded, tend to like story-rich games, and would love to spend several hours clicking on things and throwing them onto the floor, then this game's for you.
This game pierces my heart every time I play it

It took me 2.1 hours, but Gone Home is in the books here in my 1st run-through. Might go give it another some-time, to check out the Commentary - especially since it's so short for an actual game.  So, I really love the 90's atmosphere; the house + its ton of details. I felt like I took a trip back to the mid-90's and got lost into a time-wrap of some kind. Everything is pretty much not nailed down here. So - it can be picked up, locked at, examined, and moved around.  And the way the story unfolds, is just great - whether by narration, from through the actual objects themselves, finding certain areas, solving some puzzles, or whatever the case might be. You basically return to an empty house and you're to find out where everyone is + why you're actually there, as everything feels up close + personal in the first-person experience. I won't go much further than that, as that could actually ruin the experience itself.  Do yourself a favor: don't spent full price on this. I certainly didn't. It's a very, very short game. B/c it is so short - that could be a worthwhile reason to replay it, in case you missed something in the game, want to check the Commentary out, to know the game inside + out, want to re-explore the game, or whatever the case might be.  Compared to most games on the market - Gone Home is a very different + interesting adventure game focused on exploration, loaded with a unique + ordinary 1990's atmosphere for a game that will make people that were alive in the 90's - especially those who were teens or children, during that era - relate to very easily. It will feel like you've....Gone Home, naturally. With the way the story unfolds and the way it's presented to the player - this is a trip definitely worth taking, if you don't spend the farm on such a short game.  But, oh - what a grand, short little game this is!  Final Grade = B.

This game looked like a nice game for a stormy day and a few cups of coffee. It was worth every penny. I spent hours just exploring this house cuddled up in my blanket with my coffee. I felt kind of creepy looking at all the family's stuff at first but the game quickly immersed me into the body of a girl who lived in the house. Now I am a girl.

The tale of lesbians that are into the same music I am into, they are avid players of Street Fighter, and they just seem like cool chicks. There are some other things in the house that you discover as well, but none of them are as cool as the random cassettes you'll find in the house.  I should probably add that I actually enjoyed the game and the ending totally made the game worth playing!
Absolutely fantastic 'game'. Had a great time exploring and experience even when the game was busy full force kicking me in the feels.

Gone Home is one of those games you buy but you never end up playing. But hell, when I did play it, it was a surprisingly beautiful experience. If you like a mix of mystery, hidden objects and a story richness - GET THIS GAME!

Can't say how I feel about this game. There are two conflicting parts in it for me that really make recommending this game hard for me:  THE GOOD: The gameplay is probably one of the greatest representation of how a walking simulator should play. There's a huge mansion to walk around to your heart's content and interact with the objects in every room. The mansion feels lived-in and pretty detailed in all aspects. The graphics aren't TOO realistic but so much thought has been put in little details scattered throughout the house that it felt truly unique and rewarding to explore.   Once you start exploring, you'll come across the story of the empty house and slowly but surely work your way up to the reasons why the house is empty when you arrive from your trip. This leads to the only negative aspect of the game.  THE BAD: I swear I've read better lesbian fan fiction written by my 14-year-old niece than the stuff represented in here. The main character which is the primary focus of the story (who is also the main character's younger sister) is Sam. A punk-rock loving teen rebel who doesn't know the difference between the stains in her panties and the strawberry jam on her toast ....and thinks she's a lesbian because her parents probably didn't give her enough attention and the new highschool she's moved to doesn't regard her as a royal princess.   So she does what most teens do when they feel they're under pressure: going gay (well, to give credit to some of the more creative ones, they could go bisexual).  I don't know if this was a dark cautionary tale written by parents for parents with rebelious teens or by actual horny, shallow teens who want to express the diversity in probably the most woefully controversial and important subjects on the western youth's general mindset: sexuality... because that's the only freedom they feel they have.... I guess? I don't know whether to take the story seriously especially when it turns out to be a faulty, shallow and unexciting romance without a solid basis for a good story.   To be honest, I don't care after Gone Home's ending because I feel exhausted after tagging along with the game which promises mysterious twists and turns and puts me in a very interesting environment for around 3 hours just to keep slapping me left and right with its ovaries and finally unload its full load of estrogen on my face.  On the other hand, if you're into walking simulators or want to experience the interactive bliss which can be achieved through this genre, by all means check Gone Home out. The detailed environments and the general atmosphere was what pulled me towards finishing it.  MARGINAL THUMBS UP  Overrated.

Very different and refreshing experience, it's nice to see games like this in this 'dudebro shooter' dominated market, it really proves that games aren't supposed to be action oriented and targeted to a single type of users.
A fresh breath and a unique twist to gaming as a medium.  New and out-of-the-box thinking should be encouraged, and this is an exciting example!  Highly recommended!
It's more like a novel thing about lesbians with a nice punk rock soundtrack.
More interactive than 99% of the games people play on Steam, somehow not a videogame. Also not sure why the Gamergate jocks hate it so much, but they're borderline ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ anyway.

I can't believe I waited this long to play Gone Home. Sure, I completed it in one evening with some time to spare, but the story has really stuck in my head since. The atmosphere is fantastic -- the house is incredibly spooky and the story behind the house was incredibly intriguing and made even creepier by the rain/thunder/darkness. I was completely enthralled with this game from beginning to end. Don't forget to play all of the tapes you find around, especially the Heavens to Betsy casettes (Corin Tucker of Sleater-Kinney fame's band from early/mid 1990s).  I'm glad to see how much hype Gone Home has received -- it's well worth it and I hope they continue to make games like this. There's so much going on in just a couple hours worth of gameplay, but it comes together so well without forcing every problem to have a solution (much like real life!). Having a strong female AND LGBT lead is such a big deal, I really applaud Fullbright for everything they've done here.

This game isn't what I expected. Actually I am not sure what I expected but it is an interesting game for sure. I thought it was short. It took me about an hour and a half to run through it. I probably missed some things and will most likely play it again to see what I missed. I recommend this game. It is worth a play through.
This game is fantastic, but short. Buy it if it's on sale, as it's not worth $20.
Great indie game, enough 'jumpscares', even some letters had me creeped out :p good story, even while it's a very short one. Definately recommend it!

This isn't really a game, but an interactive story. I had a great time exploring the house and learning as much as I could about its residents. This game wasn't what I expected, but I still enjoyed it.
short and sweet and heartwarming with a great soundtrack. at they end they thank their cats; its my kind of game

Gone Home is a very beautiful story told within a game. The mood is set in a captivating way and the plot is very moving.   Anyone who believes that the ending was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, because there was an 'unexpected 180 turn', should stick to elementary school reading level books, since the greatest part of the narration literally told you where this was going.  Jesus Christ, it wasn't even subtle.   10/10 ♥♥♥♥boys drowned in their tears

Short game with very little replayability BUT the experience was immersive and the story is oddly relateable. I'm not sure I'd consider this anything more than an interactive story though. I personally enjoyed it as some sections of the story actually made me feel sad or even upset. All in all I thought it was very worth playing (if you're into games based solely on walking around finding small clues to reveal parts of the story) $20 seems steep if you ask me so wait for it to go on sale or pick it up in a bundle like I did.
A heartfelt interactive story worth the time. Nicely atmospheric with both touching and quirky details throughout.
One of the most beautiful love story I've ever played. 9/10
A quick and easy coming-of-age game with a creepy atmosphere and an awesome riot grrrl soundtrack. Perfect for a good dose of 90s nostalgia.
I just sat down and played this game in one sitting and I am so glad I did. It's such a wonderful story! Definitely recommend it!

The house is deserted! And it's dark! And the lights are flickering! And the owner died under mysterious circumstances! And where is everybody? And it's lightning storm outside! What secrets will the locked basement hold? What jumps scared await behind another door? The tension is almost palpable! Oh the humanity< you've got to try it youve got to it will shake you to the core the cia and kgb and kennedy and the forest fire and lonnie sam why oh why so alon so alon--
Gripping. The atmosphere this game creates is palpable. Goosebumps felt throughout. Highly recommend.

Rain and thunders are the only guests at your 'welcome back party'. In a perfect 'American horror story' setting, your new house is the only place you'll explore.  Searching for the fate of your parents, and your sister, developers decided to haunt you with a not-so-placid-environment. And the BIG surprise is just behind the corner in this interactive narrative adventure. (Is it really?)  9/10
Gone Home is an excelent experience telling a beautiful narrative.
An interactive and thought-provoking story. Beautiful!

I had been following Gone Home during its development awaiting its release, and this is one of the games I can say didn't disappoint. If you're looking to play this for the gameplay alone, don't; you'd be missing out on so much if you treated this as a game you'd merely speedrun. This is a game that should be played thoroughly and savored for it's cute and enjoyable storyline.

Let me begin by making a few things very clear;  This isn't really a game, it's more a piece of Interactive Fiction such as Dear Esther or if you're old enough to remember them, the classic Infocom text adventure games of the 80s. Most of the game is spent exploring, reading many notes left behind and listening to a narrative which is triggered by finding certain items scattered throughout the home. There's no jumping, fighting, or really any action sequences at all.   Secondly, this isn't a horror story. It can feel creepy at times. There were a several instances where I felt as if I was being watched as I wandered through the home and a few times I expected to turn around to find someone or something behind me, but that never happened. The only scares in this game come from incorrect expectations going in or the ones that a person may create themselves if they're spooked out by being alone in a large home alone at night.   Lastly, this is a somewhat short game. I just finished 'playing' it for the first time and it took be about three hours total. There isn't a whole lot of replay value since neither the story or surroundings change but you may come across a few items here and there that you may have missed the first time around. On the other hand, I'm sure that those who loved this game will no doubt play it through many times.   I'm not going to spoil any details about the story itself since the story is really what the entire experience is all about but if you go in aware of the information above and an open mind you'll probably enjoy the experience.

Rain and thunders are the only guests at your 'welcome back party'. In a perfect 'American horror story' setting, your new house is the only place you'll explore.  Searching for the fate of your parents, and your sister, developers decided to haunt you with a not-so-placid-environment. And the BIG surprise is just behind the corner in this interactive narrative adventure. (Is it really?)  9/10
It's a great story and a nice alternative from violent games if you're looking to mellow out for an hour or two.

For the time it takes to complete (around 2 hours), it's not worth 20$, but at 10$ or lower, it might be ok. This is more of an interactive story than a game per say. There is no combat, no puzzles, no conversations. You basically explore the big house of your family in 1995 that seemingly seems abandonned. There's a storm outside, all the lights are turned off. Gameplay consists mostly of turning on those lights, opening whatever can be opened (drawers, cabinets, etc), picking up stuff to examine it (3d object you can move) and reading various writings. It seems boring, but it isn't really. It's all done through a decent-looking first-person 3d engine.  The fact it's dark until you find the switch in each room, the storm raging, outside and the weird, yet could be normal, sounds of the old house makes for a creepy experience. I was even kind of scared by moments, but it's not an horror game per say. The story is told through writings and from 'audio' diaries by your younger sister popping up from time to time. Those are acted very convincingly and even though the game is short, you'll learn to like her and care about her potential fate. Overall, it felt like breaking, entering and exploring a 1995 house. It's atmospheric and a very good story told indirectly.

Gone Home is all about story telling, but does so in a engaging and clever way. Fans of 'The Room' will love this game, as well as fans of Tell Tell Games for their unique story telling naritives. Gone Home has some of the most unique stylistic art that i've seen in a long time. It constantly reminds the player the struggles teens have growing up and dealing with their emotions. The story is so good, it will make you reflect on your own life and make you question a lot of the decisions you've made over your lifetime. It also gives you insight on how it would feel like to raise teenage girls, if you've never had the pleasure :)  Overall i would give it a 9/10

Gone Home is an experience unlike anything else that I've ever played. The story of the game is emotionally driven by terrifc voice acting and story telling and really needs to be played to be believed. I reccomend this for anyone who is searching for more than a mindless shooter and dive into Gone Home as it's something that's hard to forget.

Got $5? Then you have a game with an ending you have never experienced before. At 5$ this game is an absolute steal. Without giving any spoliers... Would you like to experience human emotion at it's finest. Then spend the money an enjoy 3 hours of exploring your emotions and your soul.

this game is amazing. It's a short game but the story you are following is so good and emotional. for some reason i expected a jumpscare but luckely it did not have any of those.  if you want an nice interactive story go play this.
This made me have feelings
This made me have feelings
really fun walking sim and the tension this game delivers is enjoyable but only for a single playthrough.

I was born in 1992 and i'm a straight male  Its a short game, but a neat story  Only problem is I felt like I was too young, the wrong gender and wrong sexual orentation!  Not worth 20bux though, hardly worth less than 5

An emotionally haunting experience. Sit down and complete in one playthough and you will not be sorry. Makes you feel fear, despair and hope all at once....This game will stay with your for a long time. This is an excellent piece of art that could only be achieved through this medium. Do not second guess....PLAY IT, EXPERIENCE IT.

PROS Moving story about family. Short enough to play on a few lunch breaks. (3hrs) Satisfying ending. Invokes feelings of voyeurism that few games have captured.  CONS If you're looking for a game, look elsewhere. This is an interactive short story, nothing more. The price will be too high for most, buy it on sale to avoid buyer's remorse.
This game made me cry. 10/10. Genuinely.  (It's kinda short for £15 so get it on sale, but it's one of the most beautiful things in the genre)

So, I (correctly) guessed what the ending of the story would be within the first five minutes. And that might sound damning, but the fact that it still had me crying by the end of it means that it was obviously doing something right. Mostly what it's doing right in my opinion is actually telling a straight forward, emotional story, which is actually pretty refreshing in an industry that keeps trying to lunge for meta-narratives (Bioshock: Infinite, Hotline: Miami, etc.) when it's barely got past any kind of story that doesn't involve a giant alien exploding at the end.  But let's discuss the big thing, length. The length of this game is perfect for what it's design, but probably not for it's price tag. Okay, be honest, definitely not for the price tag. See, Gone Home is clearly designed to be completed in one sitting, and as such the roughly 90 minute play-time is perfect. But, obviously, $20 (£15 for UK residents) is quite a lot of money for an hour and-a-half worth of entertainment. So it just comes down to getting it on sale if that doesn't sound like it's worth it, because that's what Steam is for. :P
One of the best games that i have played this year by far, a game where you just want to play it to find out more of the story line. trust me on this one its worth every cent !!!  10/10
YouTube™ Video:  NME Plays Gone Home | part 1 | Welcome Home!

Gone Home   is a great game if you enjoy playing detective and drawing links. It's a game to play if you love 'working for the story'. Most of the story are hidden in documents, rooms and items - therefore the characters psychology is up to your own interpretation as well. It's not a scary game, but because of the good use of sound - we find ourselves turning our heads (in the game) many times.   Here's our   full analysis   (click only if you've played the game or want to watch it)

Summary: A great game of exploration, ruined by a story that's simply read to you.  There's a thrill when you find a small detail that opens up a whole new dimension in the character's story. Somehow, when you discover it on your own, it stays with you. The story of the dad steals the show. You never hear him talk, but through the little post-it notes, and the contents of the boxes, and the little pieces of litter he leaves, his story really stays with you.  But instead, the focus of the game is on Sam (the sister), and instead of uncovering the clues to tell you her story, the game pretty much narrates it to you. Sam's story, while well written, is hardly groundbreaking, and in the end forgettable. With such a focus on the narration, the game loses focus - it's hardly much different than any other game out there.  There's elements of brilliance in this game, but it's hampered by what is effecitvely a reading of a book. I hope the developer tries it again. And if they happen to be reading this, I hope they realize, they can do better.
This 'interactive story' is super human and super nice. I am a huge fan of it and I think it's amazing. I was tearing up.

This game isn't exactly what I expected it to be, But I don't mean that in a bad way. This game overall was charming and had a compelling story I wanted to hear more of. More than once this game reminded me of my own life and my family, Certain things just brought back reminders of my childhood and my adolescent years. Graphically this game is pleasing and the consistent use of the audio really adds another layer of immersion into this place.  The game isn't exciting and there won't be any real action, This game plays more like a movie rather than a game. So unless you enjoy all story line and not much else this game really won't be for you. On another note, Where I personally enjoyed this game and will probably play it again. It didn't even take a full 3 hours to complete and if you aren't stopping to look at every single thing then the gameplay time could be easily cut in half. I also don't feel this game was worth it's price and if you're really interested in getting it, Maybe wait for a price drop or a sale.
Overrated? Sure. Does it ruin your day for being barely a game? No. Its an interactive experience, The story is alright but the red herrings end up being what they are, which is a waste of time.

Gone Home is almost all story and atmosphere and no gameplay, and that is totally fine. It's an entertaining couple of hours of exploring a house and figuring out what has happened to the protagonist's family, both during her now-finished year abroad and before that as well. Teen issues, love, writer's cramp and relationships are all themes that feature prominently in this game. From the minute you arrive on the doorstep and notice that the entire family is missing you'll be intrigued and rush around looking for clues. It's a bit like Myst albeit with near-to-none puzzles.  I wouldn't recommend buying it at its default price unless you really want to increase the demand for storydriven indie games. Get it at a discount, play it once with normal settings, once with commentary, reflect on it and move on.

I don't often post reviews. I heard about this game a couple years ago, and it sounded interesting, but I never got around to buying it. When it was on sale on Steam, I finally decided to buy it. What a great experience. I wish I had bought it earlier, and I wish I had paid more for it. Sure, it's not replayable like a strategy game, and it's not a typical adventure game either, but that's why I liked it. I took my time and tried to explore as much as I could, and it delivered. Fortunately I had only heard a hint of the storyline, so I wasn't completely spoiled and was able to enjoy the whole journey.
4.5* Good but too short
Very engaging and moving story and I loved the 90s setting. I'd love to see more from the devs, this game was awesome! I highly recommend it!

I went into this game with little to no expectations or knowledge of what it really is, except for a reccomendation by a friend. I have never played a game that was such a clear reflection of myself, and that was truly understandable. There are a huge amount of bad reviews recently concerning this game, and I think it's really necessary to be open-minded to the game's quirky way of telling its story. In my opinion, discovering the story while exploring the house in which it took place could not have been better. This game is a true love story, reccomended to ayone.
Awesome story-telling!
I liked exploring the house. Amusing for a couple of hours. Would recommend getting Gone Home on sale.

Really liked this game. Some may argue this is not really a game, with very few interactions apart reading a lot. True. But Gone Home is more than that: a combination of oppressing atmosphere with credible cultural references (Hello 90's!), the curiosity to understand the situation we are put in, and the pieces of the puzzle adding together trough the journey in this mansion to reveal family secrets.  Some comment I read (don't remember who, sorry for the owner) qualified Gone Home this way: 'this would have made a terrible movie, or an uninteresting book. But as a game, it shows the potential that the gaming industry can propose a very unique way of telling things.'  You got it.

Slow-burning and intriguing, Gone Home is a real breath of fresh air. Few games have such an emotional impact and that such impact is generated by such simplicity is truly impressive. Atmospheric, fascinating and at times truly creepy, this game makes you care about its characters so effortlessly that when its over you can feel its absence. Short for the cost, yes, but possessed with an intensity few triple A titles can match. A brilliant, perfect little gem.

I found this game amazing. The story was so immersive. I don't even know how long I spent on it, but the story and the characters were amazingly developed with so little interaction. It manages to put so much detail into such a small amount of time and space, and without needing any background knowledge of the characters involved. I was captivated the entire time I played.  The game does feel more like an interactive movie than a regular adventure game. I went in with no expectations, and was completely blown away.

Gone Home is a little hard to explain, it doesn't follow traditional interactive gaming formulas (puzzle solving etc.). Instead it offers emotional experience in the form of interactive storytelling. There are no real actions to be taken, you're not going to lose, you're simply a witness to the story that is unfolding. I'ts a vicarious experience that at times can be eerie/mysterious/light hearted/empathetic/innocent.  Gone Home isn't particularly long, and for a $20 price tag, it is fairly steep. If you're into emotional storytelling/Interactive Art Pieces with games such as Heavy Rain/Dear Esther/Journey/SoTC you'd probably enjoy it. Again, I'd recommend it, but not really for $20, unless you consider yourself a die hard for this genre, I'd wait until it goes on sale.

Somehow, when you discover it on your own, it stays with you. The story of the dad steals the show. You never hear him talk, but through the little post-it notes, and the contents of the boxes, and the little pieces of litter he leaves, his story really stays with you.  But instead, the focus of the game is on Sam (the sister), and instead of uncovering the clues to tell you her story, the game pretty much narrates it to you. Sam's story, while well written, is hardly groundbreaking, and in the end forgettable. With such a focus on the narration, the game loses focus - it's hardly much different than any other game out there.  There's elements of brilliance in this game, but it's hampered by what is effecitvely a reading of a book. I hope the developer tries it again. And if they happen to be reading this, I hope they realize, they can do better.
Imagine this game is about Max and Chloe and it becomes so much better.
Beautiful, atmospheric, creepy, heartwarming - This game is brilliant, if a little short
Awesome story

Deeply designed and well thought out. Love it or hate it, but you do have to commend the devs for nailing an atmosphere and era necessary for this type of story that is surprisingly reflective. BUT only buy it on sale. While there was obviously a lot of time and detail put into the enviroments, it is pretty expensive for the amount of content you get.
Simply beautiful.

Slow-burning and intriguing, Gone Home is a real breath of fresh air. Few games have such an emotional impact and that such impact is generated by such simplicity is truly impressive. Atmospheric, fascinating and at times truly creepy, this game makes you care about its characters so effortlessly that when its over you can feel its absence. Short for the cost, yes, but possessed with an intensity few triple A titles can match. A brilliant, perfect little gem.
A brilliant example of how games are a great way of telling stories, and evidence that games can be about normal life as well as the fantastical.
Most fun on your first playthrough, but just as fun to share with a friend while you watch them.
FANTASTIC interactive story. Short, and very sweet. I think you might have to be a bit older to really appreciate the underlying significance of the story, though.

According to Steam I took a mere 1.9 hours to play the game through, and I'm not sure I'd play it a second time.  With that said the game really drew me in, and while I guessed at the probable ending early on, that doesn't stop it from being a well told story, with a number of twists and turns, which does really well at keeping tension running.

One of the most touching, heartfelt and moving games in ages. No combat, no NPCs, and no skill trees, just the slow uncovering of a family in the 90's story, the instability and the begining of a new era of acceptance. Gone Home touches you in a way that not many other games can say they do. Its a unique experience that everyone should at least watch a playthrough of, without commentary, that would ruin the personal value the game has. If you are looking for a change from the normal kill monsters, complete quests, solve puzzle, uncover backstory, etc. and just want a simple story of self-discovery and bravado then Gone Home is the perfect, calling it a game may not even be doing it justice, experience you can buy.
...speechless... Best 'game' I have played in a LONG time. Well done!
Short; and not technically a 'game'. Not much to do other than look at objects and read notes. Nice little lesbian love story though!
This game is amazing. I completely lost myself in the story and loved every minute of gameplay.

Gone Home is a surprisingly good game for one that has basically none of the traditional game elements. There are no puzzles (other than rooting around looking for hidden gems), no monsters and no direct interaction with others.  I guess it's best described as an interactive story about Sam, the sister of Katie (whose perspective you take on). By the end of the game I felt like I had gotten to know Sam quite well. The voice acting was good, and the story interesting enough that I wanted to see it through to the end.  (My pregnant wife would like me to add that watching me play the game made her feel very dizzy. This may or may not improve the game in your estimation.)  I'd say the game was definitely worth the price (free for me!), but I'd say it would be worth buying on special. At 3h of gameplay it's a bit short for $20 in my opinion.

Oh what a great game this is! You explore a house and try to discover why no one's there. The premise is MUCH weaker than the story turns out to be. Stay with it for the story, it is wonderful. I actually cried here and there. I think this is the only game that has made me cry. If you are all about the action!, action!, action! than this is not the game for you. However, if you are mature enough to love a proper story told well, buy this now!!
Gone Home wasn't what I expected, but much like everything else in life, the presence of lesbians eased my pain. What an unusual little title.
