Worth every penny! The story is fantastic. Sometimes is creepy and scary, sometimes its funny, and other times it sad and touching. One of my favorite indie games.
Absolutely Loves it. 10/10!

Gone Home is more of an interactive novella, than a (conventional) video game. It urges the player to engage with and become a part of the Greenbriar family's life. The player is placed in a visually unexceptional, but thematically rich domain. As the player becomes immersed in their surroundings they engage with themes surrounding the third wave feminist movement of the 1990s, homosexuality, religion, adultery and writer's block. In the space of an hour (or two), the player has become invested in the live's of the Greenbriar family, akin to the empathy a reader will feel with the characters of a well-loved book. There is no great difficulty in this game, and no skill required - however an investigative and quizzical disposition is a must. While there are many reviewers in the steam community who have been sorely disappointed by promises that Gone Home is 'the game of the year' - the game will not disappoint those who are open to story-driven gameplay that involves no interaction with other characters. This game goes well and truly beyond its mark when considering the depth and detail it has devoted to providing a nuanced landscape that is coloured only by its relation to the importance of particular items, written material and sound devices. The attention to these details in Gone Home should inspire other progressive game developers to enhance the role of story in their own video games.

While this game is short the amount of care that went into creating the enviroment is really amazing. Even though you have the time to search the house at your leisure the story elements are set to keep you going at a faster pace. There's so much to interact with as well. Gone Home was a lot of fun and even though I've completed the main storyline I look forward to looking around a bit more to see if there are any smaller details I may have missed.

DO NOT EXPECT ANYTHING LIKE SURVIVAL HORROR.   This is an interesting game, but I do find it disappointing that it was touted as supernatural thriller.   I'm not certain why there's an inventory, as it is barely used.   If you like point and click adventure, you might like this. I'd wait for it to go on sale, though.

This is an awesome game. I loved it. However, I didn't spend 20 dollars on it, I spent 3 dollars. The game takes about 2 hours to complete, so you're paying 10 dollars an hour for the game if you buy it at full price. Add it to your wishlist, buy it when it's on sale.

Fantastic, original, and heartfelt. A wonderful game with a story and atmosphere that'll keep you wondering just what's around the next corner, in the next room. It's short, but it doesn't need to be any longer.

Like most people, I was NOT expecting what I got. What I got was something far more beautiful. I played straight to the end without pause.  This is an immersive storybook more than a game. This is a game for book readers that wish to be a character in this story. It differs greatly from To The Moon in a very important way though. While To The Moon was so 100% storyline that the game play was actually very token and, I felt sometimes just an out-of-place (and annoying) interruption to the terrific story, Gone home works far more seamlessly than that. FAR more seamlessly. I was a character in the story, not a third party watching the story. This is a very sucessful immersive book.  I'm very glad it ended up being different than what I expected. In a way it was what I was looking for though. I was looking for an emotional experience, and I think the emotions were stronger for not being the emotions I was expecting to experience.  I'd like to see a lot more surprises like this.
One of the most realistic and most saddest games I've ever played in my life. Such a beautiful masterpiece!

I loved Gone Home. It was a relaxing expirence that really hit home with me. The story is well thought out and even though you dont know the charecters, in the short time you have with them you can really connect. It had amazing attention to detail and over all is an amazing story.

I thoroughly enjoyed this experience. Very reminiscent of my old point-and-click adventure days. I especially liked the way the story was presented, through diary entries, photos, notes and scraps of paper, and so on, instead of 'hey, let's do some more exposition while the player sits and cant' do anything', which seems to be all the rage these days. The price is a little too high, though; I'd buy it for no more than $10USD.
Not really a game as such, more an interactive story.  But what a story!   5/5
Wow, just try it, really, very good, difficult to describe it without giving too much away!
Just awesome!
Pretty darn good storytelling here.

Went into this game without really knowing anything about it or what to expect, and came out in awe. Beautiful story telling through beautiful characters. It's not a conventional game, but more a work of art; and while being relatively short, still left a great impression on me. Definitely recommend this to anyone who wants a great narrative experience.

It is a little drawn out for a story telling game - but I thought it was good. Some points I thought I was about to be playing a horror game, but that never happened. A good story telling game if you're into story telling type games.  It is an easy game to beat though. If you are not interested at looking at everything like I did you could beat this game in under 30 minutes.

Not what you expect. The atmosphere is filled with spookiness. The feeling of being in a big house on your own. Sometimes you just want to get to the end as fast as possible that you don't bother listening to the story. It has some replay value but not much. Not a bad 3 hours spent playing.
Amazing story!! I could spend hours just looking for more to it!

This game is one of the best experiences I've had with PC gaming, or even gaming in general. A fantastically told story, deeply emotional, not to mention the detail with the hand-written notes, and custom-made game cartridge art for the game is just brilliant.  It might not be for everyone, since there is no combat, it's simply a game of exploration within a home, but I think that's perfectly fine. This isn't a game about combat or conflict, it's about discovery.  It is short, too, but I think that's good too. It means that the narrative that you discover and experience isn't dragged on unnecessarily. Some might complete it faster than others, but I found that I didn't want to. I wanted to just look in every nook and cranny, and piece together the lives of the people that lived inside the home, to pick up on the elements of their lives that they kept hidden from each other.  I can't guarantee you'll like it, but I think everyone should at least play through it, just to experience something like it.

Gone Home is a first person story. Those who have given this title a bad review were probably looking for a computer game. If you want fast-paced, adrenalin-fueled gameplay, look elsewhere. You won't kill anything in Going Home. You won't jump from platform to platform or sprint through timed doorways. In fact you don't have a jump button, or sprint button for that matter. Your reflexes won't be tested here, though a keen eye might serve you well.   Only buy Going Home if you feel like experiencing a delicately woven story. There are so many subtle nuances scattered amongst the many discarded pages of novels, crumpled up love letters and angrily scribbled notes. This is a story about growing up. It's about finding out who you are. And it's about families - warm and loving families - cold and distant families.   Going Home is short. A couple of hours, maybe three. I recommend you take your time. Piece together the story of the Greenbriars, like a detective gathering clues. Each character has an arc.   I recommend Going Home, as long as you don't expect it to be something that it's not. I hope you like it as much as I did.

An amazing adventure of exploration and story telling. Filled with nostalgia and a deftly detailed and well woven story that anyone who is, or has been a teen can relate too. I caught it on sale for 7.99 and it's easily the best 8 bucks I have spent in a very long time. I can't recommend this game enough.

Oh what a great game this is! You explore a house and try to discover why no one's there. The premise is MUCH weaker than the story turns out to be. Stay with it for the story, it is wonderful. I actually cried here and there. I think this is the only game that has made me cry. If you are all about the action!, action!, action! than this is not the game for you. However, if you are mature enough to love a proper story told well, buy this now!!

The game was fun and interesting until the very end when you find out what happened. Finding out the truth didn't feel that rewarding. I guess I didn't mind too much since I only paid like $2 for it, but it's probably not a game you want to pay the full price for. Also it's very short, I spent a decent amount of time exploring, and still managed to wrap up the main story in an hour and a half.   I'm only going to recommend this game ONLY if it is on sale big time.

This game is seriously amazing. It's short and won't take you too long to beat but the atmosphere is phenomenal and the emotional payoff from the ending is spot on. Not the typical action adventure type that i go for but this game is more about the story line and that storyline is flawless. Playing it feels alot the same as playing Staley's Parable so if you weren't a fan of that one then this might be for you but if you have any interest in that game type at all PLAY THIS GAME!!!
short, simple, more story than game ,,
This game is completely engrossing!

Where do I start? This is probably the most unique 'game' I've ever played. It's more of an interactive movie than anything. I believe I've found everything I could find, and I feel like I know the characters so well now. If you have an hour or two to kill, I'd defenitely recommend this. The whole time, I was expecting this to be a horror game but it's not at all. There's not much replay value, but if you get it on sale, it's definitely worth it.

*Spoiler Free!* Ok so you're thinking about buying and playing 'Gone Home' but aren't sure what type of game it is or how much you're going to like it. I went ahead and got it based off of some professional reviews I read and I have come to the conclusion that it was more of an 'experience' than it was an actual 'game.' The play time is roughly 2 hours, so it's extremely short... don't expect more than that or you'll be disappointed. As far as the actual gameplay goes, though, it's extremely immersive. The game does a perfect job of leading you down the right path as it's very linear. You aren't left wandering about or confused about where to go next. This isn't really as 'interactive' as I was expecting and there are little to no puzzles to be had other than a couple combination locks to figure out (which are easy). Basically what it comes down to is panning around the interior of a an extremely large house and snooping into a family's business. You pick up and examine various objects and in doing so, you discover the secrets of your own family.  The atmosphere is very alluring, spooky, and I will admit - I jumped a few times. Overall, I loved it.. the story was relatable and as I said before it's very immersive. I would recommend this game, though if you can catch it for less than retail, do so. If I would have paid full price, I would have been slightly disappointed in the AMOUNT of playtime I received for retail price. I happened to catch it on sale on the Humble Bundle store, so check there!

All my favorite games have a strong story. This one is no exception. The ambiance of a dark, stormy night where your character is exploring her family's new home to discover what has happened while she's been away keeps you on the edge of your seat. What makes it even better is the payoff at the end.

Beautiful game. It will require from the player to really, really crouch everywhere and look for hidden parts of a journal which will provide pieces of the background and the story. It is well written, and you end up loving the characters. Tha ambiance is fantastic, and overall it is a great experience if you like the exploration kind of gameplay, to find hidden stuff etc.  Although different, it reminded me of Dear Esther.
An excellent visual novel/interactive fiction. I had no idea where the story was going until right near the end, and it left me a little emotional.
One of the most realistic and most saddest games I've ever played in my life. Such a beautiful masterpiece!
Worth buying in a sale!

I enjoyed this game a lot. It felt a little short but the story was great. I would definitely reccomend this game to anyone that likes first person adventure mystery games. I hope there is more coming from this developer.

NOTE: There is a full on campaign of people downvoting positive reviews for this game, and it may be some sort of ultrachristian agenda due to the game containing controversial lesbian content. You can safely ignore the negative reviews.   - Take the freedom to interact with almost anything, like Shenmue (from the Dreamcast). Not even Quantic Dream bothers to be quite this thorough with interactivity. It is a worthy novelty and takes dedication to pull it off to this extent.  - Combine that with the eerie mansion exploration mystery of the 7th Guest.  - Add a rich population of cultural perephernalia, hidden items and somewhat believable clutter all over the house to bring a story to life, strung together by diaries and conversational notes not unlike the scribbles on the walls in Left 4 Dead.    The floorplan of the house is pretty interesting and they did a great job of making you feel that you're really rummaging through someone's life in constant suspense. Everything was pulled off at a decent quality and there was never really anything jarringly out of place.  Though the game only has one ending, depending on how comprehensive and contemplative you were about your discoveries you may have very different theories or perspectives on what really happened.  It's unlikely to blow your mind either way, but it's a very short game that only takes 3-4 hours to complete if you read everything and search everywhere thoroughly, so there's no need to rush yourself. Take the time and get the most out of it.  They did such a great job bringing the house to life that I have no regrets about the overall experience.

If you get past the rediculous price, this game is pretty cool. There's not branching stories, or much gameplay, but there is a story. The story is worth expierencing, but the game's only 2 or 3 hours long. If you're considering buying it, consider this: How much would you spend for a good movie.

While the pricetag is a little steep for the amount of content provided - it is an incredibly short game; it took me a small handful of hours at most to complete - the story more than amply solidifies this as one of the best purchases I have made on Steam yet. The tale is gripping, and the pacing is relaxed - there are no monsters, no interactable characters, so if you are looking for a challenge or a fight, Gone Home is not the game for you. If, however, you are in the market for a truly unforgettable story and you happen to catch this title on sale (snagged it during the Summer Sale for 66% off!), I cannot recommend this more highly. It is proof positive of the concept of games as art. 10/10

I went into this game thinking I would hate it, as I usually do when something on the internet gets so much praise, but it was actually pretty refreshing. Not necessarily a 'game', but still engaging.
truly an emotional story

♥♥♥♥ing beautiful - and the riot grrrl based soundtrack is on point. Definitely not a game for everyone, but if you enjoy exploration-heavy games, this is probably your type of game. it gives you the creeps sometimes (pick up the crucifix in the basement, just ♥♥♥♥ing DO IT) without actually being a horror game, and that's pretty cool if you ask me.   Again, definitely not a game for everyone, but I recommend it nonetheless.

This game has to have one of the greatest stories I've ever seen. Though on the outside it seems like a fairly simple game of finding out where your sister went, deep down it's so much more. Walking through the house finding the missing pieces of the puzzle was fun and the story that unfolded was beautiful. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a game that will make them feel all kinds of feels.

A lovely experience in being a part of this family and finding out about the people they've become while 'I' was away -- the game will become as personal as you let it become. Take your time, look at everything, explore, and let yourself become immersed in this little family.  Beautiful, haunting, and heart-breaking at times. Thoroughly recommended for anyone who likes a story told well.  And oh thank God it's finally a game that has a specifically female protagonist and many specifically female stories.
Touching, memorable, nostalgic and emotional. A gripping experience that begs to be explored, and rewards you for it.
very short, but cool nevertheless.
Buy It.

Gone Home was a pleasant experience, with some well-realized characters. I recommend playing it when you want a break from the standard shooting/platforming fare and want to play something simple and relaxing, with a touching story.   Note that the gameplay consists of you just exploring your house and listening to audio diaries, and slowly uncovering a story (in a non-linear way). I don't mind games like this, but it seems to be an issue for many other players.

There's a lot of talk about the cost of this game in the reviews section of this site. It seems that such users are using the age old criteria of equating the possible play hours in a game with its worth. The value of this game, of which there is a plentiful amount, reveals itself at a wonderful pace during the 2-3 hours it may take to reach the story's end. The amazing sense of humanity in the game's world is strengthened by its temporary nature; the game's story exists in one evening and as such I find it appropriate that it can be completed in one evening. There is no glitz and glam, DLC gaps, hinted sequels or tacked on multiplayer. This is a game designed for an evening alone at home with a pair of headphones. I don't want to talk about the story to a huge extent: I'd rather note how the game's wonderful narrative mechanisms made for a far more consuming and involving process of play than I have experienced with any recent high budget 'story driven' games. The soundtrack never quite feels nostaliga-exploitative though I can't help but feel that this game is perhaps for a certain generation; the generation on the border of a digitisation of life itself. We who sit at our laptops now, but in flipping from Side A to Side B of the cassette in Gone Home are brought back to that sense of unknowing and possibility. Gone Home's setting echoes this sense, a truly explorable place for once, and albeit linear you always feel like the record button is pushed down right alongside the play one.
If you pick this up on a sale it really can be quite good, although the puzzles are simplistic the concept is good and you can see how this can be applied to a bigger game.
It is a good, but short game. It´s like 1 hour long. So dont buy it for 20£, buy it when it´s on sale or in a Humble Bundle. 7/10

A beautiful story that flows well from beginning to end and is just the right length. Some narrative games can leave you hunting for the next story piece which breaks the atmosphere and pacing but this one provided enough of a path without big glowing signs. I may have had watery eyes by the end.
Nice game. This game is good but can get REALLY boring at times. Intresting story and really only enjoyable if you play the whole game in one-two days.

“Gone Home” is definitely one of the best indie games of 2013. Once you enter in that home, you will find yourself in an extremely immersive place, which seems to be inhabited by real and believable people. Your surroundings seem to be alive and in every corner you will find something interesting to look at. And as you look into those details you will unfold an outstanding story that puts you right back into the 90s. Some people may complain about how short can it be, but those two hours I spent in that house were fulfilled with a kind of narrative that you rarely see in games.  You must play if: - you like games with an artistically approach;  - you like a touching and human narrative; - you do not care about a short experience and simple gameplay mechanics. _________________________________________________  “Gone Home” é, definitivamente, um dos melhores jogos indies de 2013. A partir do momento em que você entrar nessa casa, você se encontrará em um local extremamente imersivo, que parece ser habitado por pessoas reais e críveis. O ambiente que te cerca parece estar vivo e em cada canto você encontrará algo interessante para vislumbrar. Na medida em que você observa esses detalhes, você revelará uma história marcante que te levará de volta aos anos 90. Algumas pessoas podem se incomodar com sua curta duração, mas as duas horas que eu passei naquela casa foram preenchidas com um tipo de narrativa que raramente é vista nos jogos.  Você deve jogar se: - você gostar de jogos com uma abordagem mais artística; - você apreciar uma narrativa tocante e humana; - você não se importar com uma experiência curta e mecânicas de jogo simples.

This game is a real masterpiece in the way it explores telling narrative. The devs have put you into a character and you learn everything about the game/story through her eyes, but it really goes beyond that. As much as I loved Mass Effect, The Last of Us, and Bioshock, I never really felt like I was taking on that character, like I wasn't ever actually that character, just an invisible god making arbitrary decisions to see what would happen or where I wanted this character to end up. I wanted to see these characters react to certain situations I put them it, but this game is different. This game is all about me as the character. I'm putting myself in situations, not some character that always knows what to do or to say. Instead of making decisions for the character, I was making choices for myself. Never has a game actually put you into the shoes of a character where you really feel like you are this young woman unravelling the mystery as to what has happened to your family. Male or female, straight or gay, you really come to be this young woman. You feel attachment to your sister in such a profound way it’s emotionally draining. I can't recommend this game enough. This was such an amazing experience and a breath of fresh air amidst all these 'AAA Blockbusters'. This game is worth the money, but don't be looking for a time sink. This game is relatively short, but so good that it really doesn't matter. Quality always and forever over Quantity.

Gone Home is a game about storytelling, which is to say it's not so much about the destination as the journey. As I experienced the development of characters' relationships, and saw some of the hidden dynamics in this family's 'stuff,' I became emotionally invested in how things would play out. Not only that, but thanks to the writing, the excellent voice acting, and the authentic feel of the various bits laying about the house, I was able to get inside the headspace of the central character in a way that's seldom done. Indeed, it evoked the emotional experience of young love like I've never felt from any other piece of media; somehow, they absolutely nailed it, and that's very difficult. It was a great way to frame the story, one that isn't common in games, and I absolutely felt it was worth my time. It also reminded me of the value of my own family, in the wake of the experience I'd just witnessed.  I know a lot of people will balk at the price, given the approximate two-hour time to completion, but I've always found the dollar-per-hour ratio we use to value games a bit bizarre. Lots of games are too bloated, and don't respect our time, so when a game accomplishes what it needs to in two hours and then lets you move on, I think that's worthy of celebration, not condemnation. While we may have certain expectations from our past history, the medium is changing, and so is the typical gamer. With many of us now having more money than time, I think there's absolutely room for a well-executed, 'premium' experience that is short on time but long on value.  I believe this is a game that's absolutely worth that perceived 'premium' price. Fullbright, who previously were part of the Minerva's Den team at 2K Marin, have shown that they're adept at telling affecting, personal stories in this medium, and I'm interested to see what they do next.

ONLY buy this game if:  You have an imagination You have empathy You enjoy beauty You like reading You like contemplating You like taking time to explore The game is on sale (Optional) You love the 90's  If all the above is true-- you will LOVE this game.

A surprising, heartfelt game that kicks you right in the feels the whole way through. An incredible experience in a genre of gaming that is very hard to get right. One of the best stories that is delivered in such an immersive style of play. Buy this game!!!
A total masterpiece. Thanks.
Gone Home is a thrilling game that keep you in suspence till you finally find out the truth.

I was intrigued by the description of this game, and decided to buy it and dive in late on a Saturday night. I couldn't have hoped for a better experience! It's strange that such a simple idea hasn't been done before (to my knowledge). You're simply exploring a house and piecing together the story of your family while you've been away for a year. Once I got going, I just couldn't stop until it was over. And it was over pretty soon -- after four hours -- but I don't regret for one moment paying $5 per hour (besides, I will be playing through again once I've forgotten enough). The thought occurred to me in the middle of playing: 'this is why I love video games.'

No violence, just smooth and easy to play. No puzzles that I got stuck on. Incredible atmosphere. Top notch voice acting. Excellent narrative, moments like the ah-ha moment in Bioshock are hidden in here.  Non-linear, yet still presented in a way that lets the player flow through the game. Excellent game design.

No violence, just smooth and easy to play. No puzzles that I got stuck on. Incredible atmosphere. Top notch voice acting. Excellent narrative, moments like the ah-ha moment in Bioshock are hidden in here.  Non-linear, yet still presented in a way that lets the player flow through the game. Excellent game design.
A beautiful heartwarming story. Although it only takes a short time to complete, you really learn the characters as if they are your own family. I didn't want this game to end.

I really liked this game. Very different. Telling the story with a few cassete tape diaries left behind by your characters little sister, and household items. Has some light puzzles, and gives you a creepy vibe.

This game has an AMAZING story, I really would recommend playing. I got it because the reviews were high for an Indie game and the story just caught me and I had to play and play to find out where this would end 8/10 Would recommend. Oh and did I say this is based in Oregon too :D ?

People who bought this for full price because of media hype have little but themselves to blame. Like most games, it's not worth the full price.  It was a fun narrative in a good atmosphere, the ending was underwhelming to me, but it was otherwise worth the nicely discounted price. People need to get off their ♥♥♥♥horses and pretending they're cool for hating this game, which is definitely pretentious, but in a sorta naive way, not 'Har har they're pretending to be so edgy with the homos' mockingly so.  6 outta 10, not a horrible time.

This is a fantastic first person exploration game. If walking around in house, inspecting objects, and piecing together a story is not something you enjoy, don't buy it. It'll still be here for the rest of us. One of my weird things I like in certain games are 'clutter' ie objects that make a world feel 'lived in'. Not many games get it right for me. Gone Home does a brilliant job of creating an authentic feeling home that a family lives in with the various little touches. Example: peeling stickers on the main character's desk, messy rooms, etc. Gone Home does an outstanding job with creating a rich atmosphere that I personally can relate to. The game is kind of eerie, reminding me of when I was a kid being home alone kind of eerie.   Growing up in the 90's, Gone Home struck a very peculiar chord with me, but might not do so for others. This game is often criticized for not being very 'gamey', but I personally didn't really care or see why they (Fullbright) would need to make it like that, Gone Home is more of an experience rather than a game, and it's an experience I think is worth someone's time.

This game is really just an interactive series of journal entries. This isnt a bad thing by any means, but I finished it in about 90 minutes, and I felt that I searched a read everything, so overall it's a little short. Whilst the main story is the focus of the game, exploring and reading everything you can opens up some interesting if not sad subplots. I feel the game will strike a nostalgic chord with anyway who grew up in the mid 90's, so if you like the genre it can be good for a bit of a nostlagic trip. The game was paced well, which allowed you to develop the families timeline and distinguish the defining events throughout, which overall made the game more interesting, which is good becasue it really is just a walking simulator. Overall, I cant reccomend this game at $20, as I dont feel it has enough replay value. If you can get it under $5, then I'd say give it a shot. Also, make sure you know what you're buying, this ISN'T a supernatural thriller.
But it's not worth $20 bucks. Zipped through it in less than 2 hours. Felt like I was jipped a little, but great story.
Great music, good gameplay, amazing storyline.
Best realistic metroid-vania I've played.

Pretty fun little explore-em-up thingy. Lotta people say 'oh it's not a game' but I found it pretty fun to explore the house and to piece together all of the little stories based on observations of the environment. Exploring the house is the game and finding these things is the reward and as a whole it's a pretty neato thing. Get it on the cheap if you can.

Gone Home is a little tale of a family and its members, although one member in particular has a special role in this story. Play it if you aren't afraid of shedding a tear or two.  Definately worth the price if you catch it on sale.
A touching story of love, with great immersion and even a moment that was 2spooky4me. For sure grab this one on sale, you wont regret it. 10/10
Great story. Don't buy this game for the gameplay, buy it for the tale of Sam and Lonnie. And don't pay full price.
A very particular and unique experience. Truly the proof, if there still needed one, that video games are now another form of art. Highly recommended.
Buy This Game on Sale

Game is actually not bad at all, just terribly overpriced (i can't imagine how people, who paid 20$, were p.i.s.s.ed!). i think 3-4$ is suitable price for this VERY short game (you can finish it in 20min, 40 minute max, i was just idling a lot).  Bought it for 5$, and enjoyed this little story very much. Not horror/scary like i thought, just a little story, sometimes a bit emotional.  Definitely not a must buy, but storytelling feels fresh, voice acting is very good.

I would suggest this game to anyone. It is something old and something new. It reminds me of older games where you find things around a location and hunt for the random things to progress the level. And it also adds the fine arts of a book or any other form of literature into gaming, which really helps give it a story that makes up for it's 2 hour at most length. This is proof of what a good small production game can become and how it can improve all other games in it's genre.

I liked this game, although I do think it's a bit overrated and suggest not paying more than $10 for it ($20 is definitely steep for how short the experience is). It's well acted and fairly well-paced. I guessed what the twist of the story would be as soon as I watched a trailer for the game (and I got it confirmed by a spoiler before I ever owned the game) so I did find a few of the red herrings in the game sort of silly.  That being said, I did think that they did a fantastic job of creating atmosphere in the game, and the story, while simple, was told in an effecting way. (The fantastic voice acting from Sam's actress is probably part of that.) I don't think it's quite as unique as reviewers thought (the gameplay strikes me as being similar to Amnesia), but I also wouldn't call this just a 'walking simulator' since exploring the house is interesting and tells the story in a different way than, say, a movie could. It's certainly a really interesting experience and I'm really glad I played it, so if you're interested in story-driven games (or 'interactive experiences' or whatever you want to call this) I definitely recommend picking this up when it's on sale.  That being said, is this Game of the Year material? No, not in my opinion. It's a well done experience but there were better written, more effecting experiences than this that came out in 2013, even among indie games (Stanley Parable, while not as an emotional story, engaged me more, and while I've only played the beta version of Papers, Please so far I'm pretty confident that game has a story as emotional and interesting as Gone Home with much more solid gameplay).  tl;dr - great example of storytelling in gaming, great atmosphere, recommended if you can get it on sale. But I do think that the hype and praise it got from the press was a little too generous.
Great game, well done. The story was rather suspensful up til the end. perfect for a quick, get your mind off daily bull, play through. Love it.
Not much need to be said about this game,  Lonnie and Sam forever <3 <3

Gone Home is a story-telling experience that presents itself in layers. As you find clues that move the story forward, another layer is peeled back, presenting a feeling of nostalgia, or longing, or worry. It is a solitary treasure hunt in a house where you need not worry about leaving all of the lights on when you leave the room. Gone Home sweeps you off your feet to a time when information was not instant, to a time when adolescence was experienced through missed calls and passed notes. It is a game that exemplifies the trials and fervor of youth in an era when alternative cultures are coming into their own.

A college student returns home to find the house empty, despite being informed her younger sister would be waiting for her. As you explore the house, you uncover what happened to your family while you were away. Atmospheric and engaging, with possibly one of the best stories told in game media. The game is rather short, with a play time of approximately 2 hours through the story, but much more time could be spent exploring the house and its environs for hidden nuggets of information. Overall, excellent. One of the best games of its year.

Atmospheric.Emotional.Heart Warming.  A few words that spring to mind, having played Gone Home moments ago. I played on the edge of my seat throughout, enthralled in the magnificent story-telling prowess of Fullbright. And for that, I wish to thank them for making such an intriguing, emotive and attention capturing story.  Now I emplore you to experience the marvel that is, Gone Home!

Wonderfully atmospheric, with brilliant story-telling composed of part on diary-style narrative, part gamer-deduction. A great interactive story for those who don't mind exploring an empty house for a couple of hours and putting together the pieces.

As you can tell by most of the reviews of this game, it is not for everyone. This is basicaly not a game. It is a story that plays out in a house while you find notes around your house trying to find out where your sister went since you just came back from a trip to Europe for a year. This game is entirely based on reading the story and sometimes you will get a monologue from your sister explaining the note. The way that the story plays out is fantastic and it actually gets you to like Sam, since her character and the surroundings very relatable. Yes it is a short game but if you get it on sale or if you have a little money to spend, I highly recommend this game to all who love great storytelling.

I suspect Gone Home will soon be on the list of titles always mentioned in discussions of whether games can be art. There's not a lot of gameplay here -- there are no reflex-based events, just an environment you can explore at your own pace. But it's the most immersive game I've played in some time, with an excellent story and characters you'll genuinely feel for. Highly recommended.

Rarely have I played a game that floored me quite like Gone Home has. An incredible story, set in an eery house where a amily that all should be around simply aren't, takes you across a whole lot of emotional journeys.   The main story focuses on your sister, but that doesn't mean you can't follow up and invesitigate your mothers work issues, your fathers long, problematic life of trying to do what he loves, and even finding out about the protagonists past slowly throughout your investigation.  I can't reccomend this more; if you appreciate game story at all, pick this up as soon as you can.

--> spoiler free <--  This is the kind of game that I would gladly recommend to anyone. It subverts the usual first-person tropes and involves the player in a hugely unpredictable story—with the vibe of a mystery where the clues are laid out in perfect ways that reveal things about its characters, and in turn, aspects of humanity. Hardcore gamers will appreciate the change of pace. Newbies to gaming in general will be sucked into this world, just comfortable enough to press on.  It has some near-perfect pacing as a result of rewarding thorough exploration, providing compelling tidbits with almost every discovery, or confirming or denying something you may have been wondering about it. It's immersive, authentic, and honest.  It's also scary at times. Thanks to some stellar writing, a seriously ominous aural atmosphere, and an eerie level of 90's detail, it becomes easy to care about the characters and wonder about ourselves.  I won't say much more and I hope I haven't said enough to spoil anything. Get it. I really think it's a landmark game, a brilliant example of storytelling that doesn't rely on the usual gaming mechanics, and as a result, is appealing and fun to talk about and play with with just about anybody who's willing to have a gaming experience that can be easily finished in a single sitting.  [On the negative side of things: that near-perfect pacing is just that: near; the ending was a tad too abrupt for me. And the very short playtime (with pretty thorough examination, around 3 hours) might be hard to persuade for $20 (but $10 is perfect). That 3-hour playtime makes it perfect, though, for repeat playings and sharing with friends and family.]
Very short, but good story. Nice music and atmosphere. Not worth much more than $2 since it's only about an hour long.

Gone Home is to the gaming community as Al Sharpton is to politics.  It is simple, like Al, it is not what it appears to be, like Al, it has a hidden agenda to cram down your throat. Like... you get the picture.  As if guilt trips weren't enough in today's society. We start off coming home. Empty house (btw the whole thing is a walking simulator through a house with notes and what not to find and discover). We are reminded of the 90's. Hell 90% of what I found and saw in game were things I had around and kept in my pre-teen and teenage years.  The story is finding out why you came home to an empty house and why your sister left.  *Spoiler*  She left because she was gay. Lesbian.  This sends a message to players that we drive our homosexuals away. That we aren't tolerant enough of their existance. I even read comments in the Gone Home game hub that we should buy these sort of games to support Gays all over the world... really?  When we accept the Gay community into our news media, our movies, tv shows, news papers, we have openly gay politicians as leaders of our cities, of our states, we passed the point, several decades ago, that being gay is NOT a social set back.  People will always not like you because you are too fat, too skinny, too bald, too hairy, too rich, too poor, dislike you because of your position in life, because you have something they just don't. People will not like you because of the color of your skin or the fact you wear glasses or have your own sense of humor or fashion. It is a part of human nature. People will have their own opinions about gays and if a family is too weak that they can't accept a homosexual in their family then that homosexual is BETTER off without the hate from those certain members of their family.  But to guilt trip players into thinking we don't do enough? When other countries stone to death homosexuals and force them to either never display their affections or die? Or worse commit suicide?   Come on... good game, great nestalgia factor, but supporting this game soley because it has a guilt trip factor about gays is not worthy of it's meta score or praise.  We are not the 1950s. Accept this and let yourself know gays are not the new thing to praise and coddle. They are just like everyone else now. They are normal. Nothing special about them as a social status now. Lets move on, shall we?

Be warned: Similar to Thirty Flights of Loving, this is not a game. You don't really win, you don't even lose.  However:  Gone Home is the most incredible piece of interactive art yet created. It is an attempt to tell a complete story entirely through the environment. And without spoiling it, it really is the single most affecting story I've seen behind a mouse and keyboard. Friendships are tested; Ouija boards are consulted; dark rooms and rooms with dark pasts are plumbed. Ultimately, we're reminded that the hardest thing about high school is just surviving.

There is some important info you need to know before buying 'Gone Home' 1. It is not a game. 'Game' implies that there is gameplay and some kind of goal. This is an interactive story. There are no boss battles, no power ups to collect, and no end goal besides having the story told to you. If you thought 'Dear Esther' was boring, DO NOT BUY THIS.  2. Gone Home is short. You can easily finish it in 90 minutes. If you think 20 dollars is too much for a 90 minute experience, DO NOT BUY THIS. (I know I have spent 20 dollars on 90 minute movies that were much worse than this)  3. Story, story, story. Gone Home is about the story. The story is a drama. If you are not someone who pays attention to detail, you will miss a lot in this game. Everything in the environment is meant to service the story. If you are not a fan of serious drama, DO NOT BUY THIS.  If you are still reading then this game may be for you. Mild spoilers ahead. If you do not want to read spoilers I will just say that this story is amazingly well crafted. The characters are more real and believible than any other game I have ever played. And you should buy it right now.       MILD SPOILERS HEREAFTER: In Gone Home you play a girl who has just spent a year abroad on vacation. You come home from your red eye flight expecting your parents and little sister to welcome you home. Only to find a note on the front door from your sister saying she has run away for reasons unknown and your parents are nowhere to be found.  What follows is your exploration of their new house (they moved into this house while you were away) trying to figure out where everyone is.  The story is told through the environment and also through journal entries from your sister. These are recited to you by an excellent voice actress. Your exploration uncovers the trappings of a standard upper middle class life.  The story is engaging, and very moving. By the end you may shed tears of sadness and of joy. (The story is very bittersweet.)  Gone Home is an incredible example of video games as Art. This story could not have been told in any other medium and because of the way it is told it becomes even more emotionally powerful.  There is a twist in the story, that is fairly obvious to spot for anyone paying attention, but that does not detract from the quality of the narrative.   If you like Dear Esther buy this immediately. If you are on the fence wait for it to be on sale.  There is an aspect to the story that warrants discussion but to give it away in a review would be a disservice to the game. I'll just say there are some mature themes in the game. And by mature I mean emotionally mature not porno mature.  If you like your games to be full of explosions and awesome action, this is not for you.  If you want a thought provoking and amazingly well told narrative Gone Home is highly recommended.

A fantastic piece of storytelling, Gone Home captures youth and dealing with growing up in a tasteful, suspenseful way. The investigation elements are fun, and the writing is top notch, so you will feel for the progression of the characters who are battling through personal demons (in a way I won't spoil).  My only criticism would be that the game (nay, experience) is quite short, so users may feel unhappy with the $19.99 price tag at time of writing, but for the relative cost of a movie ticket where I live, this 2-4 hour trip was well worth the money spent.  The ending, without spoiling anything, is an immersive, dread-filled exploration, which never quite goes where you think it will. Go home and give it a go.
Great game, awesome music, very atmospheric, short, good story.
Amazing form of storytelling that could never have existed if not for this ongoing influx of great indie games on Steam.

This game is a great narritive piece, it is what I think Dear Esther should have been more like. The biggest downfall, and its a big one, is how short it is; the game is only 90 minutes and has no replay value. For about twenty dollars this is really steep, even for a very unique experience. I'd wait until the price is lower before picking it up.
Very entertaining 2-3 hours. Approach it like interactive story telling and you'll have a good time. Pick it up on sale for $4.99, no brainer.

This game is a very well told story in a completely interactive and detailed environment. The soundtrack (GH:OST) is very good, the story is well written and has some voice acting, and exploring is an absolute delight. You should know already if this game is for you or not.

Personal Rating: Play it before someone spoils it for you  I watched a Let's Play of this first, then bought it for myself. I'd play it again in an instant just to make sure I found every little bit of information I possibly could. But maybe that's just the kind of person I am :p The story's touching, the whole game is a brilliant example of how to create effective atmosphere, I felt clever while playing the game for figuring things out.  However, don't play it if:  - you can't go five minutes without shooting something  - not being able to jump will drive you crazy  - being observant isn't your forte > and having to be observant frustrates you < (of course, you could look up most in a walkthrough if necessary)
I'm amazed that the most breathtakingly emotional story line that i've ever played could be attached to such a simple game. Definitely worth the purchase no matter what kind of games you're into.
Short but sweet game. Story 9.5/10, will make you BibleThump.
Creepy, riveting, kept me guessing right up to the end.

Very good story driven game that takes a different spin on showing the player a narrative. Although a little on the short side i definately recommend this game for anyone who likes a good story with a bit of mystery to it.
Great game good story will definetly replay it more.

This game does so much to make exploring an old creaky house at night memorable. Each room has a distinct purpose and unique details that make exploration exciting.   The game's narrative is compelling, but being placed within it, so expertly, to intimately experience yourself is in my opinion Gone Home's real hallmark.   Even if you're a high-energy action-only games type, Gone Home is THE game you should try if you want to try something different.

After hearing both extreme hate and extreme love for this game, I have concluded that although short and not much of a traditional video game, it was still good to walk around and hear the story. I would advise though, that you should wait for a sale since I don't feel it's quite worth the asking price. (6/10)

The Good: * Creepy atmosphere drives your intrigue  * Letters, music and scenery set the mid 90's period perfectly * Audio journal is superbly written and narrated * Subtle jokes and nods that really work * Some clever, if subtle, misdirection in the plotting * Keeps you guessing and exploring * Lots to read and doled out in clever natural ways  The Bad: (nitpicking) * Short? 2 hours is enough time to complete * Little to no replay value (possibly a Commentary play-through) * A couple of lock combinations are easy to miss * Would have like more problem solving * Secrets are findable at any time and technically you can end the game in under 60secs * Some odd frame rate issues for no apparent reason  Background: Heard good things, had to try it out.  Impressions: Wow, what a great ride. Very impressed by the writing and execution that played out perfectly as I explored and all made logical sense while apparently giving you semi-open world freedom it's actually guiding you. there are easter eggs in almost every location if you look for them and none are necessary or over explained you just have to be observant. Nothing jarred me out of the game and finding a cereal box with the puzzle completed on the side in pen just shows the level of detail that goes into making this house feel lived in.  Be aware this is an interactive story and 2 hours is all it takes to complete. There are adult themes that are handled cleverly and that reading and thought is needed to get the most out of the experience as the game allows you to join the dots yourself for the broad themes and side stories.  Recommended for: 90's music lovers, those with a literary passion and point n click explorers.  Conclusion: 7/10. A pitch perfect story, expertly delivered in every way but beware the length and how much you want to pay.
Good if you were a teenage girl in the 90's.
I cried so much!
I found a dirty Magazine 10/10.
I've opened all the water faucets in the house for absolutely no reason, joke's on you mom.

This is not really a game, it's more of an interactive story. You explore the empty house of your family, piecing together really several threads of a story together until you get the whole picture. What you find is tremendous and atmospheric, and my hat's off to the designers for making this happen.   This title gets a lot of downvotes, and I guess those folks either were expecting something completely different, or just weren't the target audience of this in the first place. This is a story, and a damn fine one too.

A bittersweet story.  I played this together with my boyfriend and we both found it very moving. We were worried when we got nearer the end that the ending could have been ... different, less pleasant let's say, so we were pleasantly suprised with it. The development over the course of the game of the depth of the family's life and problems was fantastic, bit by bit finding out more and more. I want to know what happens next, I want to know the parent's reactions. But stories have to end somewhere.

Pick it up on sale if you have any interest in it and be aware that while it is fairly short, the experience you get out of it reflects the effort you're willing to put in. It's essentially an adventure game and if you're just rushing through it there's a good chance you'll miss a lot of details.   It's one of them arty-games without guns and that's why it sucks. Who heard of a game of the year that didn't have explosions.

Picked this up in a Humble Bundle/Indie Gala/Indie Royale (can't remember which one) and turned out to be a surprisingly good little game, finished in a little under one hour without looking through EVERY nook and cranny, but getting a good general sense about what happened in the story. I followed this up with a quick read of the plot summary on Wikipedia to fill in the gaps, but overall it was nice to play something that didn't require twitch-level mouse control (shooters) or the anxious wait for a fright (Alien).

A slightly arty, short game involving a lot of reading and the coming-of-age of your younger sister. Clocking in at under 2 hours, this is well worth a play for something a little different (and affecting).
A very enjoyable experience. Nice story and excellent voice acting.
Interesting game.  I'm missing three items, if anyone can tell me what they were that'd be much appreciated :)

This is a game that tells a story. It's brief but the voice acting and the story it tells are heartbreakingly beautiful. I played it in one sitting (about 3 hours) and it was so completely worth every penny and then some.
Amazing storyline, and lovely music. I'm completely in love with this amazing game.

Grabbed this at the Hw-Sale for 10€.  What should i say, its an exploration game, its (just) a little story.  First it felt like a creepy horror-game, but it really isnt.  You advance the fairly short plot through investigating the mansion.   I think i have fallen in love with the voice actress, shes really the main part of the game.  I´d recommend this game for a cheap, because its really short.  I just got into it, it was getting really emotional (thats what i like about some game stories), and then ... it ended. /sigh  After all it was a great expierence, and a very nice idea, but i see some lost potential in it.
Buy This game, Shut the lights off, and just play.

You are home a lone Yor pigeon is gone But the fear is right in your head.  Where's your dad Where's your mom And shouldn't your sister now be in bed?  A beotyful storee About time u-Go? home But there is ain't not a being here.  And if you there To seek out the true You're in for a happy, and for a cheer  ...or not At least it has a nice profile background =) 8/10 go buy it or don't

Gone Home, in my opinion, is a must play game. The way it will grab you and pull you into the world as you try to find out what happened to Sam and the rest of your family is something that no other game has been able to accomplish. Although short, it is easily a memorable game that will forever stay with you.   Purchase it for full price, or on sale, it doesn't matter, as long as you can get the chance to experience this game first hand. 10/10
Very different, only a couple of hours long, but engrossing while it lasts.
Simply the best story in a video game I've ever experienced. Actually made me cry in the end.
One of only two games that was able to really make me tear up at the end. If you go in with an open mind and don't expect a typical horror or exploration game, I think you'll really enjoy it.

the game was short but the story amazingly complex having to piece together the events of you families life while you were away from the objects and letters you find in the house. the detail in the house is amazing and even little things like school text books and homework assignments being left out leads us to learn about the charecters of the game and the life of family in the mid 90's. however sometimes it getts a little hard to swallow your sister leaving you some notes sure but wouldnt her parents also find them? perhaps thats why her parents are gone as well of searching for your sister after reading all of the same notes. however that still dosent change why the wife would leave the notes about the ensuing affair all over the house i mean come on is her fateher that nieve.

This game tells the story of a struggling youth in a family that has more troubles than first meets the eye. This game does well on what it's supposed to be, a simulation. A narrative told through the written perspective of a girl struggling with discovering herself.   The game contains an engrossing story that many of us would not expect to be told in a game that has reached this height of popularity.   Criticism arises through the high price of a narrative game, and I agree. I think that $20 might be too high a price. But, you have to admit that the story was told through a unique fashion that had many of us interested to see it through to the end, despite its less-than-perfect gameplay.  I would recommend this game to people who WANT to spend a couple of hours reading a book convering itself up as a game, a story to immerse yourself in and make you think. Do I think that's a bad thing? Not necessarily. I think they did it well.

I'm not sure whether to call this a game in the traditional sense of the word, but it was definitely a powerful and poignant experience. I fired up Gone Home, expecting to play for a few mintues before moving on to something else. Instead, I sat transfixed for the next 2-3 hours, learning everything I could about the Greenbriar family.  When I first started reading Harry Potter or listening to The Mountain Goats, I wanted everyone I knew to check them out, just so that I could have the experience of talking about something that really spoke to me with people I cared about. Gone Home hit me in just that same way.  It is worth the money. Seriously. Buy it and play through it. And then talk about it with a friend.

This was a relatively short game, but I had more fun playing this game than I have with many other games in a long time. If you're looking for a good mystery/story telling/exploration game then I definitely recommend trying this game.

Gone Home revolves around a woman who goes home to her parents and sister after a year of travelling, only to find the massive house completely empty. As you go around the slightly creepy house, you find clues to the whereabouts of the family. You can pick up almost everything, turning it around in your hands. There is a clear story which will sidetrack your thoughts about the whereabouts of everyone more than once. The game takes about 2 hours to complete if you, like me, go through everything and read and listen to everything.  (Slight) SPOILER ALERT for those concerned about the content:    The game is NOT a horror survival game: even though the house can be creepy, you will not end up meeting anyone or anything; so don't worry. However, it's still a bit creepy to run around in.
Spent the whole game scared something was gonna pop out at me.

I wouldn't call this a game; it's more a short film you walk through and listen to while you do the walking. It has basically zero replayability, there is no way of 'losing' and it's kinda short. That said, what little time i spend in it i found entertaining. I liked finding little pieces of story and history all over the place and learning about those people and even finding all kinds of 90's crap strewn about. So if you want a 2 hour long 'walking simulator', go for it. Though better get it when it's on Sale, just to be on the safe side.
The best narrative experience I have ever had in a video game
Like outlast but less ♥♥♥♥♥.
Absolutely amazing story driven game! I'd highly recommend

I read some of the reviews bellow and one of the my first thoughts was that it isn't a blockbuster game at all and it is enterely made for those gamers that completely care about the story and live the life of the characters portrayed. You will find no challenges on it, no enemies at all, no battle or any form of the contents that made any adventure or action games good (despite the plot, but of course). If you're a player that think it is worth it for playing a game with none of those things but yet one of the best stories and character development maybe ever made in a video game, condider yourself able to click on read more.  The game is short ? yes. Should it have been longer ? Definitely not !  The game as you should read or heard before has only one character appearing on itself for the entire show: yourself. There is no npc, no interactive characters, no enemies, no nobody. Just you, yourself and thy !  Now thats one of the amazing things. The game is actually settled in one huge house, really huge, and there was a psycho living in there (not spoilers, you get that in five mins of gameplay). There is a wheeping voice recording on your voicemail calling for your sister, that left a letter asking you to not contact any of your parents or to say what she have done.  I said it was one of the amazing things, wasn't lying. IT IS NOT A HORROR GAME. You are throwed in this whole enviroment with a badass storm on the background and you go on and discover that the house has eletricity problems, so then and then the lights of a really long hallway just start blinking. Also the sound of the game is really amazing, so you hear the wood in your feet make a lot ( a lot !!!!) of noise. But again, it is not a horror game. I'm saying that because i ♥♥♥♥ in my pants for some few hours and even searched on the steam community just to make sure that i wasnt, and it isn't. But allong the gameplay you really find yourself splitted in a thriling crazy mansion and a really great story (that was actually awesome) Again, no horror game !  But finally, the story: The story is actually told in a very peculiar way. You are a hitchhiker and was in trip for some time that i don't remember. But enough time to your family ( parents and sister) move in to another house. You find the whole house in the moving mood, so sometimes it is sometimes not full of life like a normal house, and again making it better for the scary feeling. You discover about your parents story through doccuments and letters and find a lot about their lives, fears, objectives and commitments to. While about your sister, you follow the story by notes, bottoms, cassette tapes, and a lot of things; allong with a journal that was written by her for you, while you were in that great trip. She writes because you were really close and she don't want you to miss about her life that she always shared with you.  The game is actually settled in the 90's, so no internet as you thought ! This ambientalization is made in a very good and with a lot of nostalgia feeling. Just like the cassette tapes, SNES games , the shocking death of kurt kobain, the letter exchanging and of course the good'ol journal  The game is very touching and very grown up, despite its simplicity. The story of your sister and her friend in the new school escalates in a very exciting way, and this is totally a story that you won't forget. I am really afraid of giving spoilers in here. Just know that it is a real crying-maker, beautiful, touchy and pure piece of art inserted in a awesome story and development. To this gem 10/10

Like the majority of the reviews, this exploration title is NOT worth the normal price tag of $19.99.  Luckly I won a copy from ONLYSP (an online game review/news website...you should check them out...plug over.)  Roughly 70 minutes of a short story regarding what has happened to your family while you were away on holiday.  Pros: - Great 90's flashback of pop culture and somewhat relatable for the children of the 80's and 90's. - Decent Enviromental original soundtrack laced with 90's Punk/Grunge. - (IMO) Interesting story  Cons:  - Short - Dear Ester Style of Gameplay...(I'm personally fine with it) - High Entry Point (19.99)  I'm very much looking forward to The Fullbright Company's next title 'Tacoma'.  Final Thoughts: If you can pick this up during a steam sale go for it, it's an interesting game but, leaves you wanting more in the mystery/game/exploration department. 6/10.   - A review by someone who got the game for free and has no idea how to make video games.
Absolutely amazing game.  Took my time and finished it in just over 4 hours.   The story really was absolutely amazing.   Hauntingly beautiful and moving. Cannot recommend this game enough.

This game has major ups and major downs. The story, despite the simplicity of it, was executed extremely well, and kept me interested from start to finish. The atmosphere was taut, also keeping me slightly on edge for no apparent reason, in such a way that you can really tell this has its roots in an Amnesia mod. The music was subtle yet effective, especially in contrast to the occasional cassettes you can put on around the house.  However, the game is way overpriced. Many people have complained about the game being so short (I finished it in 81 minutes) but I think the length was just right for it. Nevertheless, you cannot seriously charge any more than £3 for something so short. So wait until the game is on sale before picking it up.  Overall, this was a really enjoyable experience, and I hope that people will be open-minded when they try it, rather than saying it's not a 'real' game.
There's only 80 minutes of play time. There's no shooting. There's no gore. There aren't even any enemies.  Just play and enjoy the emotion, it's worth it.

This  is  a game, no matter what anyone else says, and it's an amazing one at that. It's thoughtful, mature, and emotional in a way that more games should strive to emulate. The story is simple, yet compelling. Just know going in that there are no enemies or puzzles or anything, it's  only  about exploring a house and uncovering the secrets of a family that's probably a lot like your own.

Got it during the sales and it was definitley worth the $9.99 if you enjoy a strong story with something different. If your looking for something filled with more excitement this probably isn't for you though.
The 'debates' about video games being art need to stop. This game has the most beautiful story. Don't be scared. Relax. Enjoy the ride.

One of the greatest and most immersive games I Have ever played,but due to it's short length (I Finished in two sittings,and It took three hours altogether for me to finish) and lack of replayability,it is not worth the 11.99 asking price,but Gone Home is still an experience I'll never forget.

Gone Home is something special. The guys and ladies at The Fullbright Company have crafted an amazing experience that runs the gamut of emotions, all with the simple idea of wandering an empty house on a rainy night.  I can't say more without spoiling things. But if you like piecing together pieces of a puzzle and wandering creepy deserted houses. Gone Home is absolutely worth it.
An amazing journey that hits you right in the feels.
No combat, no skill tree, no objective. You just look through other people stuff. Its an odd and different experiance. Must try when it goes on sale.
Amazing Game! Great Graphics, Amazing Storyline, and definitely fits the time period.

I just spent the last 2 hours falling in love and subsequentially having my heart broken for a pair of characters who's notes to one another guide me through a spooky family inheritance home on a cold, rainy night.

The challenge of this game is one of immersing yourself in the storyline, empathising with the characters, reading everything, finding everything, understanding what is going on and getting the emotional pay off at the end. If that doesn't sound like fun to you then you should avoid this like someone who doesn't like clicking on men with guns should avoid Call of Duty.   On the other hand if you want mature work of interactive storytelling then by all means get this. I cried a little at the end and thought about what might happen next so fair to say it successfully drew me in.  On a third hand, the one holding the wallet, this is a two hour long game that compares well to a good film in terms of length and emotional payoff. I'm not sure I'd recommend anyone pay more than they'd be happy to pay to go to the cinema so the current non-sale price of €19.99 seems a bit steep.

Gone Home offers a classic close-quarters adventure game with several unique plotlines, each detailing very real problems, such as identity, fear of the uncertain, and depression. Discover the secrets of a long-lost relatives mansion, dig into the trials of a conspiracy novelist, and trace the potential love affairs of a close family member. If you're the kind of gamer who enjoys a compelling, memorable story, Gone Home is definitely worth a try. [Game time - about two-to-three hours.]

A cool little interactive story. You come home after a long trip and find your family house deserted. With no information or way to contact your family members you need to explore your house in order to uncover what has happened since you've been away and discover why the house is empty. You track additional pieces of each family member’s story through notes, letters and other clues. The stories of each family member are geuinely interesting and the story culminates in a satisfying ending. Definitely not what I expected getting into things and a game I thoroughly recommend.
Completed in just over an hour. Not bad to amuse yourself for an afternoon.
Hmm. That was... nice... so,... thanks.
Such a fantastic exploration video game. Short, roughly 2 hours or so, so sit down with some people and experience together!

It's not very long, but Gone Home is absolutely engaging through the few hours you spend with it. The game plays like a mystery where you step in after an long trip abroad and arrive home to an empty house. The simple mystery is: 'where is your family?' This leads the game into an apparently linear narrative, but that linearity is somewhat an illusion. Completing the game is simple enough, but if you really dig there are stories to be told far beyond reaching the brings you to the credits that bring to life some of the most believable characters in any game I've played through the leavings of life around a home.  Gone Home isn't a revelation in gameplay mechanics, but it is an experience that's only possible in an interactive format.
Honestly, it's an amazing game. I wish it didn't have the lag, though. Gorgeous setting, the house gives off a creepy, eerie feeling. Overall, I love it.
Not that bad. It's, dare i say it, cute? Meh. Good idea, poor price decision. Just wait for a humble bundle version. Btw you can beat it in 20 seconds... So if you do buy it, try to savour it.
Great exploration game with good graphics, amazing attention to detail, and a story that will not just pull your heartstrings, but give them a yank that will make most cry at the end.
Surprised me. Lovely.

Don't care the bad comments,if you want to listen a good and really emotional story just buy it.  Pros: -Amazing story -Nostalgia,nostalgia... -Really good soundtrack -Emotions...  Cons: -Not for everyone.   ♥♥♥♥ the little CoD players,this is a masterpiece,GOTY 2014.   10/10

The word that comes to mind is intriguing when playing this game. Its unlike anything I've ever played. I kept expecting zombies to pop out at me, but no. Completed it in less than 4 hours, but is that necessarily a bad thing? Definately worth a shot.
A brilliant experience. This is a fragile, intimate game not for someone looking for an action game or a horror game. This is a story, in game form. And it is done very very well. 8/10
I really liked this 'Game'. (Not a game so much as an interactive story)
special experience, unlike any game out there...
Better story than most AAA titles, and has characters that I actually care about.   10/10 would go home again.
Great environmental exploration game. It's like a short story in a video game format.

Fantastic story-telling, atmospheric setting, great music.. I can't recommend this highly enough. It took me around 4 hours to complete - it's short but sweet. I wish that I could go back and play it again with no knowledge of the story so I could experience it again for the first time. Go play it!

This game has truly amazed me. I didn't think much of it at first, in fact the only reason I played it was because it sounded like some sort of detective game, which it sort of is. However it is so much more than just exploration. There's many little hidden things in this game that tell you about the story and among other things.   The story touched my heart and changed my perception on many things. I doubt I'll ever be able to feel the same way this game made me feel again.  I truly reccomend this game to anyone who loves exploration, a bit of eeriness and a beautiful story.
if you want a game to tell you a short storey a interactive novel if you like,  its short and intresting but thats all it is probiley not worth the asking price

This is one of those great experiences that come along very infrequently; I'd say it's a must play when priced under $10, and a worthwhile consideration when at it's full asking price - just keep an open mind.  If you're looking for a traditional horror game, a puzzle solving thing or a more traditional first person experience, you won't find it with this title..   What you will find are aspects of horror and tension, a richly detailed environment and a love story bound together in a wholly uniuqe package.   If every game that came out in 2013 was like this, it would be a drag to be sure, but it's good that this title exists.
Amazing story development, great music choices and an amazing ending that kept me guessing. 10/10

I got the game on sale for $6.79. I have played the game for two and a half hours, although I believe half of that hour was idle while I was chowing down on some delicious ham. I will tell you this...if I paid 20 bucks for it, I'd probably be upset. Being that it was under 10, I was more than entertained. It was fantastic.  The premise is that you are a girl that returns to a large, spooky home after an overseas trip where you studied abroad. No one is home. It's a dark and stormy night. You hear cracks of thunder. Occasionally a lightbulb might go out on you. And you are aaaaaall alone. Except for bits and pieces of journey entries you get from your sister Susan who is voice acted.   There are rumors that the house is haunted. And so the premise builds that something wrong happened to your family.  But did it?  And that's the whole gist of the story. You playing inspector detector to try to gain insight on what happened while you were gone. Oh and it takes place in the 90s. Which oddly enough...I grew up in the 90s so I remembered a crap ton of the references.  This game is not a Slender Man game. You're not running around with your heart pounding afraid of what might jump and gobble you up from behind. It's a story about discovery and understanding. It tugs on the emotional heart strings. It's not going to be a game for everyone. But it's fascinating in that it focuses on story and that is literally all there is. And a few minor puzzles.   Game gets my two thumbs up for making me feel something and entertaining me.

Take a lazy afternoon and play this. It doesn't take long to finish and you'll be thankful you did. Turn the lights down low and make sure the volume is up. Pay attention, listen, learn and really dig into it. You'll be rewarded for your efforts.

What a beautiful experience. The way the story is told could only be done in a game -- not a movie or a book -- and the creators have done a marvelous job. Fantastic.  Recommended for anybody who loves beautiful storytelling.

This isn't a game, so much as an interactive experience. Do not expect a typical adventure game with complex puzzles. It's more of a discovery of your family, particularly your sister. It is a good story, and one that I think people who grew up in the 90s will be most likely to enjoy.

I dropped my boys off at daycare this morning and then sat down to play, and 3.5 hrs later I'm writing this.  Quite a nice game. Gave me goosebumps in a few places. I can't see myself playing through it again, however, I'm very glad to have experienced it.  Well worth whatever sale price I paid for it.
This game is amazing. It's so simple in theory and yet so freaking complex. I don't want to spoil anything, just get it right now.

'Gone Home' is another in a growing body of non-linear story discovery games. I for one am happy that these games are appearing, because they signal a willingness to develop a long neglected gaming mechanic, that of interactive fiction. Even though there are a few keys and combinations you need to discover, every location in this deliciously detailed old mansion is open for you to explore, and in exploring, you are drawn into the complex interactions of a family, it's problems, and its past.  I found the characters engaging, the story believable and poigniant, and even though the game is only a few hours, it's well worth your time.

Looking at the traile, the game pretty boring and frankly it seemed like something I wouldnt really get. Given that im recomending it, it should come to no surprise that I was wrong. Gone Home is a story exploration game where you play as a young women named Katie. You have just came home after studing abroad in europe, expecting finialy see your mom, dad, and sister again after the long trip, but nobody is home. That is your goal in the game, to simply find out why. Although you can coast through the story simply by listening to the journals, if you really want to piece things toghether you will have to study your surroundings. Its this that makes Gone Home truelly special. It manages to tell a verry compeling story all while using a verry little amount of dialog.
It's a nice game with a rich back story you need to dig for. You'll be on pins and needles until the end, which wasn't what I was expecting, but was a satisfying conclusion.

I love these kinds of games. Though I do agree that the price is too much for this short of a game but if MGS did it why cant this? At least this is an actual full game. Its obvious that these developers gave a lot of thought into this story of Sam but the thing that bothers me is you dont really care what happens to the rest. Only Sam's story is interesting just because of the diary entries. It wouldnt hurt to have some other commentaries to this but I guess that will go away from the intial main plot. Overall this game is amazing but not worth its initial price. Just get it on sale lol
really feels like i just read a coming of age book... through a first person exploration game?   yes to new gaming experiences!

I found 'Gone Home' to be thoroughly engaging. It's a linear exploration game, but I felt eager to follow the story. The main plot is very touching, and I would be lying if I said I wasn't inclined to shed a tear or two at certain points! There are other stories to uncover, however, so don't miss out on those. The family has a dark past, but I'll reveal no more.
