I generally LOVE games of this 'narrative' genre, but compared to The Stanley Parable and even 'Dear Esther', this game falls pretty short. It's not a terrible, or even bad, by any stretch of the imagination...but it's just not that good. Buy it if it's on sale if you're really interested, but don't expect it to be the revolutionary title that some critics hyped it to be.
Hauntingly beautiful.

Wasn't entirely sure what to expect when I started playing and it was a little slow to start but the atmosphere really kicked in and the narrative is excellently paced with good voice-acting. Play it in the dark with headphones on for the best immersion.  Nice game.

Trying to describe this game without giving anything away is incredibly difficult. It is a game where the less you know about it, the more likely you are to be immersed and rewarded for exploration and discovery of the amazing story inside.  So instead, I'll just state that I loved this game and highly recommend playing it with as few preconceptions and foreknowledge as possible.  It is not a long game; I leisurely played it, examining every object in every room, and still finished in under 2.5 hours.  There is also virtually no replay value, save in the context of re-reading a book you love but haven't read in years.  On that token, I very much look forward to playing this game again in a few years' time after my memories have dulled and the specific details are lost.
A wonderful and moving interactive expierence.

9/10 It's purely a story-based game. Gameplay is kind of like amnesia, but with more light and less monsters. Gone Home isn't scary by any means. I finished it in like 2 hours. There's a lot of reading to do in this.

This is a great game that was very interesting. The graphics looked good and the soundtrack was amazing along with other rock songs that I enjoyed a lot. The games topic may offend some people but I can’t say much more than that without spoiling anything for you. controls were good but sometimes felt a little slow. sometimes I got confused about where to go because it was that out in the open to me but that is part of the fun of the game is exploring this big house and looking for secrets. 9/10

Loved it,the voice acter that voice Sam made this emotional. Decided to play this because of Vidjagame Apocalypse podcast, and i can't believe I didn't played this when it came out. I never get emotional, unless i'm watching anime but this game actually made me emational. Now it only took me a hour and twinty minutes to beat this and I did about 98% every there is to do but I got my money worth just because of the story. I wish there are more games that has a good story like this, that made be shed some manly tears. I Want to go back and play it. but I can't handle it right now. To much feels.
More visual novel than game. Kinda short and no replay value. I wouldn't pay full price for it, but definitely get it if it's on sale.

An awesome story to discover bit by bit while you explore the house. I was sceptical at first, but found myself searching every crook and corner to just find out more about the story. if you like visual novels, you'll love this one.

Hmm, not at all what I was expecting. I really enjoyed the game but it is very slow, over very quickly and a little frustrating that you can interact with so many elements but the interactions don't achieve anything. It also seems to be aimed at quite a young, and possibly primarily female audience? All in all I enjoyed it though.

This game is definitely not for every person on this community platform to enjoy. There's no such of levelling up, changing characters, tweaking appearances, or necessities to kill off any opponent you encounter. It's not action based at all and it's more of a puzzle for those types who have to connect the dots to solve the mystery. In a way though, you play as a young female in her early 20's that returned from Europe in the 1990's. The vicinity is vacant, there are lights left on and you have to discover where your family is. Despite the thundering and sounds of footsteps in the house, it's not much creepy or horrific for those that hate to be startled.   The controls for this game are also very simple. W,A,S,D to move about and left-clicking on objects to use them [that's your action button!] and right clicking or holding left shift to zoom in.   This game, however, is what I enjoy on any day. May there be no action or horror/gore involved, it's a laid back game and a puzzle.

Gone Home isn't just an interactive Dear Esther. First things first, it is not a comparesion between Dear Esther and Gone Home, rather, my point is they are very different games. Gone Home offers you a fully-interactable enviorment, a masterpiece story telling experience, and a very interesting story alongside with a perfect ambiance. There are no words to describe the game, it is not even a game in traditional sense. Go and grab it, if you want a very interesting story. 10/10
Short, but great story!
This is one of the best games I've played all year.
Surpassed by far my wildest expectations.
This was a well made game. The voice acting for the narration was phenominal. An amazing story!! This is a must play.
*Spoiler*        this game is gay

Picked it up on sale and def got my money's worth.   Avoid the spoilers, here's what you need to know: There is no combat, chasing, or dying. (And that is a great thing for this game!) It may startle or freak you out at times. Immerse yourself in the every bit of the story that you can find, and you'll have a blast. Lastly, after the game is done, you can go back to explore more.  Those are the things I wish I knew when I started, so maybe this will help you too. Support great indie games with new, and inventive story telling! Buy it now!!!
Really great story! It's currently for sale from Humble bundle for just $5!
Fun game although short. This is story/movie style genre (no platforming). Roughly 4 hours of gametime if you take your time.
Short game but really good. 9/10

I played this game once before but was distracted and didn't fully enjoy it, but the second time around...damn. This experience punched me in the chest and left me crying. It's beautiful. Expensive so get it on sale.

First of all: its a walking simulator. If thats not your thing, if you dont wanne take your time to read, listen, feel, explore, dont get it. Also: its short, if you want value for your money, buy it at a discount.   The (main)story was not very surprising in itself, but I would not have expected to find it in a game. Recognised a lot from my time in the 90's; I think it would have been a great game for my teenage self back then. I was disappointed in the end only one storyline was finished, and others where left open. Really think they could have done more with them.  Overall: the low price (<3 summersale), atmosphere and the story are good enough to give it the thumbs up. You decide for yourself if you like it or not.
Very good narrative, throughly enjoyed!

Gone Home is NOT a horror game.  It feels like one at times and your always expecting something but that something never comes. What is here is a experience that rivals something on par with Dear Esther. Its a haunting look at someones life through a 3rd person perspective. Its quite emotionally engaging and aesthetically appeasing. The environmental story telling is great too, if your one for small details and mysteries then this is for you  More 'games' like this please.

Another 'game' in the vein of Dear Esther. It tells a story that is pretty obvious from the first few minutes in. There is minimal user interaction beyond pressing forward and occasionally entering number combinations to open lockrs/safes.. For a $4 experience, it was okay... I think it's normal price of $19 is way too high, and the reviews for it are drastically overhyping it. If you enjoy the 'walk forward and learn story' genre that seems to be becoming a thing like I do, you might get your value out of it when it's cheap, but it's not the best example of that genre I've seen so far. I think the gist showed promise though and I'd be curious to see what else the studio could produce.
What an awesome story!

Got it on sale for $5 and I got every pennies worth of enjoyment out of it. Could see how those paying $20 might not feel they got their monies worth. This games main mechanic reminds me of the scavanging of Fallout 3/4 with the audio logs and world building reading material to match. It also has a series of cassette tapes containing music you can listen to it. Cool little detail that helps you get into the head space of one of the characters.  The main component of the story is the younger sister but it also focuses on the entire family and their lives over the last year. You get to know these characters, their relationships, and their struggles without ever meeting them. It's an emotional journey with some real gut punches and a very satisfying finale. I cried a little bit. Then a little bit more.   If the idea of walking around reading and pouring over every room for clues doesn't do it for you then this game isn't for you. If that sounds good then I would highly reccomend this.
It's a creepy, empty house, and I can promise you two things: you won't die, and you'll experience magnificent storytelling.
Fantastic game. It is worth the money that it is in fact ithat's worth more. Such a gripping story with a unique naritve. I would love for there to be some how a sequel to the game.
Good punk tapes all over the place.

If you're looking for a game that you can sprint through and brag about 'winning', this is not it. There's nothing to fight, no conflict, no 'boss level'. It's just you, your house and a lot of memories.  'Gone Home' starts on your front porch. After a year overseas, you've come back to find the place empty. Your sister is gone, your parents are out somewhere, and all you have in the way of information is audio-tapes, notepads, school binders and letters.  I don't fault others for calling this game 'bland' or 'uninteresting'; certainly, there isn't anything in the way of 'action' or 'adventure'. What it does have, however, is a lot to say about family -- the one you're born into and the one you create for yourself.  Take your time. Read the letters. Listen to your sister's story.  Sometimes, we all need someone to just listen.

A first-person exploration game set in your parent's new home. You've just arrived back home, but nobody is there. You explore the house and find things to read / listen to. Nothing too crazy, simply a play-at-your-own-pace sort of game, as you put together the pieces of the puzzle... the story you missed out on while you were away from home.  A very unique experience that I highly recommend. Don't read too much into it or you might spoil it for yourself. Took about 2 hours to fully explore the house from beginning to end. Gone Home kept me intrigued for the entire playthrough, but by the end left me expecting and wanting more.  I hope to see more games of this genre in the future, that hopefully expand upon the idea and add lots more detail and content. Dear Esther is a similar type of game, but I found it fairly boring most of the time.

Gone Home is a polarizing work. Its closest kin are visual novels and games like Dear Esther; but whereas Dear Esther was opaque and obscure, Gone Home wears its story on its sleeve.  You play as Katie, returning home from a trip abroad to find your family home empty, the only explanation at the start a letter from your younger sister, and a strange message on the answering machine leaves bad implications. Just where has everyone gone to? Unwinding that narrative is the focus of your journey through the house. A sense of dread and the unknown permeates the atmosphere, but eventually you start to uncover what's been going on since Katie left for Europe. And always you hear the rain pelting on the house all around you.  Gone Home is a love story told out of order. There are few if any real puzzles to solve, mostly of the 'put key combination in x lock' type. You can pick up and examine everything in the house, turning on lights and finding clues in objects. There is nothing to solve, apart from the satisfaction of learning what happened. You could easily speed run the game to the end but that would miss the point. The game isn't about speedruns as it is about setting a mood and getting under your skin. The voice acting for Sam is amazing; she comes across as a vulnerable character you come to care about as you learn who she is. Her struggles can break your heart if you let them.  As a story, it's not without its problems; you're never privy to how the stories for Katie's mother and father ended, and the ending itself feels consequence free, like what you'd find in a romance novel. Real life, which the game adheres to for the most part, feels painted over by the end. The game does its best to be optimistic, but who knows how this will all really end?  As for exploring the house, it's huge. It feels lived in, and since this is supposed to be set in the 90's there is a lot of nostalgia on display. Video tapes with old movies and X-Files episodes litter the house, punk band cassettes that you can listen to, and numerous other small details make it a treat for explorers. Sam even has SNES cartridges and is a professed Street Fighter fan, although the system itself is conspicuously absent. Often times you feel like Cole Phelps in L.A. Noire, picking up objects and going, 'Not relevant,' but this game is about exploration rather than pixel hunting.  Gone Home has many detractors. Games are traditionally about choices, but here you're given a different kind of choice that really comes down to the type of game you want to play. Outlast or Amnesia this is not. You don't order a salad when you wanted a steak sandwich. Do you want to instead play a game where you get to explore a house and pick up on the threads of a touching story? If so, Gone Home might be up your alley.   A final note on the price: as of this writing it's $19.99 which can be very pricy for what amounts to a short 2-3 hour experience. You can't replay it unless you wait a few months so items and events aren't as fresh in your memory. Even with the developer commentary ala Valve's games, this price is a little high for gamers on a budget. If you don't want to spend that much, you can always wait for a sale to get the most bang for your buck. It all depends on how much an experience like this is worth to you.

Gone Home is exploring game without any puzzles or enemies. Your objective is find out why the house is empty. The story is told in short 'cassette recordings', written notes and by visual presentation. And the story captivates the player from the start to end.  Note of warning to those that don't like exploration and/or reading/listening: this game requires you read and listen to what is said in order to understand what the game is trying to tell you!  This game is meant for those that enjoy good storytelling and have the patience to explore the house and it's inhabitants story.

Not what I was expecting at all. The craftsmanship of the total game is just great! I don't want to say too much to give away what it is all about, because exploring the world not knowing why your family's home is empty to come to understand all the stories *IS* what the game is about. The music is great, if you like garage punk rock. The atmosphere of the house with not knowing what is going on is just incredible. This is a game worth picking up if you are looking for something different from the normal offerings out there.
Wow, that was simply beautiful. If you enjoy playing the same old ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ over and over again, don't get this wonderfully inventive gaming experience.
Wasn't really a game it was more of an experience.   Tl;DR Anthony is gay, suck a ♥♥♥♥ :D

This game truly is a work of art, a living interactive mix between literature, art and music. Be aware, this game is not for close minded people and touches some topics that might make people dislike this game. But if you are open minded and don't have any prejudice against differences then this game is an open narrative for you to read through in the pace, order and mood you want. This game can be fairly quick or you cam take some time and really expand on your interpretation of this, just like you can with a good book by re-reading it.

I just went through the whole game in one go, and I loved it. Its story is well thought out and actually feels real. Exploring through the house I had no idea what to expect. I didnt have high hopes for this going in as I got it in a bundle for cheap, but I was very pleasantly surprised. If your wanting a well paced, well thought out, and well done story. This is your game. As others have said you do have to look for the clues and follow the marks on the map but I didnt care I just wanted to hear the rest of the story.  HIGHLY reccomend
Has a great story that is incredibly easy to get sucked into.
very short, super creepy

I honestly don't know what to say about this game. It isn't exactly what one might think at first, if this was intentional or simply the creator of the game realising while working on the story what the game actually is, I don't know.  I'm not sure how to rate this game, I like it although I have to agree with most people that it is too short (I played it for 98 minutes and I'm already done, without rushing) for the price it is currently sold, luckely I picked it up during a sale.  I think I make it short:  - Yay: If sales are going on - Nay: If you have to pay the full price (at the time of this writing 19,99€ on Steam)  Because I liked the game as a whole, I still give it a thumbs up.
WELL I LIKED IT. But seriously worrth playing, but don't pay too much for it, I finished it in two hours but still great game

Don't be a pleb; invest $20 and roughly 4 hours into ‘Gone Home.’ This is interactive storytelling at its finest, surely. To date, I’ve never experienced something so affecting—I’m close to speechless, really.  The narrative effortlessly compels you to connect those all-important dots; it unfolds in teasing dribs and drabs, and in the last moments, when everything comes to a head, its staggered assemblage makes *perfect* sense.   ‘Gone Home’ is a bizarrely voyeuristic, yet entirely personal experience. Words don’t do it justice. Just buy it, and then experience the cascade of feels. So many feels. :’D

You get home from your exchange in Europe and no one is home. Where is everyone? Let's go through all their stuff and find out what they've been up to for the last year! This is probably the first game I've ever played, and knowing the game industry, the last one I ever will, to deal sensitively and maturely with the subject of being a lesbian teenager. The story is well told and reasonably well written, and you become attached to the characters and trying to piece together their lives by rifling through their sock drawers. The game is pretty much 'on rails' , as in, you don't find out anything before you are 'supposed' to. Linearity is often necessary to tell a good story when the story is pre-defined. A good linear game makes you feel like you're in charge. Gone Home succeeds at this quite well. Get it if you like interactive stories of the non 'Zork' variety. If Dear Esther intrigued you at all this is a must have. If you are the dork who had to read every book on the shelf in Myst you will love this game. If you hated DE, like I did, get it anyway because it's an example of what the genre can be if done correctly.
A good story but a rather short game; would recommend for all gamers who love indie adventures
So many layers! The game is over in only about 4 hours, but will definitely stay with you for a long time.
I cried like a ♥♥♥♥♥.

Absolutely fantastic. I was scared at first (and at one point at midnight, a light switched off and I nearly ♥♥♥♥ myself) but it evolves into a beautiful storyline that almost brought a small, manly tear to my eye. Interaction is great, the graphics are perfect. It is as close to snooping around someone's house as you could possibly get. I couldn't recommend it enough.

I ended up liking this game much more than I thought I would. I normally don't like games that are just walking and nothing else, but this one pulled it off so well. It was nothing like what I expected. Nothing much happens all game, but I still found myself glued to it for the 2 or so hours I was playing it. Highly recommended

Disclaimer, I got it one sale for around 5€.  I sat down a cold and dark december evening. The wife and kid was away for the evening, so it was only me, the dog, the rain, a few candles and a blanket. So with my headphones on, I was ready for a history to unfold.  The game, and house, ooze of atmosphere. You move around in your own tempo, and let it all sink in. I really liked how the mood was set, and how the story was told. I was left with a weird feeling in my chest, I was fulfilled, but I wanted to do something. So I sat down and wrote this.  Everything in this game is about the story and the mood. The story is not a Stephen King novelle, eventhough it's obvious that the writer of the game have taken some inspiration. But it is good, charming and doesn't overstay its welcome.  The music also really help setting the mood, but some of it was actually somewhat of an annoyance, but it did fit in the story, so I guess I can't complain.  I think I would feel lacking if I had paid full price for the product, but I really don't know. Even 30 minutes after I finished the game, I am still left with a feeling of having played a remarkable product.  But I have to stress, this game is not for everyone. But if you like to explore and want a good movie-game-story, you should give it a try.

This game is to put it blatantly , ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful.  'Gone Home' is one of those things that isn't really a game, it is a experience and if you dont like these types of games you should probably turn back now. It's about returning home to the families manor and finding out just what has happened in the two years you have been gone. It does this is such a way as to drive you into a amazingly powerful story full of little details snips of information you didn't NEED to know but you wanted to , thus it exists as if for once the devs cared about the feelings of the player getting involved rarther than the profits. If I say anymore I may ruin the experience for you just buy this thing a game, an experience, whatever you want to call it it's great.    9.5/10

Where is everyone when you return from your trip? There are clues everywhere you look. The title tells you the answer, but you can't understand it until you've played. A lovely, somple, engrossing game.

I try to put into words what Gone Home is and why it works. But it can’t be done. Play it. Now. It is not for everyone sure, if you are looking to run and gun then look elsewhere. If you want an immersive experience, great soundtrack, familiar atmosphere, and a touching and unique love story then Gone Home is yours to keep. Game of the Year? Absolutely. This is definitely one of the greatest games I have ever played. And whether you are a gamer or not you should experience it.
One for the nostalgic. The story is quite sweet, if not overly simplistic, but the atmosphere is supurb and it's always fun to listen to garage rock while you cautiously step though a creepy house.

Great game, with so much wasted potential. An extremely innovative concept and game design executed to perfection. Unfortunately, while the game sets itself up perfectly to be a chilling psychological thriller..  (SPOILER ALERT) it ends up going the opposite direction. I just can't help but think the developers had bigger plans for this game, then shifted directions and cut development short for some reason. In any event, it is probably not worth $20, but its originality, design, and execution are worth experiencing, albeit probably at a lower price point.
It's short but worth picking up during a steam sale.

I honestly didn't know what to expect when I started playing this game, but as I got more and more into the story I found myself both a little creeped out by the emptiness of the house and the weather outside, as well as following along closely with the journal entries that I found. I thoroughly loved this game, not for its gameplay, or it's action, but for its realism and story. The house felt real, so much so that I felt creeped out by the thunderstorm, as if it were really happening. If you love a game for its realism and story, then I highly recommand getting this game. If you're a big fan of Halo, this might not be for you.
Give it a try if you like story driven games. Really short but definitely worth it.

Gone Home is such an intruiging and interesting game. After only 1.5 hours, I'm loving it. This is a tough game to describe. There are no enemies and no real puzzles, but the game is totally engrossing. If you grew up in the 90s, you are gonna feel at home in the house you explore; the amount of detail, from VHS tapes with 90s decade TV shows and movies to the little glow in the dark stars on bedroom ceilings, this game has it all so near perfect. The mysteries that lie in the house are what drives you to play. What will the next room be? What will this hidden crumpled letter tell me about someone. This is a game that you have to experience to grasp it, but it is so worth it. So far, so good. I'm thoroughly enjoying Gone Home so far and I imagine it only gets better from here.

Beautiful. SImple. Heartwalking. At the end of the game you feel a connection to the events that transpired , you are ultimately happy about the outcome. for somethine so simple to make me have a tear in my eye surprised me , but its something that is beautiful in its own right.   9.9/10

Fantastic story telling, amazing attention to detail, and one hell of a voice actress. Take your time with this gem as it's only 2-3 hours, but there is tons to see. Lots of little twists all along the way will certainly keep you entertained. One warning: this is a story, do not go in expecting a traditional game.

This is a revolutionary game that pushes the medium into new territory. It avoids any kind of combat, though still manages to be slightly scary at times, and tells a mature and interesting story about young love and the lives of family members by simply allowing you to rummage through your house. It is a story that could not be told as well through any other medium, since it's basically just you looking at your house. The play time is short, but the game is so well thought-out and detailed that it's really not to be missed.

What can the things in your house tell a stranger about you? This is the essence of Gone Home and something you will definitely think about upon completing this game. I understand many people have an issue calling Gone Home a game. This is something that I cannot agree with. Gone Home is as much a game as any other point and click mystery game. This is not just a mystery game but an emotionally charged experience that everyone should feel.   Gone Home makes bold statements about the places we inhabit and the marks we leave on those places that leave clues to who we are and what we believe in. Gone Home was something special too me because of the many emotions it evoked from me throughout the relatively short experience. The atmosphere in the game is surprisingly chilling even though you will never find anything scary. What makes Gone Home something so captivating is the attention to detail put into the house you explore.   The story is also something worth mentioning as I personally found it to be a touching and eye-opening statement about the relationships we have with other people. After playing the game some many months ago I still think about the game and all the things it has made me reflect upon. This is the only game I have played that has stuck with me for such a long period of time after finishing it. Gone Home is the game that will leave you reflecting inwards on what your house might be able to tell a stranger about you and how we affect the different people in our lives.
Just play it. Any information I give you about it would just ruin the amazing wriiten and directed story. Just play it.

Really enjoyed the experience. I found the qualities that kept it in touch with being a game were so well paced out, there were no needless gameplay gimmicks. The sense of discovery, the enjoyment of finding a solution to opening up a new space. Production was perfect, fine voice acting, just the right amount of text to read, wonderful detail in the visuals.  Enjoyed the story, the reveal of the characters, their development and the atmosphere of the world. It was all very believable, meaningfully voyeristic, and fantastically nostaligic for someone that was a teenager during the mid-ninties.   I think one of the biggest things I could say was that it really entertained my non-gameplaying girlfriend, whom I have never really witnessed her taking much note of any game before.

Was pretty swell. It was written pretty well and was pretty fun unraveling the story. I don't believe I've really pieced together all the stuff that can be learned about the other characters in the tale but I explored a lot of the game and enjoyed what I found.  The mechanics feel very similar to Amnesia if you've ever played that. This may be based on the same engine.

I knew this game wasn't a 'normal' game before I bought it, so I knew what to expect. That said, I'm very happy with where it went with the story and how well it piqued my curiousity to explore until I finally finished the game.   It's a short game (~2-3 hours) but it's such a unique experience that I think developers will take note and try to encorporate Gone Home's ideas into their games. If for nothing else, it's worth a playthrough to see why it was on so many 2013 Game of the Year lists, and where video games can, and should, go in the future.

An Adventurous game.  I give it cat/10... it's THAT good.  ~~~~ [EDIT] What are you still doing here? Just go play it, the reviews aren't going to help you and you shouldn't be reading them anyways. ~~~~

My goodness. My  goodness. .  Gone Home  is something very special. It is a game of remarkable gentleness and compassion, and has a story that brought tears to my eyes on several occasions.   Too, it serves as a beautiful look at life in the decade of my childhood, without ever being uncritical or gushingly nostalgic.  There is little more that I can say here, but much I would like to after you play it. Please do, please do, as soon as you can.

Gone Home is the first game I've bothered writing down a review for 10/10 while a bit taxing on any computer system it scared me, warmed my heart, mad me sad, and made my skin crawl if you like mystery with a dash of spooky this is the game for you.

This is a great game that was very interesting. The graphics looked good and the soundtrack was amazing along with other rock songs that I enjoyed a lot. The games topic may offend some people but I can’t say much more than that without spoiling anything for you. controls were good but sometimes felt a little slow. sometimes I got confused about where to go because it was that out in the open to me but that is part of the fun of the game is exploring this big house and looking for secrets. 9/10

I first became interested in playing this game when I read a rant from some one saying that it isn't a video game. I know, odd right? The thing is that it got me interested in how it possibly couldn't be one, and now that I've played it I'm even a little bit more boggled how some one might think that it isn't a video game. The play here isn't in complicated game mechanics. The game is in the player's imagination, and this game is very good at playing with the imagination.  I loved this game and plan to play through it many more times. I find myself wanting to pick up every item in a room. I read every page that I found. I smiled at the details. Things like how a young kid would put stickers on their story and spell the word 'liar' as 'lier'. Or things like how tempting it was to crawl into the couch fort and listen to the severe storm warning.  The game plays well off of other parts of the imagination. Namely in how the game is set-up. I don't want to give too much away because this is really the type of game that people should just jump into and play. The lighting in the game sets such a great mood, and since the player is dropped into such an odd circumstance it feels like a ghost or a murderer could be around a corner at any time. The game feels like that moment when you walk into your house, all the lights are off, and no one is home.  I'm sure this game isn't for everyone. It's on the short side of things at about two and a half hours if you really explore. There really isn't any action to the game either. The enjoyment is in searching around and piecing together your own stories from all the scattered clues. If searching every nook and cranny is something that you love to do in games this one is right up your alley.
Excellent immersion and art-like gameplay.

You are an older sister who returns home (from a year abroad in europe) to a new family home you have never been in before,and no one is home. You find out your younger sister is a lesbian (not the hot kind) as she left little notes all around the damn house like some crazy OCD person for you to find! Cool GAME, but overall a missed opprotunity to have a steamy lesbo sex scene.

A lot of people hate the becasue its not really much of a gme and/or they don't like the story. I enjoyed the experince (not worth the $20 in my opion, but that why I got it on sale). the twist is seen from a mile away and it a cliche but not a bad story. I'd say pick it up during a sale if your interested
A very touching tail about a sister coming home to an empty house, and snooping around her sister's stuff. I can't spoil it for you but there are no monsters that pop out at you, just feels.
The best narrative experience I have ever had in a video game
An interesting exploration game based around journal entries, that kinda pretends to be a horror game. Not really worth $20 for a 2 hour 'game'.

When I finished this game, I wanted to immediately run through it a second time.   The game is short, but also poignant, interesting, and beautiful.  Most importantly however, the game highlighted for me the fact that game stories still try to be Hollywood movies. Video games are an interactive medium. To limit games to the types of stories we have limits the art form immensely.   Gone Home has no combat, no puzzles, and no central conflict. But it is a shining example of what we can do with this medium. I have played video games for nearly 20 years. The fact that it took this long for me to experience something like Gone Home saddens me. But the existence and success of Gone Home give me hope for the future of this art form.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who is invested in video games as an art and believes there is something truly powerful about games' interactive nature.

I really enjoyed this game. But I think that's mainly because I only paid $2.99 for it. If I had paid the full $19.99 I would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The story is touching and lovely and they really know how to set an atmosphere. But that's all it is. Good atmosphere and a great story.  It's not long either. I beat the game in an hour and a half.  So, do I recommend it? If you really enjoy a good story then yes but only at the Steam sale price.  If you want more out of your games then go somewhere else because it's not here.

The story of this game was excellent and unexpected. Lots of fun. It was very mysterious and it required lots of attention to detail to uncover everything. I definitely recommend this game highly. The story made me very emotional, especially towards the end.
I think this game is worth it while the steam sales are on. It's short but packed with emotion, like you're playing a movie.
What a wonderful story and experience. I'm really glad I picked this up. Yes, it is short and the replay value is pretty low, but its still worth grabbing. I do not regret it.
Wow, that was simply beautiful. If you enjoy playing the same old ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ over and over again, don't get this wonderfully inventive gaming experience.
Brilliant story, presented in an engaging and suspenseful way.  Definitely worth the price!

This exploratory game has a great atmosphere, and delivers a fantastic narrative about the struggles of an ordinary '90s family, and an ordinary teenage girl trying to deal with all the angst and questions of sexuality that come with growing up. I felt very engrossed in the game's world, and was surprised at how deeply I cared for the characters.  However, I don't think the game is necessarily worth its current price-point of $20. It took me 4 hours to get through the whole thing, and I basically explored every nook and cranny. If you can get it on sale, though, this is an exploratory narrative you shouldn't pass up!
One of the most amazing games I have ever played, Well. Not really a game. More like a Mystery/Story.   Perfectly written and great to just get in the atmosphere of it.

i feel like there are a lot of negative reviews for this game, so i wanted to offer my slightly more positive opinion. yes, this game is short. i finished it in 2 hrs but i think it could be done in 1.5 hrs easily. it's completely exploratory and has a good story, which is something i love. the way that the story comes together is beautiful. it's almost like an interactive book. it also deals with things that i enjoy and can relate to. i think to enjoy this game you have to be invested in the story because the gameplay is so simple, so if queer teenage feminists in the 90s aren't your thing, then i'd suggest you skip this one.  my final opinion is that this game is not worth the $20 they're asking for. i paid $6.50 for it and i'm satisfied with that price. if you can catch it on a sale, buy it. the story is great, and the way it is delivered is great, but the price is too high.
Very good and interesting game. Whether or not it is worth the price tag is debatable but it's still very good. You should get it on sale like I did to avoid buyer's remorse.
Great exploration game with good graphics, amazing attention to detail, and a story that will not just pull your heartstrings, but give them a yank that will make most cry at the end.

Its a really good game, very interesting, quite different from anything I've played before. It was origionally an amnesia mod just like stanly parable was a HL2 mod. It's an hour or so long if you find it for like a euro get it, I promise you that you spent the same amount of money on something that is not even half as good as this.

BUT. That's the first word I feel I need to use. This game is fantastic, and I thoroughly enjoyed the two hours I spent with it BUT I have to admit it's not a game for everyone (in fact I'd say it's for a minority quite possibly). I know, I know... it sounds so typical, yet it really is the truth. It's a short game with almost no gameplay whatsoever, and the plot is nothing to write home about (pun intended). The story is a whole different animal, however, even if I'd argue that it's not so much a story as it is perhaps a portrait. A picture of a family in just a few strokes. It's not quite original, and as far as plots go, it's mostly predictable. What really makes it stand out is the way you experience it, bit by bit, peeking at things you probably shouldn't be seeing.  *(Extremely light SPOILERS)*  In a way, you're getting to know the family, as if you really had been away for a long time. You learn what's changed in the last months, and you get some insight into what each of the family members feels deep inside. As said, it's done with brevity and somewhat vaguely. Not very subtly at times, but in the end, it really gives you a strong sense of where is everyone at in their lives.  *(And we're out of spoiler territory).*  Wether you'd like it or not is hugely dependent on your taste and interests. One could draw a useful comparison to films. If you enjoy emotional, introspective films, very light on plot and action, you might find this game interesting and possibly even enjoy it quite a bit. If you'd rather watch a more traditional film (and I mean no disrespect, I do enjoy traditional films too!) you might want to pass.  At any rate, I do agree with most other reviewers in that the price seems a bit too steep. The cinema comparison is again relevant here, for the experience is not only similar, but it also lasts for about the same time and has comparable 'replay' value. Fortunately, I did get it on sale, and for 6-7€ or less it's certainly worth picking up.
Simply the best writing gaming has seen in a long time. Clever, funny, sad, silly, and evocative.
Fantastic game! Amazing story! It's truly a fantastic exploration game.
Some people call this a walking simulator, I just call it a great story, beautifully told.

Ok first this is all you need to know before you buy that game . If you're looking for any action related games with objectives and stuff you probably won't find any in it . BUT ! This game has a lot to offer in the ways that it's built . Honestly i really liked this game not for the fact that it's also familial and has many ways of reminding you the 90s typical cool stuffs only but also because you get to learn about your family the more and more you find clues . This game is either gonna make you skip everything and not qppreciate the game at all or calmly enjoy every writings you find in the multiple rooms . I honestly loved this game as it brough emotionals vibes and made me love the story . Just for the mood it puts while you almost feel like you're getting near to your family i think it is great and well done . I give it 10/10 and honestly for a game that most people won't find it a 'game' i think it deserves to be bought and appreciated . <3 Love you all

I adored this game. Honestly. Regardless of the debate it's sparked about what exactly constitutes a 'game,' this is a beautiful story cloaked in incredible atmosphere. If you don't prioritize strory, you won't like this game. Period. It's a visual novel of sorts, and I am so so glad I was able to play it. I would reccoemend getting it on sale, since it is only about a two hour game. And i certainly reccomend it to all the young queer girls who aren't sure if it'll get better. :)

Picked it up on sale and def got my money's worth.   Avoid the spoilers, here's what you need to know: There is no combat, chasing, or dying. (And that is a great thing for this game!) It may startle or freak you out at times. Immerse yourself in the every bit of the story that you can find, and you'll have a blast. Lastly, after the game is done, you can go back to explore more.  Those are the things I wish I knew when I started, so maybe this will help you too. Support great indie games with new, and inventive story telling! Buy it now!!!

One of the most emotionally satisfying games I've played in years. It's short, but it's a great example of a well told, nuanced story told through a game. After finishing it I can't stop thinking about it.

A wonderful experience. The total gameplay I put in was about 2 hours which just flew by. The story that you uncover while exploring the house is a heart-warming and insightful one. Well worth the $10.
loved it. <3
I absolutely loved this game. Don't expect to have much fun playing it, the beauty is in the storytelling and exploration. WARNING: You may come down with a bad case of 'the feels.'

Pretty cool story if you are into solving mysteries. Not $20 dollars cool but totally $5 bucks cool. Highly recommend if it's on sale!  PS - To get the full effect you MUST play this at night with all the lights turned off. The experience probably won't really be half as good during the day.

Gone Home tells the most personal narrative I've ever experienced in a video game. The ease with which it manages to make its characters relatable and the situations they find themselves in resonate on an emotional level, as well as its wonderfully heartfelt and earnest delivery, left me with the impression that with Gone Home, developer The Fullbright Company was telling somebody's story. But this small, intimate tale of family, adolescence and self-realization is told with all the confidence of a grand epic.  Set during a dark and stormy summers night of the mid-nineties, Gone Home casts you as Katie, a young woman who has just returned to her parents suburban home in Oregon after a yearlong trip across Europe. Much like the player, Katie is a stranger to her parents' new house. However, instead of a warm welcome, Katie finds the ominous building dark and empty, with a mysterious note from her younger sister on the front door.  Of course the mansion itself holds the answer to many of the questions this set-up evokes. Piecing together just what exactly happened while you were gone and figuring out where your family is consists largely of exploring Gone Home's many rooms, with the house acting as both a well designed puzzle for the player to work through, and an essential narrative device.  Gone Home's setting is filled to the brim with interactive objects, revealing notes and high-resolution artwork. It's a masterpiece of environmental story-telling, with every small detail adding to your understanding of the people that make up Katie's family.  Its intricate recreation of a suburban home of the nineties is almost uncanny: it's the furniture, the wallpapers and the many small touches like scattered VHS tapes and cassettes, complete with labeled sheaths. In fact, my only criticism of Gone Home is that, at times, the recreation feels almost too perfect, too meticulously designed.  The main narrative thread revolves around Katie's younger sister Sam, as she guides you through the past year of her life and acts as a narrator of sorts with journal-entries scattered around the house. Smart, witty, rebellious and lively, she's the type of person that I wish I could have been at her age. Her growth into womanhood is a captivating story and marks Gone Home's emotional core. It's brought to life with some fantastic writing and exceptional voice-work.  Katie herself never really plays an integral role in Gone Home's story. Instead, she serves as a vessel and emotional anchor for the player. This slight disconnect actually works to the story's favour, as it allows the player to come in without any pre-conceived notions on the family and yet still have some connection to the world and characters.  However for all the touching moments and heartfelt emotions that Gone Home so deftly portrays, one other emotion dominated a large part of Gone Home for me: fear. For the majority of my time with it, I played Gone Home like I would a horror game: clinging to the lights, avoiding the shadows, getting startled by every little sound and taking short brakes to catch my breath. The dark hallways of the house are deeply unsettling at first. I almost expected a monster to jump out of the closet, or to catch a glimpse of a ghost out of the corner of my eye. But there is no monster, and no ghost. Gone Home evoked the same fear in me, that I get when I walk around in a dark and lonely house -- the fear of that which does not exist.  But my relationship with Gone Home's setting gradually evolved. As I started turning on more lights and familiarizing myself with the layout of the house, my fears began to vanish. What I at first perceived to be a gloomy and uninviting mansion, now felt like a cozy and warm place, a treasure trove of human stories and emotions -- a home.  In the span of a mere two hours, Gone Home took me through an emotional roller-coaster that few games have been able to match, starting with the suspenseful unease of a super-natural mystery and ending with a beautiful emotional pay-off. By the end, I didn't know whether to laugh or cry, so I did both. Even thinking about it now makes my heart swell with a rush of emotion.  Final Words:  In many ways, Gone Home is very mundane -- a slice of life, captured in a quaint suburban home. But it's ultimately this mundanity that sets Gone Home apart. Through it, the Fullbright Company explores a set of human emotions that games rarely deal with -- and rarer still so well. Players who grew up in the 90's will undoubtedly appreciate all the small particularities of the era, but Gone Home's narrative themes are universal. There's something for everyone to relate to in this understated, introspective masterpiece and anyone with even the slightest interest in the possibilities of narrative in games should play Gone Home.
Game of the year. A masterpiece.
Just buy it already, seriously. It's wonderful.
The kind of game you'd show someone who's never played a game in their life.

I have no words. its like nothing i have every played. i wouldnt call it a game its more like a interative short story. a tad creepy at times but you follow a very emotional story. recomend playing it alone with no distractions. an awesome way to end the night, well only if youre a big softy like me

Aside from the incredibly short length netting in at 2 hours average, Gone Home is still nonetheless a brilliant story based game. You will either love it or hate it.   The characters (only 2 are important) have genuine personality told through the letters and objects you find as you explore the house. Important items and clues play voice tapes, which reveal more story. In the end I genuinely connected with them, and they felt real.  There's no real sense of gameplay, the interface is minimal and as far as the investigation elements go you'll tend to keep all the clues in short term memory. With Gone Home It's all about the story, and the story is only meant to be played once. If you get it on sale, like I did, you won't feel ripped off. If investigation and exploration (i.e. Games As Art) aren't your area then this won't be for you.

What an astonishing, unique way to take me on an incredibly personal journey with no on-screen characters. The game narrates by 'journals' from the main character's sister, which are read aloud in the sister's voice with the sister's tone, and that, truly, is where the game gets you. It's bits of story separated by multiple minutes of exploration in which you come to draw your own conclusions about what is going on, and wait for the next chapter.   For me, personally, I've never played a game that makes me *feel* much of anything, until this.

This game is short and revolves around exploring a house and filling in the gaps of a story that has already transpired. If that's not appealing to you from a gameplay standpoint, don't play this game.  If you want a story that's evocative and touching, tapping into some real emotions and their impact on people, play this game. If you want a story about women, particularly queer women, play this game.  To say any more would honestly ruin the experience. Just let Gone Home happen to you. Play it in a single sitting, let it envelop you in its setting and story.

Warning, this is not an full review just my final thoughts about this game.  This game let you go anywhere you want but still it follows an liniair path. You need to find 1 thing to open up another thing and so pogress the story. There are nice little details in the game that doesnt affect the story like soda cans and bottles, ect. There are also many things to read if you want but most of the things only tells you something about the life of the people there.  I completed the game in 1.4 hour's and i think thats far to short. I want to give this an yes/no but i cant. So i say a yes because i think for what the game does it does good and i mostly dislike leaving negative reviews.  -Sorry for my bad english

It's one of these popular arty walking games like Stanley Parable and Dear Esther where the primary gameplay is what you missed and observed from the experience and how you choose to explore each corner of the room. This is a game for observant players who enjoy a slower and methodical approach to games.  I adore simple interaction that you wouldn't see in a lot of games today such as rotating and looking for nuances at the back of each book or cassette tape cover.   If you don't care for the story at all or if the premise of walking around a seemingly mundane mansion isn't that exciting for you, don't bother playing this game at all. At least the storytelling is integrated with the game mechanics and rarely relies on cutscenes which is a sign of decent narrative gameplay  Narrative wise and mild spoilers ahead...     I applauded the game's theme of sexuality and gender and its subversive nature to mainstream games.

Short but interesting, particularly if you would like to see first person games that aren't about shooting. I got to the end of Bioshock Infinite and thought 'My girlfriend would enjoy this if it didn't involve 15 hours of killing things.' and Gone Home occupies that niche nicely. Try to get it on sale though, it's only 2-3 hours of fun.

Amazing game, if you can call it that. It is more or less a story of a family and their struggles that you have to piece together by rummaging through the house. It is very immersive, complex, and well thought out. A must play in my opinion.
Fantastic direction in gaming
2 words: Lesbian Sex
90s nostalgia blast. Had fun, would recommend.

This is a wonderful game. I recommend it to everyone. You will be injected into a persona and a place, and you will want to know who you are and who your family is.  Is there something wrong with the world that $20 is a completely fair price for the amount of work that goes into this, yet most people would consider it a $5 entertainment escape at most? Possibly. Do I regret having spent $10 on it? No.

If your goal is to 'win,' this game isn't for you. On the other hand, if you enjoy uncovering every detail in an environment, give Gone Home a try. While the primary storyline is provided through excerpts from your sister's diary, many of the interesting elements of the larger story (of what has been happing in the family while you've been studying abroad) are revealed only through careful examination of artefacts around the house. It's true that the game is short and the 'clutter' objects are quite repetitive (how many times do we have to look at the same pens and soda cans?), but the sense of discovery is still worth it (though picking the game up on sale is probably a good idae).

Gone Home is a rather straightforward game but it feels, looks, and plays pretty well, this is one of those kind of games that really will get you stuck in a certain part of the game, so i think that you should play it for a while to get used to it, in my opinion it was worth the money, but it was pretty friggin' confusing, becuase you'll never know where to go, it also has a bit of emotion to it, the only problem there is that it doesn't get across very well.

Short, Sweet, and Nostalgic. A little too short for the price tag. But, just sweet and nostalgic enough to tell an emotional and endearing stroy. It gives me hope for the future of storytelling in videogames. Definilty worth playing when it drops to a $2.50-$5.00 price.
a solid game... worth the 20 bucks... kind of slow... but the story is amazing
Great period game. This is set right when I started playing PC games.

This was simply the best game I have played this year. Short, but amazing narrative. Took only a few hours, but now I'm truly hooked. I even looked up the full story online to see if I missed anything. I also looked up the soundtrack. To my amazement the soundtrack is by some small time artist. Just wow! Could it get any better? A sequel perhaps? A must play for 2013, going into 2014.

This was a very touching game -- I had to stop playing a few times just to think about some of the concepts raised. If you've got two or three hours to just sit around and play a thought-provoking game, I'd say this is an excellent use of that time.
Certainly the greatest video game story I've ever experienced. Done with so much purpose... perfect.

Once I beat this game, I was like wtf did I just play, but it's been about a week now and I think about the game alot. It sticks with you after you play it. I only paid 5$ for it so it was well worth it, but I would not recommend this game for full price, wait for it to go on sale. 8/10
This is most definitely a game and a very good one.

This is a great game that was very interesting. The graphics looked good and the soundtrack was amazing along with other rock songs that I enjoyed a lot. The games topic may offend some people but I can’t say much more than that without spoiling anything for you. controls were good but sometimes felt a little slow. sometimes I got confused about where to go because it was that out in the open to me but that is part of the fun of the game is exploring this big house and looking for secrets. 9/10
It's got a tampon in it.

This game took me a lot less time to finish than all the other posters' times that I read before purchasing. The storyline was interesting, but seemed shallow in terms of character plots other than the main protagonist. I'm hoping I just missed some content; but is unfortunate that a certain trigger ends the game even if you have not heard the whole story. Will have to play again--I think it would be worth it.
Has a very great story! One that I will never forget! Even though it may not have action like most games, the story that is revealed within this is worth it!
This is an excelently crafted game.

I really enjoyed this game. But I think that's mainly because I only paid $2.99 for it. If I had paid the full $19.99 I would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The story is touching and lovely and they really know how to set an atmosphere. But that's all it is. Good atmosphere and a great story.  It's not long either. I beat the game in an hour and a half.  So, do I recommend it? If you really enjoy a good story then yes but only at the Steam sale price.  If you want more out of your games then go somewhere else because it's not here.

Guys... this game is great! It tells a wonderfull story, extremely emotional and well done! I don't recommend it if you don't enjoy games that revolve around story with almost no gameplay. I really enjoyed because I love shorter experiences like journey, Dear Esther, Protheus, that are kinda weird but just let you relax and enjoy the show. For 20$ its a little much, so wait for a good sale! 75% is pretty good!  Not everyone will like it, but as I said, If you like a story driven, short, simple and relaxing game.. this game is perfect for you!

This game was simply astonishing. It is a relatively short, but very immersive experience. Throughout the game, the player must unravel the mystery to the dissapearance of her family. I would strongly recommend this game to any fan of indie games or to anyone who appreciates a great story telling experience. This is a perfect game for new or casual gamers.

I just finished playing Gone Home, while I must say that it was a very entertaining experience, probably the only and biggest problem is that it waaaaay too short. I managed to finish the game in less than two hours while examining every corner and object in the game. The game itself is wonderfully made, you stroll around the house uncovering the secrets that led to the situation at hand. I would highly recommend this game but only if it is on sale, it is definitely not worth it's full price. I hope that if there is a sequel, that it will be much longer than this.

Despite being VERY VERY VERY VERY short, it is interesting and unique I suppose. I do however feel a bit ripped off that I payed full price for it rather than wait for it to come up on sale. Seriously, NOT worth $20 at all for a less than 2 hour game. But if you want to check it out, it is definitely worth paying a few bucks for.

Insanely good story line. Beware, this is not a game, but an interactive story. All you do is explore a house trying to solve puzzles while piecing together the story of your family over the last year.

I don't know where to start with this game. Not saying it in a bad way, but in a very good way. Gone Home is very unique unlike the first-person games now-a-days. If you were looking for a first-person shooter with limbs flying everywhere... This is not a game for you, which I am sure you would know that probably because you have seen a trailer or two of the game. Gone Home is a story based adventure-ish? game that ttakes you back to the mid-1990's. Although you play a different character in the game, it is a story about your sister Sam, who narrates about the few adventures that she had while you were away on your trip. But the one main adventure that runs through the rest is her friendship with a girl named, Lonnie. It is quite a lovely story, some parts happy and funny, some are drenched in sorrow and sadness. I wish I could go more into detail with the story line, but I am not a spoiler. Throughout the exploration of your house (A big house I might add) you find many neat things around every corner. Letters, (Which you will see a ton of) cool items that most 90's kids would understand, (Recommened for 90's kids!) and tons of soda cans. Some items that you pickup push the storyline forward. I wanted to get to each key item as fast as possible to see what the next part was going to be about (Gripping story if you ask me!). A lot of the things you think you can't interact with, you actually can, so search every part of each room. Also, a few of these items are pretty funny. Plus, the kick ♥♥♥ cassette tapes rock! Mainly the only thing that I thought was bad, was the shortness of the game. If you have read more reviews about Gone Home, one of the things you will hear is, 'Its too short!' or 'Very short game!'. I have no problem with the game being short, maybe if they could just put an extra 20 (30?) minutes into it. If you dont like short games... Dont play it. I reccomend buying it when it is on sale (Holiday sale, Summer sale, etc.). Overall, it was a touching game. I loved the story that was pulled you in with curiosity and adventure. It was heart-warming, wishing that something like this could happen to me as well, seeing that this storyline very much relates to many people who have been in Sam's shoes.   Pros:  -Graphics -Interaction -Storyline (Loved it!) -The secrets... 0.0 -Everything else!  Con (Thats right, only one!):  -Wish it was a little longer   Recommendation to:  -People who love a good story -Exploration -People who enjoy non-violent games -90's kids!

Gone Home is one of those select few indie games that truly makes you think about what gaming can be. This game illustrates a narrative that allows you to discover what's happening, rather than it being blantantly told to you. Gone Home gives the player a sense of mystery and discovery as you progress through the game, and gives you a sense of enlightenment once you've reached the resolution of its journey. If you are a fan of narratives, mystery, or story telling then this is a must have game.
Don't miss this beautiful experince. It's one of the most emotional ride in gaming i've ever had!
two thumbs up jew suck yeah!
A unique story telling experience. Like portal but without the portals.

Good story line and good placement of story elements within the house. I would had liked to have seen more explanations about the 'creepy house' and background about the people who lived in it before. Also, the parents and your character seemed flat and uninteresting. Overall worth the $5 when it was on sale but I don't think I would had spent more than that since I got throught the whole game in about an hour and a half.

Good story line and good placement of story elements within the house. I would had liked to have seen more explanations about the 'creepy house' and background about the people who lived in it before. Also, the parents and your character seemed flat and uninteresting. Overall worth the $5 when it was on sale but I don't think I would had spent more than that since I got throught the whole game in about an hour and a half.
It's like playing a short story. An awesome exploration into the 'games as art' genre. I teared up a bit.

I loved the story of this game! The only issue is that the game is super short, only around 2 hours or so. I want more! This game is purely story so don't go in expecting anything other than a interactive novel type game.
Great experience. I'd wait for it on sale as it is short.

Pretty cool story if you are into solving mysteries. Not $20 dollars cool but totally $5 bucks cool. Highly recommend if it's on sale!  PS - To get the full effect you MUST play this at night with all the lights turned off. The experience probably won't really be half as good during the day.

I ended up liking this game much more than I thought I would. I normally don't like games that are just walking and nothing else, but this one pulled it off so well. It was nothing like what I expected. Nothing much happens all game, but I still found myself glued to it for the 2 or so hours I was playing it. Highly recommended

Incredible game, terrifying atmosphere, but still an incredible game! Takes you through a nostalgic journey while still having a fascinating story, though one with some very dark undertones.  Still, good to keep in mind that it's a very short story!
Great adventure game/mystery.
Incredible and thought provoking!

I sat down for two hours and played Gone Home without thinking at all about the time it would take. It felt like an eternity of endlessly wading through the intricate personal relationships of four characters, like lifetimes of memories shrunk and compressed into perfectly formed pieces of memories. You'll feel as though you took so long figuring out the true nature of Sam's disappearance, but not long enough. I want more.
Brilliant storytelling in a manner only the Fullbright Company can execute.

At first I had no idea what I was getting into but had been told it was a great game. I got it on sale (steam sales rule!) and immediately starting playing it. What I got out of it was completely unexpected. The game is able to pull at your heartstrings quite well with its emotionally powerful story. The voice acting is superb and I had a blast trying to find the next piece of information needed to advance the story. I highly recommend it. Yes the story is extremely plain and cliche, but I still enjoyed it. I guess I am weird in that I like to explore peoples houses and see the stupid ♥♥♥♥ they have. If you dont care about that and arent going to buy the game then let me say this:*SPOILER* lesbian love story. While you don't get to see anything, the mind is a beautiful thing...wink wink.

An Adventurous game.  I give it cat/10... it's THAT good.  ~~~~ [EDIT] What are you still doing here? Just go play it, the reviews aren't going to help you and you shouldn't be reading them anyways. ~~~~
Fun to look around and see the life that happened in the house and while it only lasted 60 or so minuets I really enjoyed it

I have not enjoyed a game this much since i was a kid, this game does not feel like a traditional game.. There's no bosses, no enemies etc. Going home makes you feel like you're in someone's real home with real issues. Amazing game, there's no replay value after you 'beat' it, but it's so satisfying. Please buy this game it is an incredible experience
Nice little story worth 5 Euros in the STEAM SALE.

It's alright.  Gone Home is like a well written short story, an enjoyable snack but leaves one wanting for more substance.  What's there is well done, most objects in the game can be picked up and rotated sometimes revealing little snapshots of the kind of life the people of the house live. The game manages to give characters depth without actually having any visible characters outside of pictures here and there.  The entire house is a time capsule with the game leading the player gently at first and by the nose with a shotgun in the other hand towards the end. The pacing is a bit jarring.  The story is well told however the big revelations may not have their intended impact in this day and age though many of the topics brought up are infinitely relatable.  If it's a light and enjoyable experience you're looking for, Gone Home fits the bill. Those wanting a heartier bite should look elsewhere.

This is a love letter pure and simple. A short story that will probably only take most people an hour or two at the most, but do not let that make you think it is not worth every pennie.  Set in the mid 90's a girls comes home to find her house empty, her parents and sister gone. But why? Following clues around the house will explain why, bit by bit you find out the secrets of her sister Sam. It is done in such a understated, beautiful way that I do believe even the most harded minded of people would have a tear in their eyes.  Beautiful.
Love it, It almost feels like LA Noire. You have to solve puzzles and interact with the world and its objects. Plus with all that you have to put the peices together.
Sorry, The Last of Us. I think I have a new favourite game for 2013...
Gone Home, while suprisingly short, is an amazing take on exploration-based story telling and it's worth it's full price. It would be interesting to see what could be done in a larger setting though.

Gone home is a unique first-person explorer game. There's no action, puzzle or challenges to overcome, what you do for the entire duration of the journey however, is to explore every nook and cranny for information to advance in the game. The characters, setting and tone of the game is laid out elegantly, almost like following a trail of cookie crumbs the creators spread out to guide you from one place to the next, where you learn about yourself (your character) and your family. Most of the story is told throught written letters and notes that you discover throughout the house. The story is well paced and written; culminating into a satisfying over-all experience. There's no denial that the game is short. If you like a unique slice-of-life experience and you're not deterred by the fact that there's a lot of reading to be done, then this game might be something for you.  Rating: Gameplay: 3/6 Story: 5/6 Fun: 4/6 Production value: 5/6 Replayability: 2/6
How is this not listed under horror? This game scares me more than Amensia ever did.

This is a Beautiful game without astonishing graphics or revolutionary game mechanics it simply takes your hand and step by step it tells you a greatly written story.  It's really like reading a good book. Buy it now because it's worth 5$!!

Serious review underneath  I played the game and was a little bit creeped out but very entertained.  Then I read the negative reviews and found some really good and decent and was almost disappointed. But then I read the usual rambling and was very amused.  Then I read the discussion sites and was very very amused.  You can have all that for 2,39 right now! Buy it, play it, get amused. And by buying the game you are destroying all of the games and you participate in the LGBT-Machtergreifung. Who possibly can't want that?  Nah, seriously. Gone Home doesn’t reinvent the wheel. The gameplay is a very basic first person point and click: Look for keys to unlock new rooms where you have to look for new hints or new keys to unlock further areas. There are no difficult puzzles in any way. The Gameplay is much more the vehicle to transport the story which is also not so ground-breaking although there are some details that make it a bit more creepier / deeper (check the forums after you played it). It is not at all about the character you play but of her sister and the personal changes she goes through and the conflicts with her parents that come as consequence. Minor Spoiler:    She doesn’t like a girl the way her parents would like her to.    Anyway: It isn’t not a revolutionary story but it is nonetheless a story worth reading (and you will do some decent amount of reading).  The graphics are basically good I guess. Gone home doesn’t have a special art style but it looks good.   Conclusion: Gone Home is nothing special, neither in the good nor in the bad way. But it is worth giving it a try and exploring it at least when it is on sale (you can “beat” the game without any problem in under two hours when you don’t search for every detail in the story).

Good story, in the same vein as Dear Esther. A lot of cool exploration moments, but we're talking maybe 3 hours of gameplay here. Not nearly worth the full price of $20-- wait til it drops to around $5

This game only takes about an hour to complete, if you're not reading every note and journal, but it's a nice experience (though a bit costly at $20). It starts like a horror game: an empty house in the middle of a thunderstorm, trying to piece together where your family is, but it turns into a bittersweet love story. Not quite what I was expecting. If you can pick it up on sale for $5 or $10 and like a nice exploration story, give this a try. Don't expect much replay value though.
Unique, and wonderful.
This game made me feel so many feels all at the same time

I'm the type of gamer who isn't into the usual 'shooters' (barring Half Life series, Mass Effect series, and their ilk that have engaging stories and role playing adventures). So games like 'Vanishing of Ethan Carter' and 'Gone Home' really speak to me. I really appreciate the story delving into experiences that aren't often included in North American overculture, particularly ones that feature female leading characters. If you are seeking a different kind of gaming experience, one that focuses more on story, mystery, and discovery, this game is for you. This is a game for indie fans.   Only draw backs are the puzzle elements aren't too much of a challenege, and the game is short. I completed it in about 2 hours, and I thought I was 'taking my time' really exploring everything.   There were some creepy moments, especially when you enter dark rooms and can't find the light switches, the TV's are playing looping messages, and other subtle but effective 'jumpy' experiences. The voice acting, art, and stories were very well crafted and believable. This is truly a story that could have happened, and most likely has, representing a well produced piece of historical fiction.   As I was also a teenager in the mid-1990's, it was very nostalgic to see references to homemade 'casette tapes' and references to Kurt Cobain, 'zines, and punk/grunge bands of that area. The game creators captured the ambience of that area well.

Great '90s atmosphere, really takes you back. It pulls you in and makes you want to know just what happened to your family. It really is a unique gem of a timecapsule that has a really gripping story to tell. One that brings out all kinds of emotions. Strongly recommended.

I've not played a game in a long while which I considered as quickly as immersive and evocative of the time like this game is. The tension from the outset, the angst and expected heartbreak of a situation which I wont spoil is wonderfully compelling... I'm reviewing this within two hours. That's how good this game is! Oh and a tip o' the hat to the sound/music guy! It's brilliant!  Edit at 4Hrs: I took my time and finished it. What a gem of a game! A totally beautiful story with characters I connected to immediately. If only the game were longer, not that I mean it was too short. I mean it in the sense I would have loved to have spent more time discovering the secrets of the house.
i'm already home though
Atmospheric, clever and the perfect amount of creepy!

Disclaimer: this game only takes about 2 hours to finish 2nd Disclaimer: I purchased this game at about 90% off so about 1.99 to 2.50ish  The story and emotion conveyed were incredible. I haven't felt so deeply for a character since Last of Us and this game doesn't have any fungus monsters. For the time it took and the price I paid this game was exceptional, however I don't know that I would have felt the same why if I had paid the full $20 dollars.   This is a must buy if you can get it deeply discounted, but it's worth the wait for Steam Sales.

Gome Home is truely fantastic.   It's creepy, it's fun, it's definately one of a kind. Once I started playing it I couldn't stop till I found out what happened!  This game isn't for your typical thrill seeker or FPS junkie. It moves slow, but only at a pace you set. Take your time with this one. Pay attention to the details and take in the whole story.  I have never seen another game like this one and I await another of it's kind.

A nice story game that has you playing a sister who is exploring her family's empty, inherited mansion. It's highly linear and the only real gameplay to speak of is exploring by clicking around the house. It's got a creepy atmosphere at the bigginning but the focus is on the story of the younger sister, with some show-don't-tell story popping up around the mother and father of the family. All of that said, I do recommend this for anyone who likes a nice story. Definitely pick it up on sale, though - it's extremely short, has no replayability, and while it is engaging, it almost isn't a video game so much as an semi-interactive radio play with related visuals provided to enhance the atmosphere of the story.

This one of the best games I have ever played!!!  This truly is one of the best games I have ever played. The story is very good and gets you invested in the characters. The gameplay complements the story and helps you to navigate the story like you are in an interactive movie. But, it is not like any movie you have seen. As you progress through the story you get narrations that help to engross you into a story line that might otherwise have been very bland and unoriginal. The way they let various elements of the game lend themselves to make a very immersive experience.  It is hard for me to find any faults with this game. While it is not a very long game I do not think that it needed to be. The game is well paced. It never rushes or slows down. It adds bits and pieces that nicely build upon one another to create a very unique story telling experience.  Pros: +Fantastic story +Great visuals +Right length, not too long and not too short  Cons: -Nothing, nothing is wrong with this game  P.S. I hope this developer does more games that develop a story this eloquently.
This is an amazing piece of interactive story telling. Compelling exploration and great narration keep the story flowing effortlessly. I highly recommend.
More like a short story than a puzzle game but quite satisfying.

Fun isn't the term that I would associate with this game persay. It is filled with shuffling through papers and exploring a home that doesn't have danger around every corner. This being my first professional review of a game I felt that when I scrolled through the comment sections of this game I felt the overwhelming response against this game almost discouraged me from giving it a try. I do understand those whom paid $20 for a three hour game feel a little shafted, I also completed it under 3 hours and may only have a few notes and things to collect totally up a possible 4hours.
