I wanted to like this game. I really did. I like the idea of telling a story but the story was almost entirely told in the trailers alone.

After reading a bunch of reviews on how 'Gone Home' revolutionises storytelling in gaming, and how it's a deep, rewarding and emotionally rich experience, I decided to give it a spin. What I came across instead was a voyuer's romp through a family home (albeit a well fleshed out retro one), pixel hunting for clues to a story that could be summed up as a hipster's wet dream.  Call me immature, but my character's right click farts in South Park, were far more entertaining and emotionally engaging than my entire run in Gone Home, which I pretty much finished in under an hour.  Avoid, and try something along the lines of 'Papers please' to get your alt gaming fix.

This 'game' isnt really so much a game but an interactive novel. And a shot novel as well. It's a pretty interesting walking simulator, but thats about it. It's also pretty slow paced, it definately fits a niche crowd. If its on sale I would recommend it, but at $20 its theft.

Dull, dull, dull. I guess I am too old to feel at all uplifted by the ending. Instead, my thought is, 'Well, that'll never work out.' If I actually *was* the main character, I'd be pretty annoyed at my family for leaving trash all over our house, and that NO ONE could just put a note and some keys in the entrance way. I wish I could get back the short amount of time I wasted on this game and use it to watch, I don't know, Tavis Smiley or something.

This is more of an interactive story than a game, and so far I don't find the story particularly compelling. I am getting good at turning on lights and reading notes though.  Edit: I've finished the game now, so let me add a few more comments. First, the game is very short - 90 minutes or so. You could probably stretch that out to 2 hours if you obsessively listen to every cassette tape, I guess.  I can also see the game having perhaps a larger appeal if you were a teenager in the early 90s. Although I will say that even as a teenager in the late 80s, I'm surprised at the use of cassette tapes throughout the game vs. CDs.  One final thing I forgot to mention - the Mac port appears to have technical issues. I saw black blobs throughout the game play. In fact, when I first launched it, all I got was a black screen and some music. I was only able to see the game after force-quitting and relaunching. YMMV, of course.
What is that? Obviously not a game! You walk through house with worst GFX last 20 years and read letters??!!! Maybe would be more interesting as text adventure?

This game had great potential. You're supposed to immerse yourself completely, look at every little detail, as if going through a house you deserted for years, and came back and everything is supposed to bring back a memory. The problem is, it's just too short. I completed it within an hour, and once you finish the story, it's hard to go back and try and explore and look / listen to more things.  I only got this for a dollar, and honestly I feel as if it wasen't worth that even.

I am really upset about this game. I thought it was more of a mystery type game. It took me less than two hours to complete and was pretty boring. Glad I bought the game on discount. I don't recommend this game.

Althogh the story of this game is good and the atmosphere in this game is really appropriate, the length of this game is not worth the price. 19 dollars ? I feel a little regretful and I swear that I will never spend money on such a short game unless the price for it is cheap. I thought the elder sister would leave home to look for her little lesbian sister but the game just ended with her little sister's words'we will meet, someday'.

While I can commend the developers for trying something newish, factors like the initial price, time spent playing and the lack of replayability pretty much shoot Gone Home in the foot. Unless you enjoy developer diaries there's no reason to go back to this game and I for one felt ripped off after I was done. If you must get it, get it the next time it goes on sale.

Gone Home combines the excitement of wading through molasses with the fun of reading your family's mail. Turning on every light and faucet, throwing every identical drinking glass and empty binder in the hall, and listening to every awful cassette tape and journal entry will take you about as much time as a trip to the movie theater, and for only double the cost.

The atmosphere works well and the gameplay is simple, but enjoyable. That said, however, the critical acclaim surrounding this game is completely unwarranted and underserved. Sam, your sister, is gay and in love with a high school misfit. The story explores their growing relationship. The problem is, the story is banal. The only twist is that it's about two girls in love, rather than a boy and a girl.  It's a story ripped from any teenage drama you've seen, and were the central characters of the game opposite genders (because the game is really about Sam and her love, not you) no critic in their right mind would be praising it as hard and loudly as they do.  So, if you're just gushing to play any game about lesbian love, I suppose this is a title for you. If you like a good story, there's a lot better out there.
Not a video game. only redeeming quality is that it lasted only 93 minutes.

A graphic adventure game with some survival horror-like elements. A very short one, considering I finished it in less than 2 hours while doing most of the not secret stuff. The developers could have extended the game to include more details about the fathers, Oscar or even Katie, but it is clear they wanted to focus on Sam.  I got this game in a Humble Bundle, but if I paid for it I would not feel satisified.

I'm conflicted: I liked playing through this game/experience, and yet I still don't feel like I should recommend it with much enthusasm. 6.5/10 for me? Some people would probably like it a lot.  I definitely found it compelling to learn about a family by looking at the different artifacts around their house. And it was ultimately interesting to learn why nobody was home. All this involved me going through and opening up every last drawer and cabinet in the house, which was occasionally boring but which was mostly interesting because how often do you get to snoop around a normal family's home like that in real life. The game also reminded me of the quaint old days when we used landlines and answering machines, which was fun.  I think what bothered me was that things weren't realistic, which didn't actually bother me that much while playing the game, but which bothered me in retrospect. I was left with questions like: Why are there so many conveniently useful scraps of paper everywhere? Why am I spending all this time looking at background information I should already know (given that I've lived with these people for years)? Even more so because right now the house is creeping me out a little. What about my sister's situation required her to be so drastic? It also seemed debateable whether it was a good storytelling choice to have my sister read her diary entries before I actually found her diary. (It probably made the story more compelling, but it's a bit lacking in temporal realism.)

Got this for my wife, didn't realize the gameplay time at around an hour, or an hour and half.  She seemed to enjoy it in that time, but from watching over her shoulder:  1) I wouldn't have been happy if this was bought off sale.  2) What is even the point of this?   She said she came home to her parents missing, as well as her sister, but instead of trying to find out what's going on, she's more just walking around the house reliving her lesbian experiences.    So... It's... okay? Maybe? She says 'No, unless you have an hour flight you need to pass time on.'
This game is boring and sucks donkey balls. Not recommended, If i could I would delete it from my library. Boring weak story, thats only 'indie' because it's about lesbians.

Your time could be spend doing far more productive things, like plucking your arm hairs out one by one.

Have you ever watched a movie that looked really great in all the trailers, but then turned out to be a big let down when it finally comes out? This describes Gone Home perfectly. The store page in Steam looks great. It looks like a mystery game with a 90's flashback kind of twist.  Then you start playing. The game environment is gorgeous to say the least. The way the lights and shadows look, the sound of the raging thunderstorm outside, your footsteps on the old wooden floorboards. The ambiance is beautiful. The developers did a great job of sucking you into the game world. But that's sadly where the praise stops.  When they said it's a short game, they aren't kidding. You can finish the game in an hour or two, depending on how thorough you are in your exploration. The story is rather vague to start out, which I suppose is good for a mystery game. But halfway through all the pieces just suddenly and abruptly fall into place, and you know the answer to all your questions at once. There are still a few things left to do before the game is 'done', but you already know how it all ends.  As for the story plot, the word cliche comes to mind, and the little side story (I won't tell you what it is should you still want to play) abruptly ends in a trail of loose ends. This is sad because it was actually more interesting than the main plot.  Oh well. At least there was the nostalgia.
This game costs about 1$ per minute of play time.

Took me an hour to complete the whole 'game' and it is not worth the price. Actually, it should just be free. You spend an hour to find out your sister turned lesbian and run away to find her girlfriend who ditched the army, you're mom is off running around with some man, and your dad is out drunk. It is nothing more than some hidden pro-gay propaganda piece hidden in the guies of an adventure game. If it wasn't for that, I'm sure this game would of not gotten the attection it did. The story is your generic highschool love story, the game's graphics are bland, and the engine loves to jutter for no reason. I had avoided reading the reviews because of spoilers, now I wish I hadn't. It is not revelatory, the greatest love story ever told, or whatever these review sites have dubbed it. This is one of those two bit wattpad love stories set to pritty pictures. Save yourself some rage and buy a game worth buying, unless you like half-baked stories about ignorant high schoolers.

I understand its a graphic adventure game and puzzle games are my favorite but there really weren't even any decent puzzles at all if you consider walking around and looking at paper a puzzle. I'm glad I bought it in the sale instead of paying the full $20 on it. Would not recommend .    SPOILERS AHEAD: The reason why I say the story is decent at best is because it just seems like a generic love story. Two people fall in love and one is leaving somewhere and they can't be together but then they give up their future or whatever to be with the other. Alright fine, generic but they play it off alright. There was just not enough good gameplay though to make it that enjoyable for me.
A boring visual novel about your lesiban sister that isn't good at anything but writing badly.

Highly overrated, cannot see why it won so many game of the year awards. Story is deep, if you consider Twilight to be an epic fantasy drama.   Pick up on sale like I did if you really want to experience it, avoid like the plague at full price.  EDIT: I'd like to add that it is not a bad game and had so many GOTY awards not been thrown at it I mayhave enjoyed it more, but it certainly didn't live up to the hype.

While Gone Home presents a very interactive home from the mid-1990s and has lot of objects you can pick up and read (usually the covers/labels) with perfectly legible writing (unlikem any games where the labels are horrifically low-res) and is a neat '3D point and click' game, it has a very limited audience it would appeal too. The story is about going through the personal belongings of your parents and sister to figure out why they are not home, which is a bit weird TBH, and involves a lot of teenaged angst.   It isn't quite BAD, but it is by no means worth more than a couple bucks, at most, and really isn't something that would interest most people (which makes its length of about ~1.5 hours both a good and bad thing).  It really doesn't live up to the overblown priase it received from a number of 'reviews'.
Developer is a horrible human being

Highly overrated.  Reviewers have been seduced to positively rate a game that utilises a trip down memory lane to a world of retro cassettes and school notes in order to get cool points. Gone Home is a game that definitely has an inkling of a good idea- choosing to make an (barely) interactive world based around the mundane.   It just falls short for me. Excruciatingly short. The experience is simply boring and the narrative not compelling enough to make up for it. I found it difficult to follow which characters were which.   It's a taste of something that could be great and I enjoyed the atmosphere, at times, of the house which pays homage to the likes of Twin Peaks.   Just because a game is different in the right direction - it doesn't make it good.
10/10 - Best disappointment simulator I've ever played.

Far too short and over hyped. 102 minutes to complete. drunk. not a mystery a linear note collecting game.

Well, 'Gone Home' is more of a visual novel than a game. I was attracted by extremely high marks of different gaming sites and promising video. But seriously, this 'game' lasts for ~2 hours maximum and only in case you are looking around every corner like I did. Paying 12 bucks (it's full price in my country) for this is nonsence. I PERSISTENLY do not recommend you buying this game. Better watch it on YouTube.

The only reason I own this is because it was part of an indie bundle that contained some good games I liked the look of. £15 for what amounts to a short novella is a ridiculous price really so even though I am the sort of person who wants to give everything a fair go that initial price barrier is what stopped me.  So I finally got around to seeing what the fuss was about and while I wouldn't call it terrible at all, it's certainly not GOTY material. I started off looking at everything I could (highly recommended to lower mouse sensitivity). Even though I had known about the hidden room with the key to the attic I left it til last since I felt I was going to explore this as intended. Interaction isn't heavy, you can pick up things like cups and specifically placed books but not everything else. There was a letter that lampshaded the whole 'spooky flickering lights' trope that could lead you into thinking this is a horror game. It is not. It is much like exploring the ruins of a building in Fallout as you read old notes, follow along the corridors and come across the remains of the people and what happened to them. However since there is no combat, travelling outside the house or interacting with other people they had to ramp up the effort they put into the story and 'level design'.  The game is teenage lesbian love story with a heavy dose of rebelion. Girl meets girl, girl ends up becoming punk and rebelious like other girl, parents don't like what is going on, other girl has to leave, ect. While the summary may make it seem rather tripe, it's not that bad, it's just not that amazing either. The short story format probably hinders the kind of story they are trying to tell here since you don't get to know the characters long enough for what you find out about them to have much of an impact. While there are a few members of the family the story doesn't touch much on anyone else besides the youngest daughter. In fact you may forget you are playing as the eldest due to how little use of this character is taken. Despite this I actually was disappointed that I heard so little about the mother and father compared to the daughter. Pretty much everything in Gone Hom revolves around the youngest daughter and her girlfriend.  Set design is pretty good for the most part. There are places where thought is put into why certain objects are where they are, you can tell what happened there as a result. There's the rejection letter close to the alchohol, the pillow fort in the TV room, the opened clothes drawers in the parents room and the bottle of hair dye in the bathroom.  The last of which brings me to my next point, the journal entries. As you explore the house you will come across various letters and items. When you pick up certain ones a narrated journal entry of the star of the game is played. I assume that these are all from the book you pick up at the end. Of course the problem with telling the meat of the story through this journal is if you don't tear the pages out and spread them across the house then you have to leave them intact and the player spends most of their time wandering around not knowing much until the end where they spend 5 minutes reading up on a large percentage of the story.  So instead you get this story fed to you though intangible 'audiologs' that are attached to what appear to be normal items at first glance until you put them down and cue the narrator. This isn't bad per se but it's clear that the developers had more focus on this being a story told through traditional means than they would have liked. They wanted the story to be told through exploring the house and picking up bits and pieces but they ended up relying a bit too heavily on the audio logs.  I smiled a bit at some points where nostalgia was used for audience hooks. There's a bunch of nostalgia spread around which seems to be one of the things that got critics hooked. The other is the lesbian romance.  Had the star of the show been a boy or the girlfriend switched with a boy then I'm sure people wouldn't have given this anywhere as much praise as it has gotten. While the VA for the star of the story delivered her lines brilliantly and with emotion, she was still voicing an average short story. The story was too short for the characters to properly hook you at all and the plot of it was rather standard life. I wouldn't be surprised if critics praised this because anything less would have possibly risked them being labeled as homophobes.  A book I read, The Lovely Bones, is somewhat similar to this in ways. Besides dealing with mature subjects it essentially features an outsider viewing their family unseen and how they live their lives. However the differences are plentiful. Besides being a written novel it benefits from it's medium and allows you to connect to the characters in the way that Gone Home didn't manage to do. The Lovely Bones also focuses on various family members including that of the outsider rather than mostly on a single one. You get a better sense of relationships as a result too.  Had Gone Home instead had the main character be a ghost viewing their family it could have really told a far more immersive story. You could have the family members actually be in the house interacting with each other rather than reading letters in an empty house. The story could have gone on a lot longer as a result allowing you to connect with the characters more. Why you could even affect at least the progression of the story by interacting with objects to influence the family members to do certain things. Though this would require far more writing, modeling and even animation to do this.  -----  Gone Home is an average story where the focus is clearly on one character and the others just serve support roles. Exploration is looking around a room, finding objects and letters that trigger story points and finding hidden rooms and passages because spooky inherited house reasons. There is a little thinking at some points to find and uncover certain points of the story but not much else.  All in all it's a risky buy even at 75% off. Not at all deserving of it's praise but it tries some interesting things that will hopefully inspire better people to have a crack at something great. Ask yourself, 'Am I the kind of person that is drawn to cheap pandering that it can make me like an average story more than I ever would rather than feel somewhat insulted at the attempt'. If Yes you might like Gone Home, if no then think about it before trying this because that teenage lesbian romance and rebellion story is the selling point here, not the exploration aspect.

The short of it: Have you ever wanted to trespass in a stranger’s house, not to pillage and plunder but to just float from room to room analyzing your surroundings, scrutinizing items and imagining what the lives of the inhabitants must be like? If so you’re gonna love the feck out of this game!  But if you’re looking for horror, suspense, action, or puzzle-solving then baby, ya’ need to look elsewhere. (*coughcoughAmnesiaCOUGH*)  Pros: -Go through someone’s house -Trash the house by throwing sh!t everywhere -Looks pwetty owo -Superb voice acting -Believable characters -Interesting rooms  -Story is about Lesbians, which was refreshing to see -90’s time capsule (much nostalgia) -Fantastic punk music *within* the game, like dayum  -Steggy! ❤    Cons: -No challenge whatsoever (You’ll look for a couple of key items, that’s it) -Lack of puzzles  -Your interaction doesn’t count for much. You can throw stuff and turn lights on/off, that’s it. -Searching simulator 2013 -Really boring if you’re not into this kind of story-based stuff -Woulda' been cool to hear about  all  of the family members problems in depth -Short (I seriously took my time with this one and finished it in a coupla' hours) -Way, way, way WAAAAAAAAAAAY too fuu-king over-priced (I know the devs gotta’ eat but for the content that’s offered I feel like it should be ftp. >o<)  My thoughts on this game: As a gay female with queer-hating parents I probably got a lot more out of this game than someone who falls outside of that spectrum. In some ways it was like seeing my own life personified as someone else, and there were quite a few things that really hit home with me. That being said, when I played the game I felt an intense craving for something that just wasn’t there. I was expecting to be challenged, to have to fill-in-the-blanks myself, to care about the characters for who they were and not just because I could relate to  one  of them….and I didn’t really find any of this in Gone Home. It was a little different and kind of fun, but it wasn’t particularly satisfying and the story didn’t leave any lasting impression on me.  As for recommending it, I can’t really recommend it as a  game . As an interactive story  YES , but not as a game, or for its gameplay.  (If this sounds like something you’d be into make sure to wait for a sale and pay no more than a couple bucks for it! Peace! ^o^ ❤ )
Dissapointing. Not worth the money.

This is game that sadly commits the worst sin of story telling imaginable; it TELLS you, rather than SHOWING you.  “Gone Home is what would happen if you took a click-and-point adventure game in the same vain as Deponia, and tried transferring it into a first person perspective. A game where you could [in theory] click on and interact with your game world in a dynamic way that makes that world feel alive. Gone home however has seemed to miss the biggest part those click-and-point adventure games had; a compelling story and actual interaction. Rather than focusing on characters that were interacting with each other, the player instead plays the cameraman. You as kaitlyn have no point in the story because you didn't have any interaction when the game starts. The game instead should have focused on the father coming home, only to realize his daughters gone and discover an entire world he really didn't know about. That would have been interesting because the father could have commented on his opinions and views of what happened, and we would have actually seen character development as the father realizes he'd done something wrong.  Instead, what they did is focus on a character who didn't have any major interaction and instead acts like the cameraman. It would have made more sense story wise if you weren't even in the game. The parents would have been interesting cameramen because they would have had revelations about their daughters world they largely ignored or pretended didn't exist, you as kaitlyn don't have that option because you weren't their to have those original interactions. Instead, the story entirely focuses on the wrong characters and the WRONG interactions. It committed a sin, and a game to focus solely on the story and have the story be a failure leaves little to grab onto.
This game is so short

An idea with a lot of potential but ultimately isn't worth it. The writers could have gone with anything, but seemingly picked the least interesting option. The characters - in so far as they are fleshed out - are flat. I bought the game knowing absolutely nothing about the plot, so it was pretty interesting to play through, but the ending was a huge let-down. There is no replay value, so if you do decide to go for it, wait for a sale.

The voice acting is good, the graphics decent and the plot has some interesting points. Exploring a big house with some mistery and read clues about the characters was to an extent enjoyable, but I didn't find it very engaging. As other people said £15 or $20 is too much for this short point and click adventure, compared to many other good quality games. I'm glad I bought it on sale. A central subject of this game is the difficulty of growing up as a lesbian in the 80s/90s. It can be an interesting subject but I found it wasn't developed enough.

Can't believe that I paid for this 'game'. It costs £15 (!) now, I paid half of that price but still I feel like I've got robbed. Trust me on this - just don't buy it. There was a massive hype created over this game. I've bought into that hype and I've wasted my money on this piece of (f)art. Just watch a youtube walkthrough first and then make a (an easy) decision. I just feel obligated to warn other players who may got fooled by some positive reviews (IGN 9.5 WTF?). And if you really like a narrative stories buy The Stanley Parable instead - it's witty and fun to play.

Way too short. Just as you're getting into it, bam done. Very predictable ending and you don't find out what happens to othe other characters. Meh. Not worth even the few dollars I got it for on sale. Needs more content.

Good storytelling, but I was left feeling unsatisfied. The ending is supposed to make you feel warm and fuzzy, but (spoiler alert) when you think about it two teenagers running away together is reckless and will probably lead to misery (doesn't matter if they are straight or gay).  I was also unsatisfied with the length of the game. It seemed way too short for the price. Additionally the game has very little gameplay in it. There are some minor puzzles but for the most part the game is simply find clue, listen to narration, find next clue, listen to next narration... Gone Home is not so much a game but a story with complicated pace control, not that there is anything wrong with that but its not something I am interested in from a video game.

Once again, I made the Dear Esther mistake of thinking this was going to be a puzzle game. It is not. It is a guided narrative. There are no puzzles to solve. If you liked Dear Esther, this game is very similar, just in a different setting. I think it's supposed to be some sort of cultural stance by the company that made it, which is probably it has been labeled one of the best games of the year, because they were gutsy or something, but if you want a puzzle game this is not it.

Storytelling, painting, movies - all of those initially went through a formative period, where writers were simply coming to grips with what this particular storytelling tool allows to do. Tons of experiments, most of them to crappy / hilarious / weird results, until the proper usage of specific storytelling medium is finally nailed down.  This game can be considered one of those 'formative period' works for games.  It is not a good game, and that's why i sincerely cannot recommend it. It is, however, a good experiment with telling a story through a game, and - in that capacity - anyone who takes games seriously should probably take a couple of hours off his/her life to suffer through Gone Home.

MINOR SPOILERS, but a WARNING to unwary players.  A 2-hour bait-and-switch story. What starts out as a possibly paranormal and very interesting mystery ends up being a passive social commentary on tolerance. You have very little agency in this game and all of its events have already unfolded.  After hearing rave reviews about this game, I checked it out and I have to say I'm disappointed with how deceiving the original premise is. I've never seen such a bait-and-switch story in a game in a long time.

Game reduced to note-searching and ambience in order to give you a good story - too bad it's a really bad story and yes, I did read every side-note too - none of those stories were any good either. Don't buy this game, don't let bad developers get anything for essentially nothing.

This game felt disappointing. I thought that there was going to be a big buildup to a big climax, or at least some puzzles to solve, but I left with nothing. It was very short, but that is perfectly fine for a small budget game. The part that was bad for me was the story. Without any spoilers, it felt much too stereotypical, and I saw the whole thing from the beginning. It felt like it could have gone in many much more interesting directions, but instead it was a very stereotypical game about a teen girl, with nothing really standing out. Even the main plot of the game, why the house is empty, left me very disappointed. Visually, it looks very good, and I am curious to see what else this team could do, but this game just fell very short for me.

Gone Home ~  An Overrated Story Exploration Video Game   While I like short story-driven games, this game didn't do it for me.   The story seems like it was ripped from a cheap mass-market paperback book.   The redeeming quality of this game is the graphics / environment, which is very well done.  I got this game very cheap on a bundle, but even so, this felt like a waste of time.

From what I heard about this game I was expecting a lot more. TL:DR Bad, predictable ending and plot, with near perfect voice work and good pacing.  First and foremost I should point out that, as far as games go, this one wasn't bad, I'd even call it good, but where it fell apart was telling an orignal story set in an orignal enviorment. From the very start of the game I was able to predict every single twist and turn in the plot from a mile away, while at the same time hoping that the story wasn't going in the direction it was (now mind you this has nothing to do with the romance plot, I'm actually a sucker for those, my problem lay in how they executed said plot). By the end I saw hope for what I thought could have been a decent, if cliched ending to what I would call an above average game, but then the ending came around and exactly what I thought would happen, and I feared would happen happened, creating an ending that just felt sappy and unrealsitc. There were several moments throughout the game where I thought from a writting persepctive 'Hell, I could do better than this'.   But of course the story isn't everything this game has to offer, there's also the walking......which is exactly as it sounds, though I did feel the walking speed was just a bit too slow, but nothing too bothersome. There was one thing that this game got perfect, and that was the performance of the actress who played Sam. When I mean this was an absolutley increadible performance worthy of, not only any AAA title, but also any film, I mean it. There were times where, despite the lack-luster story, I felt emotional soley from this girls performance.  In the end I would like to give this game my recommendation, just from the great voice work alone, but the rest of the game just isn't fun enough, and the story interesting enough for me to recommend the moments including Sam's dialogue.  Rating: Acting performance: 9/10- fantastic Gameplay: 4/10- this one is more subjective, but I just found it boring. Story: 5/10- Painfully average Graphics 5/10- They get the job done

At £2.50 or whatever it is on the sale you can't TRULY complain about this but had I spent full price I definitely would have demanded a refund. If I've played less than 2 hours I might still.  In short, this was a pseudo horror game which isn't a horror game. It sets itself up as a mystery horror, with a Resident Evil-style mansion you stroll around, but instead of zombies you have notes giving backstory. All well and good. Problem is the mansion itself, as other reviews say, is portrayed as a supernatural place, with artifacts about the occult strewn all over the place and footsteps heard around you which aren't from you.  But it isn't any of these.  It's just a walking simular you collect notes on and piece together one of the most pointless stories I've ever 'read' - there wasn't even any payout, no revelation, no final surprise or any twist - it was absolutely banal.  It presents itself as a horror mystery, but it's just a rather vacuous story which leads to nothing.  This game will not satisfy you and I've no idea why the reviews are mostly positive.  Yes, the story itself is reasonably engaging, but you're in a mystery 'horror' abandoned house and you expect more at the end than what you get.  This really is just a bit of a waste of time. It's not bad, it's just not worth very much.

We don't care... if that's who you are that's who you are. Now I get the postion that they were trying to make. how ever story aside got to give props for interactive enviroment. but seems pointless with the story being bland. Now the price tag is a bit insane seriously. It's 22 dollars canadian for little over an hour and a half of content and no replay value. personally I can't complain too much about the price because I received it in a humble bundle. I can't in good consious recomend this 'game' with a ludicrous price tag. on a extensive discount and your very very bored and have nothing else to do. maybe pick it up but be warned you can't get those 2 hours back...

I can't say I'd recommend this game to play, but might be a game worth experiencing. That is whether you watch someone else play it or just try it yourself.  I say that because I'm not really a big fan of linear games. I can tolerate them, but only to a point. Gone Home has advertisted itself as a 'Story Exploration Video Game' and it just that. You explore your environment while they take you on a ride. It's vaguely similar to theme park attractions where they shuffle you along room to room to tell you a story. Such as the peculiarly perfect placement of breadcrumb notes to lead you along the story.  The problem is, the part of the thrill of theme park attraction is buying into the experience and thrill of the environment. Gone Home tries to capture but doesn't quite reach it, at least for me. Perhaps with Oculus and some additional VR gear, it might bring the experience more to life, but until then it is nothing more than a movie you could simply watch.  Being a kid who grew up in the 90s in the suburbs with one sibling, I can say that this did tickle my nostalgia. It gave me fond memories of my own childhood. Of my friends and classmates who have I grew up with come out of the closet. Of a time where acceptance was only starting to become the popular belief. And I have a odd fondness to narrative storytelling, but even with all that Gone Home doesn't have the full experience it needs to make me want to play it again.  Gone Home is a growth in the lines of experimental narrative walking games, such as Dear Ester and Stanley Parable, and is worth a look.   ...But what you might hear as a large complaint is the full price tag of $20 USD Gone Home, while the original Dear Ester and Stanley Parable were both free game mods. I can't fully dismiss that the price tag was a deterrent since I didn't jump to grab it at full price. I've grabbed this in a Humble Weekly Bundle Leading Ladies for $15 USD, which included a pile of other games I wanted to play. However, price tag isn't something you're really reading the review for anyways, since each individual already have an idea of how much they are willing to spend on a particular game.
The way the camera moves on this game made me want to puke. Avoid.

So...  This isn't a game. Not really. It's interactive fiction. Self congratulatory interactive fiction. Trite, self congratulatory interactive fiction. Preachy, trite, self congratulatory interactive fiction.  When I heard that the team behind the excellent atmosphere in Bioshock did a game that was, in practice, what Bioshock would have been if the only thing to do in Rapture was hunt for audio logs, I was excited. I loved the world in Bioshock and thought an experience where I could wander around and learn the story of a world without constantly worrying about being shot at would be fun.  And it might have been, with different writing.  I won't comment on the controversial subject matter. That part doesn't matter to me anyway, aside from it being very banal while pretending to be very edgy. I might have giving this game a positive recommendation, except that none of the characters are particularly likeable. We're meant to sympathize and/or empathize with Sam, but Sam is such an obnoxious person; other personality traits aside; that I can't bring myself to care what happens. I suppose that could count as edgy, since characters of Sam's type are rarely shown as anything less than saintly in most popular media. So maybe the game is actually subversive after all, though I doubt it's for the reason that it thinks it is.  Anyway, I got it for 50% off, and was still unhappy with the experience. If you're interested, more power to you, but it just wasn't for me.

This is definitely not worth the $20 - Heck, it's not even worth $10. Finished it in less than two hours (I usually take my time with games too) and there is no replay value. I’ll warn you now, Gone Home is not even remotely the suspenseful game it markets itself to be. Gone Home is a contrived piece of interactive fiction that is being paraded around as a game. It is a game like Microsoft Bob was a game. It essentially acts as a medium for a subdued   coming out   and coming of age tale. By about 10 minutes into the game, you will have likely figured out that the main character’s sister   is a lesbian, and she has run away from home after meeting with disapproval from her parents.   The parents are also revealed to   have been having trouble, but they seem to have resolved their issues with a couple’s retreat, which they are on when the player character arrives home.   This is found out about 45 minutes into the game, give-or-take. Hence why the house is empty. It will only take about an hour and a half to see this easily predicted narrative come to fruition, hardly worth the $20 being asked for this piece of software. I would say that, while I do recognize that a lot of hard work was put into this software, it is worth $5 at most.  If I were to break down the score I would give the game into numbers, it would be something like the following: Gameplay: 2/10 (very shallow and primitive; like Real Myst) Story: 1/10 (very contrived; the topics explored in the narrative are shallow at best and have been covered numerous times in gaming and other media in much better ways) Graphics: 5/10 (relatively good use of current technology, but nothing groundbreaking) Audio: 10/10 (superb audio work) 18/40
A rollercoaster ride of emotion, an experience worth having for anyone who's a fan of story in games.  But not at $20.
too overpriced for a 47 second game tbh

I went in knowing nothing about this game other than the fact that people liked it.   I liked it at first too. It had great atmosphere and exploring the house was spooky and fun. Unfortunately, about a quarter of the way through your realize that there is nothing interesting happening and the payoff is a story with the emotional depth and sophistication of a young adult novel.   I probably would have been pretty into this if I played it when I was in high school, but, to avoid such spoilers as there are, I will just say, there are better ways to spend two hours exploring the game's real themes.    Gone Home is actually a game about the protagonist's sister slowly discovering that she is gay. It is done in a nice, nostalgia-driven way that has you discovering clues and recordings from her around your parents house. The game semi-successfully juxtaposes the childhood fear of isolation (home alone in a big scary house) with a quasi-adult fear of isolation (I am different from everyone else).   Knowing this going in would spoil much of the effect, as it would undercut the initial 'spooky house' section, but having not known it I feel like I kind of fell victim to a bait and switch. I came for a creepy exploration game and ended up getting a diary entry from a kid confused about growing up.  That sort of story is fine, it is just not what I signed on for and I am kind of getting tired of every plot about a gay character being a coming out story. It is like watching super hero origin movies over and over again. Surely there are interesting things that can happen to gay characters after coming out?
I tried. I really did. But I guess this is a game for people with a lot of patience and don't mind walking around. And around.
Unfortunately doesn't work with the Xbox One controller - refunded.

Gone Home is for me a very overhyped 'game'. It feels like the developers had an interesting idea , but eventually gave up on the project and settled for an at best average story, with underperforming voice actresses. There is just not really any element of surprise.  Compared to games like 'Life is strange' and 'Her Story' I simply can´t recommend this game.

Meh I would say. Nothing really interesting and I have beat the game from start to finish in one sitting. Though it was a pretty boring sitting. All I really got out of it was:  Lesbians find love. Ohhh noooo I have to goto the army!!! Byyyyeeee. OUR LOVE WILL STAND FOREVER  girl power.  M e h

This game is disappointing. The appeal is that it tells a cinematic story that's still interactive. You assume it would contain the same amount of content as a movie, but I completed it in a little more than an hour without skipping over   anything  . I looked at everything in the game. It invokes a creepy atmosphere that amounts to absolutely nothing. The one good thing the game has is its soundtrack, and you can accomplish the same thing by listening to punk and riot grrl music from the 90s.  Of course, you don't have to find out whether the game is worth purchasing or not from reviews. As I stated, the game took me less than two hours to beat, and I did   everything  . Purchase the game, set a timer when you start playing it for 1:55. If the timer goes off and you're already done with it, you can just refund it. If you aren't done with it, you can decide whether to return it then, but I'm willing to bet you'll already be done with it.
This is a two-hour first-person 'After School Special' placed in the 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' days. Chris Remo's soundtrack is decent, though.
Story is meh, gameplay is boring. It's like Myst, but super easy baby mode and you can walk around instead of clicking everywhere.
Wow! Interactive chic lit for hipsters!

How the game got so high praise is beyond me. I usually defend games that are primarily art, but this...I can't even consider it to be art. And it is bewildering that such a polarising game suspiciously doesn't have a single nehative review on metacritic out of 60 professional reviews.

Possibly good if you're 16 - and preferably female. And also, prefer females.  As a side note, this game allows you to pick up matches, and all sorts of chemicals. But you can't set any of those on fire. Or make them explode. In any way. That would be acceptable, sort of, if there were a story line.
Almost as boring as Dear Esther. It's also the gayest game I've ever played, literally.

I foolishly picked up this turd after hearing from several previously reputable gaming websites talk about what an interesting and thought-provoking experiment this was in advancing the medium.  I am an idiot.  Even if the almost non-existent gameplay mechanics reinforced the story (they don't), even if the game was wonderfully detailed (it isn't), the story itself, which the developers proclaim as the backbone to this visual novel is drivel hipster ♥♥♥♥. It's another attempt at 'progressiveness' being shoe-horned into videogames.  I'm not so annoyed by the creators of this game (despite them being bona-fide tumblrfeminists) as I am the gaming media for collectively agreeing this turd was not only a good idea but in recommending it for purchase.   I do, however, agree that this game provided an interesting and thought-provoking experiment; why are gaming journalists so full of ♥♥♥♥?

I don't know, I haven't finished yet, but I got fairly broed, really quick. I don't see the point in the game either. Your a girl, coming home to a note saying 'she' left and that you'll meet her soon. Then you go into the house and look around for stuff. And once in a while there is a diary, explaining Sams love for this girl. But all -in-all I don't really like this game!
Not worth it, I buy it under false advertising, very disappointed.

Hardly qualifies as a game.   All you do is walk around an unbelievably designed house and search for letters, and then you get the 'story' through them. Don't waste your money or your time on this garbage.

Someone stated below 'this is a game for everyone', it should have read 'this isnt a game', you wander round a 3D house reading books and letters, its an interactive 3D house not a game, my laptop more then meets the spec but it ran really poorly and I had to put everything on low, this is also well over priced at £14.99 and steam refused to refund me as I wasnt happy with the performance or the misleading product, unless you want to wander round a 3D house doing nothing execept reading then avoid this misleading garbage.

Game does not get beyond the opening menu. After forcing use of the 64bit executable I could actually change between the three menu items but no other key entries were accepted. Had to consistently ALT-TAB and close the program via right-click and 'close'. I have tried numerous video resolutions with no luck. I have 49 other games via Steam and can play them all. If I could get a refund, I would. I've noticed a stellar lack of responses from the DEV in the support requests so am removing this game from my Steam library.

It's not that I don't want to recommend this game (Or the lack there of), its just that this title isn't worth the asking price, at all. There hardly is any 'game' here. Yes, its an adventure title. I get it. But when you take into consideration the content, the length of the title, and the amount of money the devs are asking for it....This is just a rip off.  The story is intriguing and immersive. It feels real. But the story is not worth the asking price. 20 USD for this? You smoking crack, FullBright? I have played better games with better story and storytelling...'Brothers: A Story of Two Sons', 'Among the Sleep', 'Metal Gear Solid', 'The Last of Us', Just to name a few. Its good, but not that good. It certainly isn't worth all the hype and attention this title got from various big names in the game industry. It certainly isn't worthy of getting GOTY awards. I feel like the only reason this game got any attention is because the critics desperately wanted to pander to the LGBT crowd, during a time period that the game industry is under fire from feminists and other special interest groups. Pandering.   I recommend giving the game a spin. BUT ONLY IF YOU ARE ABLE TO PICK IT UP FOR <$2 (Steam Sale)
